PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Stephen Martin) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTER FOR THE ENVIRONMENT, SPORT AND TERRITORIES

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move forthwith:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the honourable member for Higgins from moving forthwith that this House censures the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories for misleading the Parliament, blatant political bias and maladministration in the disbursement of grants under the Community Cultural, Recreational and Sporting Facilities Program.
Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Costello Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the honourable member for Higgins from moving forthwith that this House censures the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories for misleading the Parliament, blatant political bias and maladministration in the disbursement of grants under the Community Cultural, Recreational and Sporting Facilities Program.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no more important role that this House has than to hold ministers to account for their conduct as ministers of the Crown and in their administration of the affairs of the Australian people. There is no worse thing that a minister can do than to mislead this parliament in relation to the conduct and the administration of the affairs of a minister. There is no clearer case than that which has been established in this House yesterday—that there is a minister who has misled the parliament and misled the Australian people, a minister who deserves the complete censure of this House for the conduct of her affairs.

PARA.TAB: It is urgently necessary that standing orders be suspended at the first available opportunity this morning so that this House can deliberate upon the things that it has been told: where it has been proven that that minister has not been candid; where it has been proven that this minister has misled this House, not once but on three occasions; and where it is clear that this is a minister who, over a period of three months in this place, has sought to concoct a gigantic tale as to the administration of her affairs and the administration of the sports rorts program.

It is absolutely clear that, in relation to that concocted tale, every piece of evidence which comes to light damns the minister further. Every piece of information—that turns up in a documentary form, that turns up in an answer to a question, that turns up from the sporting groups that have been affected, that turns up from the Auditor-General, that turns up from the involvement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), that turns up from the involvement of the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) and that turns up from the involvement of the honourable member for Jagajaga (Mr Staples)—damns this minister.

It gives the lie to the explanation that she has sought to maintain in this House that this is somehow a political program or a program of expenditure that was only ever considered on a needs basis and money was only ever granted where eligible applications were taken into account and where they were justified on a needs basis. That whole story has been a concoction. Sure, it has had its lighter moments like the great big whiteboard, but now it is a matter of the utmost seriousness. This is a minister who has been caught out and this is a minister who must go.

This minister has been trying to maintain in this House that she granted only eligible grants. She said to a parliamentary committee that the department, through its system, threw out all those that were ineligible. She said, `I never saw them'. Yet we had the spectre in this House yesterday of the minister, when making an additional response to a question in this House, freely admitting that the Pine Rivers youth band was not on the schedule and that it was not considered an eligible grant, but that it was granted on the basis of representation from none other than the Attorney-General.

The minister took an ineligible applications considered it eligible and gave it money. The Attorney-General needed to prop up his chances in a by-election. The minister claimed she had never seen this ineligible application, yet she picked it out on the basis of the representation of the Attorney-General and she granted it. She has clearly misled the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts and she has clearly misled this parliament. She is a minister that deserves censure.

She is also a minister that is completely at odds with her own Prime Minister, for she has completely dumped the Prime Minister into this whole affair. She had him, on her say-so, saying this as recently as Monday, 21 February 1994:

SPEECH.PARA: Those opposite may laugh, but all her proposals were eligible ones.

It took one day for the minister to come in here, as she did yesterday, and to nominate the Pine Rivers youth band as an ineligible grant which she granted. She put herself at odds with her Prime Minister. She has now put the Prime Minister in a position where he has misled this parliament because he said that only eligible grants were given. On her own admission yesterday, the minister gave an ineligible grant, one that she was never supposed to see, on the say-so of the Attorney-General, and she granted money out of the taxpayers' funds for blatant political advantage.

PARA.TAB: That is not the only time she has misled this parliament. She has repeatedly misled this parliament. On 15 December 1993, she said:

SPEECH.PARA: The decisions were made by me as the minister because I have responsibility as portfolio minister . . .

We now know that was false. We know that the minister did not make the decision which had the effect of giving money to the Altone Park complex out of the sports rorts funds. In this parliament yesterday, she said:

The Prime Minister was involved in the government's decision to fund $1 million as a specific election commitment towards the funding of the Altone Park complex. What I then said was that I had responsibility for how that could be and should be done.

She did not make the decision, contrary to what she told this House on 15 December 1993: `The decisions were made by me as the minister'. An ex-staffer of the Prime Minister was fighting an election for the marginal Labor seat of Perth, which he was worried he would not win. So he went out and made a commitment to the Altone Park complex. The Prime Minister told the minister to go and put that into effect. She had nothing to do with that decision. She freely admitted that yesterday. She was just told to go and find the money from her sports rorts fund, and she found $250,000 for the 1993-94 year when there was no program for the 1993-94 year and when there was no budget appropriation for it. She entered into a commitment on the say-so of the Prime Minister without an appropriation for future funding. How can you say the Prime Minister was not involved? She dobbed him right in yesterday and said that he was involved in that matter.

PARA.TAB: That was not the only time she misled the parliament. It was absolutely clear that last year she misled the parliament. Last year she was maintaining that she had given every document to the Auditor-General, yet we had a document which the Auditor-General quite candidly said was never given to him. A fax was sent to the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) from the minister's office, classifying his seat as safe Labor and asking him which projects he would like funded in his electorate.

The minister has never answered. She has never given an explanation as to what the purpose of that fax was, never given an explanation as to how it came into effect, never given an explanation as to why the Auditor-General never saw it and never given an explanation as to how she was able to stand up and say candidly in this House that she had given every document to the Auditor-General when we proved conclusively that that was false and that, in saying it, she has misled this parliament.
Misleading the parliament is a case where a minister should be sacked. The 1976 report of the royal commission on Australian government administration stated:

SPEECH.PARA: In cases where the minister has misled parliament, condoned or authorised a blatantly unreasonable use of executive power or more vaguely where the minister's behaviour contravenes established standards of morality, resignation or dismissal is the appropriate action.

The appropriate action, according to the doctrines of the Westminster parliamentary system, is for this minister to resign. If she will not resign, the appropriate action is for the Prime Minister to dismiss her. An article in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald states:
There is a growing view in Labor ranks that the only way of cutting the Government free from the sports rorts tangle is to cut Mrs Kelly free of the sports portfolio.

That is the only way that you will disentangle yourselves from this matter. If you do not have the decency to assert proper standards because it is warranted by the Westminster system and the doctrine of accountability, you could at least have the decency to try to save yourselves from the odium and the contempt of a public who now sees the Prime Minister as someone who cannot maintain standards, who cannot hold accountability to the public, and who has grown imperial and arrogant in office. In respect of public accountability and administration he needs to send this minister off to the back bench where she should have been and where she should now be.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson Mr M.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. Yesterday was a classic example of the fact that this government has totally abused the whole parliamentary process. It got caught out and it will now pay the penalty for it. Let us go back to the question of eligibility. We will look at a minute from Ms Dal Bon. Do honourable members remember Ms Dal Bon? She was the person who really damned this government and the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly). Let us have a look at what she said about validating program eligibility:

SPEECH.PARA: Applications not meeting program eligibility are generally weeded out by the Department on receipt. However, with the compression of the timetables this is not always the case and I am advised that sometimes projects not meeting program guidelines are included in schedules submitted to the Minister's Office, albeit on schedule three.
In the current round I insisted that all such applications be removed from the schedule and I recommend this practice be adopted in the future.

What did the minister say about that? Did she say, `Yes, I took Ms Dal Bon's advice?'. No, she did not. She said that Ms Dal Bon was doing what she told her to do. Not only has the minister taken credit for this eligibility question; she has also specifically said that Ms Dal Bon has no right to take the credit for it. Yesterday we saw a classic indication of the fact that she has misled this House, probably in the most obscene way that most members, including those who have been here for many years, like the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), have ever seen. She quite blatantly misled the parliament.

PARA.TAB: The sad fact is that yesterday you sat there on the back bench and you knew exactly what was happening. You knew that she was dragging you down to levels that you did not think were possible. She has totally implicated the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the front bench and yourselves.

If honourable members are going to look at what is required in this, I will take them to the Western Australian royal commission. This is now starting to smack of WA Inc. Do you know what Brian Burke did in WA Inc.? He just happened to use public funds via sporting clubs for the distribution of his dirt bag. The commission established to review public sector finances said:

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from the obvious point that funds at the disposal of the Minister, or available for payment at ministerial direction, can be perceived to be open to political preferment, the practice is contrary to the basic principle of parliamentary control of the annual disbursement of funds through appropriations made by law . . .

The essential point is that the budget provides for, and Parliament approves, annual appropriations for departments such as the arts, and sport and recreation within the context of overall budget constraints and priorities. It is possible for bodies that benefit from these appropriations to then be able to double and triple dip into the public purse through grants from the Health Promotion Foundation or through ministerial grants . . .

The Commission considers that the allocation of revenue by law to ministers and statutory authorities for disbursement at their discretion is an undesirable practice that can be perceived to be open to abuse.

Not only can it be perceived to be open to abuse but it has been very openly abused. When that minister came in here yesterday she knew that she had taken that Pine Rivers grant outside the guidelines—the guidelines over which she had attacked Ms Dal Bon for taking the credit for changing them. She must go because she deliberately misled this parliament.

PARA.TAB: The gall of this government to attack the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) the day before in relation to his comments is another example of the fact that the government will go to quite extraordinary lengths to justify its own dirt. This is dirt—this is dirty. The practice of this minister in relation to this program was sanctioned on high, as evidenced again by Ms Dal Bon, who was told when she came into this department that `we did these things as sanctioned on high'.

Who was on high? Was it the minister? Was it the Prime Minister? Why is it that every major newspaper in this country has called for the resignation or the sacking of this minister? Why will she not go? Because the Prime Minister is up to his ears in this whole dirty, smelly rort. You know that he is and the rest of the country knows that he is. She misled the House and she should either resign or she should be sacked.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will not facilitate this motion, although we understand absolutely the background to the opposition's moving of it. It is the hope of the mover of this motion, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), that he is going to surf into the Liberal Party leadership on the back of it. As he gets lazier and lazier, as he handles the issue and makes more and more mistakes in his actual presentation in the chamber, his ultimate motive gets more and more obvious. He is caught in this place in a conflict of disloyalties. The conflict is not with any particular leadership; it is which leader he wants to knock off. Which leader does he want to knock off?

—Mr Speaker, I raise a very simple point of order. This is a motion to suspend standing orders. The Leader of the House has been on his feet for a minute and a half and he is nowhere remotely close to the substance of the motion, and he knows it.

—Order! The honourable member for Bennelong will resume his seat. There is no point of order. In the course of the presentation of the two previous speakers, the issue was quite widely canvassed and the Leader of the House is in order.

—You set the standards in this. You broadened the debate in your moving of this motion. We accepted it. Now we will answer it, thanks very much, without interruption. As I said, he is caught in a conflict of disloyalty. He has Michael Kroger parading on television endorsing Bronwyn Bishop in the certain knowledge that, through that process of endorsing Bronwyn Bishop, he is putting the skids under the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson).

PARA.TAB: He hopes that in the morass he will come forward as the alternative leader of the Liberal Party. If he gets enough destabilisation going, gets the old Kroger he lunches with regularly to plot the destabilisation of his leader, he will then see what happens down the line—`After all, I can make my reputation on this matter so I will keep my name up there in lights after I have successfully white-anted him'.

But the honourable member for Higgins also has another strategy because he does not know whether that is enough. He does not know whether he really wants to knock his leader off at this stage. He thinks that perhaps he will have a go at the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Dr Wooldridge). So what does he do? He has his factotum parading around the place using information, which he produced inside the Liberal Party, to write letters to the press, undermining the—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on a point of order: no matter how much latitude may have been extended to the honourable member for Higgins and the honourable member for Ballarat, at least what they had to say related to the minister on the rack. At least what they had to say was relevant to the issue. The minister now speaking has not even come within a hundred miles of the substance of the motion and you should bring him back to the motion and rule him out of order.
—Order! The minister is responding to the particular issue before the House and as part of that he will come to the issue.

—Those opposite have their factotum running around the country, white-anting their deputy leader, revealing the internal balance of the Liberal Party to do it. We do not facilitate life for people who wish to betray their leaders. We will oblige them to skate through on their own merits and not off the back of their illegitimate claims here.

PARA.TAB: Let me start to deal with the issues that the honourable member for Higgins raised. Do opposition members want to hear that? For starters he raised the subject of the Pine River band. He told us that this was a get-up by the Prime Minister to support the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch), who was then selected as Attorney-General pro tem, to assist his by-election campaign. Is that correct? That is what the honourable member said.

The band's application was received on 1 September 1992, two days before the closing date for applications. The department advised the applicants in writing on 4 September that at that stage they were ineligible. They then wrote back virtually straightaway to appeal against this decision. On 13 January the grant was awarded. I do not know whether the honourable member for Higgins recollects the timetable of the time, but that was well in advance of any particular by-election even being considered.

This is how he is getting away with this—`slip sliding' away. He has stopped actually thinking about this issue. He stopped actually any detailed consideration of the matters before him. Any requirement upon him to be accurate is no longer a matter of interest to him because, fundamentally, he is intellectually lazy. Fundamentally, he has only one target and it does not happen to be Minister Kelly. She happens to be merely a way station target on the way through to his leader, or at least to his deputy leader—whatever particular instance he considers fit.

For starters, the honourable member for Higgins misled the House with dates that were readily available to him when he got up and determined that this had been cynically introduced in a by-election context, to amplify the point he sought to make that somehow or other this was a deal aimed at assisting a person who was in the process of going through an election. That is the first bit of nonsense from him. Quite emphatically he was wrong in his allegation that this was put up by the Attorney-General to get him through. He advocated it in exactly the same way as members on this side of the House and members on that side of the House, including the Leader of the Opposition, advocated the claims of various elements within the group.

Then we go to the suggestion put forward in relation to Altone Park that somehow or other this was connected to this activity in a way to discredit the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister made a statement during the election campaign that he would fund to the tune of $1 million—$750,000 of it directly off the budget and $250,000 out of this program—a $7 million project that is well supported by local authorities and by the state government in Western Australia, a very substantial project. This was a statement during the election campaign as an election undertaking, albeit in the seat of Perth. Fine. There is no walking back from that. But what I resent in that particular process is the suggestion that somehow those opposite regard this as a reason the minister ought to resign. If they regard that as a reason the minister ought to resign, perhaps they could explain to us the difference, in anything other than scale—the difference in scale is massive, of course—between that particular election undertaking and the undertaking of the Leader of the Opposition in Cairns during the election campaign.

What is the particular difference? The particular difference is, of course, $29,250,000. You make a claim that there are inappropriate administrative processes of proceeding here. What administrative processes proceeded in that particular problem? Was it a consideration undertaken by the Higher Education Council? Was it passed through the higher education budget processes of the department and given consideration in regard to priorities: Cairns versus other alternatives around the place? Was that a consideration of influence due? Was it a consideration based on what was available to you when you were ostensibly cutting public expenditure that you would do that $30 million? Did you contemplate that you might have to, say, remove money from Sydney University or the University of Western Australia or whatever to pay for it? `No. I calculated in my head three times 10, as I made it, and that came to $30 million, boys. I worked it out and it came to three times 10. Then I went up to Cairns and I said, in virtually the same interview, "Yes, we've got a great Liberal candidate up here; he is going to win that election. I am here supporting him, and here is a bag of money, 30 million bucks on the knocker—no research, nothing. You vote for us, you get it"'. You have the hide to walk into this place and offer a criticism of the minister, offer a criticism of the Prime Minister, with filthy hands like that.

I do not take any notice of honourable members who get up and talk about the Western Australian royal commission. That commission declared the Western Australian parliament corrupt; the structure of the Western Australian parliament, it says, is corrupt. We await the actions of the Court Liberal government to reform the corruption of the Western Australian parliament—and we wait in vain.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for this debate has expired.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Can you provide some guidance? As I suspect we may well be about to have a division on this matter, can you advise the House whether the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories is entitled to come in and vote when she is not even rostered on this day and she did not even front in the chamber for this debate?
—There is no point of order. Resume your seat.

That the motion (Mr Costello's) be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca The Hon C.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SCIACCA
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Further development of HMAS Stirling, Garden Island, WA.

SPEECH.PARA: HMAS Stirling is located on Garden Island, Cockburn Sound, 60 kilometres south of Perth, in Western Australia. HMAS Stirling provides maintenance, supply and operational support for assigned and visiting warships as well as port berthing and shipside and administrative services. Additionally, it will become the home base for the Collins class submarines.

PARA.TAB: The overall development of HMAS Stirling comprises three stages. Stage one was largely completed in 1978, with additional works progressing through to stage two, which covers the development from 1989 to 1996. Stage three extends the development from 1996 to the year 2000. This proposal, which continues the stage two development, will provide additional operational, logistic, maintenance and training support prior to the planned stage three development.

The development is to support the needs of the approved concept of a two-ocean navy. The works proposed in the development include a helicopter support facility, a small arms range, an upgrade of the powerhouse, increased fuel storage, training facilities, a science and technology facility, torpedo intermediate maintenance facilities and extensions to the Submarine Training and Systems Centre. It is anticipated that construction will commence mid-year and continue until mid-1996. As at October 1993, the estimated cost for this proposal was $48.9 million. I commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition, naturally, supports the motion moved by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Sciacca). This arises from a decision taken by previous governments to considerably increase the capacity of the Garden Island defence facility. As has been mentioned by the parliamentary secretary, this proposal is to continue with stage two as a precursor to stage three, which will take the total project out to the year 2000.

PARA.TAB: The most important element is of course the demonstration in technical terms of the reality of a two-ocean naval concept. This was a concept which was developed back in the 1970s. For a long time Australia tended to take the view that its navy had to be based on the east coast and was part of a British Commonwealth naval presence in the South-East Asian and Pacific region. What has been significant about the change in address in the last few years is the acceptance of the fact that Australia is a continent surrounded principally by two oceans; namely, the Pacific and the Indian oceans.

The significance of the decision to build up the Garden Island facility was the recognition that we had to maintain on the west coast of Australia a significant military presence, especially a naval presence, because so much of our trade—especially with the Middle East, Africa and certainly Europe—crosses the Indian Ocean. Therefore, it is essential that we have a naval facility on the western coast which could protect the trade routes into and out of Australian territorial waters.

This project covers a number of elements: the helicopter support facility, the final stage of the power development project, and further training facilities including facilities for the submarine training centre which will support the presence of the Collins class submarines based at Garden Island. Overall, this is a major project. It will cost nearly $48 million but will go a significant part of the distance towards ensuring that by the year 2000 we will have on the west coast of Australia a totally integrated military technological capacity with support facilities for the Australian navy.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1993-94Cognate bills:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1993-94APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1993-94

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 22 February, on motion by Mr Beazley:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday afternoon, before debate on the appropriation bills was interrupted, I was speaking of the fear many Gippslanders have in relation to the build-up of fuel in the Great Dividing Range and the East Gippsland forests. This concern is directed at the failure of various authorities to engage in sufficient and regular fuel reduction burnings. It is no exaggeration to say that many East Gippslanders believe that, unless urgent steps are taken to reduce the amount of scrub and bush that has grown up over hundreds of thousands of hectares, we will face circumstances as catastrophic as those New South Wales faced during its recent disastrous fires.

PARA.TAB: But I hasten to add that it is not just East Gippsland which is at risk. There is growing concern in South Gippsland also at the failure of authorities to engage in fuel reduction burning. This leads to a very dangerous situation. Mr Bill Davies, a much respected former president of the Shire of South Gippsland, wrote a letter to the Shire of South Gippsland on this very issue. I believe that Mr Davies's warnings, based on his experience of living and working throughout this region, must be taken with the utmost seriousness. Allow me to quote from that submission:

SPEECH.PARA: I am very concerned that there are areas of Crown Land in our shire where the fire danger is growing rapidly because of lack of controlled burning.

Whilst there has been some controlled burning in the Wilsons Promontory National Park I believe that there needs to be larger areas burnt each year otherwise there will eventually be a total disaster out there, especially in the area originally known as the back of Yanakie.

On a recent visit out there I noticed that since the grazing of cattle has ceased in the area known as the old aerodrome, the manuka scrub is starting to spread. If something is not done about this the whole area from the entrance of the park to Tidal River will become one big death trap. If a fire gets going out there on a bad day there will be no way of stopping it.

Another area of great concern to me is the Crown Land to the west of Waratah Bay. There are some fire tracks there but I feel that they too are death traps as they are not wide enough. Other areas of Crown Land around Foster could also pose serious problems on a day of high temperature and winds.

I wish to place on the public record of the debate on the bills before the House the concern of so many Gippslanders and, I believe, Victorians at large that the lessons of the New South Wales bushfires will not be learnt. The authorities, particularly the state government of Victoria, are now on notice that urgent action is needed if we are to minimise—we can never totally eliminate—the risk of bushfires. I certainly intend forwarding a copy of the Hansard as well as the representations made to me by East and South Gippslanders to the relevant ministers in Victoria. I certainly look forward to a complete review of the fuel reduction policies and actions of various state departments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my comments to the general appropriation strategy of the Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development and refer to some of the underlying theoretical approaches that are appropriate in that area. Historically, in the industry policy area Australia has oscillated between a number of different theoretical approaches. The neoclassical approach of non-intervention, of allowing the markets to rule, has always been an influential player in debates although rarely followed absolutely. The crude protectionist approach, encompassing high tariff walls and blanket assistance to industry, has essentially dominated Australian industry policy for most of this century. Also influential in the debate, although again rarely applied to any great extent, is what I would describe as the political economy approach. It could also perhaps be described as a statist approach of selective intervention in various sectors.

PARA.TAB: The neoclassical approach to industry policy is intrinsically flawed because it fails to acknowledge the influence of externalities, particularly the role of technological change, the implications of environmental damage and a variety of other issues that are simply not recognised in the theoretical model. It is also flawed because it treats all industries the same. We all remember the famous comment by a member of the Reagan administration: `Microchips and potato chips, it is all just chips, what is the difference?'. Different industries and different types of products have a variety of different spin-offs and obviously different multiplier effects. The neoclassical approach sees competitive advantage as essentially a static thing and something which is largely bestowed upon a country by factors such as land, location and natural resources.

What I have described as the crude protectionist approach is also intrinsically flawed. That is increasingly recognised across the political spectrum in this country. It tends to entrench inefficiency and direct resources into the wrong areas, into inward looking industries, and limit the amount of resources that can be directed towards potentially export oriented and internationally competitive industries.

The political economy approach, which has essentially been the approach endorsed by the left in Australian politics over many years, has been put into some difficulty by the internationalisation of our economy. There is still substantial merit in this approach. But one thing that needs to be acknowledged is that the effective internationalisation of Australia's economy over the past 10 or 15 years has rendered much of the policy approaches within the political economy school of thought ineffective or just downright wrong.

As we move towards an industry statement or part of a broader statement relating to industry policy, my concern is that we are drifting into a more ad hoc approach—back to the 1970s in some respects—where we will be assisting certain industries and providing certain packages and particular initiatives without having a broad theoretical framework underpinning what we do. Contrary to the headline in this morning's Age, which I hasten to correct, I am a strong interventionist. The article was accurate, but the headline was not. It is important, as the government moves away from a fairly strong market forces oriented industry policy to a more interventionist policy, that there is a serious theoretical underpinning of that policy. It should not just be on the basis, `Oh, it seems like a good idea' or `Other countries are doing it' or `Commonsense suggests that we should do this' or `Pragmatic considerations dominate'. We need to have an underlying theory.

TALK.START.PARA: —But Cook is not moving away.
—I would leave that one up in the air for the time being. There have been a lot of developments in theory in this area in recent times. I want to refer to a few of them.

PARA.TAB: Strategic trade theory is one which essentially acknowledges that what has been occurring in the world in recent years is a major change in the structure of trade. Increasingly, trade is being dominated by intra-corporate trade with increases in factors such as barter and the like. Externalities now dominate international trade. It is characterised by oligopolistic tendencies. Therefore, notions of free market forces are inappropriate in that sort of context. It is logical and appropriate for government to intervene in order to assist internationally competitive industries within its territory to compete within that environment.

New growth theory is a recent development which actually had its origins back in the 1950s but effectively came into its own in the mid-1980s. This theory challenges the neoclassical model with respect to the issue of externalities. It argues basically that the key force in economic growth is technological change and the development of human and technological capital, as such, and that there is a major role for government to play in stimulating growth and development in those areas. The private sector tends to underinvest in things like human capital, development of technology and research and development primarily because the benefits of such investment accrue very substantially to the world at large and less to the private individual or corporation that actually achieves the breakthrough. Therefore, there is a major role for government in assisting that sort of process.

There has also been a substantial school of thought that could be described under the title `post-Fordism' or with the term `networking'; the two approaches tend to merge into one. This argues basically that a massive change is going on in the whole structure of economic activity in the industrialised world, that the old days of large factories with Taylorist production lines—with individual workers involved in very precise but very limited activities that did not involve much use of their brains and was all organised in a rigid hierarchy—are rapidly disappearing; and that production more and more is becoming located in smaller corporations with highly flexible, highly skilled workers, often linked to each other in networks and performing a range of different parts of the production process, rather than the entire whole, as was the case previously in the typical Fordist-type factory.

Michael Porter, in his book The Competitive Advantage of Nations and in other works, has put forward a fairly comprehensive theoretical approach that relates primarily to industry policy but is also relevant to broader economic policy. The essence of Porter's argument is that the key factors in international competitiveness now are what he describes as advanced factors such as skills, the capacity to innovate and the like, and that basic factors such as natural resources, land and location are becoming less and less important in a country's international competitiveness relative to these advanced factors.

What Porter also argues is that it is possible for government and society to create advanced factors and that there is a major role for government intervention in economic activity in order to enhance the creation of advanced factors that will make a major contribution to international competitiveness. The types of areas that are involved include: education, research and development, marketing, innovation, communications and the like. The best competitive advantage is based on these advanced factors and not on the basis of reducing costs and the basic factors.

Robert Reich has also contributed substantially to this debate in his book The Work of Nations in which he argues that the national economy is effectively disappearing in the way that we have known it and that the critical issue which now faces us is primarily what work is actually being done by the people in any nation. He believes that the key focus of economic policy, industry policy and the like should be on education and training. This is because the skills of our work force and the nature of the work that is actually being performed by our workers up and down the hierarchy are the critical factors which will determine our standard of living and our wealth. This has also been pushed further by Ray Marshall whom I had the pleasure of meeting yesterday. He has co-authored a book with Mark Tucker called Thinking for a Living.

Based on all of these theoretical developments and a number of other things, I would suggest that the key aspects of our industry policy should be based on the following themes. Policies that run counter to internationalisation will almost certainly be ineffective and possibly harmful. The promotion of high quality education and training is probably the paramount thing that government can do to assist in economic development. Industry policy should focus primarily on indirect assistance through the enhancement of factors such as research and development, access to capital, use of advanced technology and the availability of skilled workers. Obsessive interest in costs will produce limited benefits. Government intervention can enhance the overall economic development of a nation if it is founded on a comprehensive overall strategy. Assistance directed at linkages between firms, between industries and between sectors is just as important as assistance directed at individual firms.

Intervention should also focus on issues like work organisation and factory design, factors that are critical in competitiveness but that tend to be left behind a bit in the debate. Government has a vital role in fostering the flow of ideas and innovation through industry, acting as a knowledge broker. Industry policy should be directed to achieving the broadest possible internationally competitive industrial base, not the broadest possible industrial base per se, nor the status quo. Assistance should be targeted, not indiscriminate.

Finally, the modern industrial economy is, in my view, so complex that the crude application of any single theory will not necessarily produce the results that theory indicates should occur. We have moved a long, long way from industrial Europe of the 1870s—or, indeed, the 1820s—when some of the basic theories such as the neoclassical school, Marxist economics and the like first emerged. The society with which we are now dealing is radically different from the societies around which those theories were developed.

We can see a lot of the theoretical developments that I have referred to in the structural changes that have been occurring in the economies throughout the Western world, including our own. There is clearly a growth in smaller firms. The phenomenon of networking is taking off in many countries and is providing the basis of competitive advantage in a number of European countries in particular.

Specialisation in particular parts of the production process, the development of flexible manufacturing technology through the use of microelectronics and smart machines is having a major impact. More contracting out of particular functions is occurring—not because of new right conspiracies, attempts to break unions or to beat on-costs but primarily because the economics of contracting out, as opposed to doing things in-house, has altered as a result of technological change.

The spread of advanced manufacturing technology—unfortunately Australia is behind most of the rest of the industrialised world in this area—is also instituting substantial change. I would recommend to honourable members the work of the Cooperative Research Centre for Intelligent Decision Systems in Melbourne which is doing some landmark work in this area. The distinction between manufacturing and services is blurring because the distinction between goods and services is blurring. Lots of goods that are now produced are linked to services. They have services built in which are related to them.

Internationalisation is something that we are all aware of. I would urge honourable members to keep in mind the fact that internationalisation should be truly international. Yes, we do have to look at Asia but everybody else is too. Opportunities are coming down the track in the world beyond Asia. The next tigers should be where we are focusing on just as much. I think Latin America is a fairly good example of that.

Australia has problems to deal with. We still have an export sector that is absolutely dominated by resource industries. We have limited clustering of our industries and huge gaps. We have very low levels of advanced manufacturing technology take-up. Our management quality is, in general, substantially inferior to most of the industrialised world. We have a low savings ratio. We have declining investment in infrastructure. We have foreign ownership, which in itself is not a problem but when it involves restrictions on the ability of the Australian subsidiary to export to other countries—for example in the case of ICI—then it is a problem; whereas other countries tend to do the reverse and allow foreign ownership and investment on the basis that export will occur.

We have an incredibly fragmented domestic market and regulatory structure which is yet another disastrous product of our outrageously outdated three-tiered system of government. There are weaknesses in conventional solutions, as I have indicated before. Market forces, if left to rule, will ensure that we remain, in Michael Porter's terms, a factor driven economy, vulnerable to cyclical fluctuations and essentially dependent upon natural resource based industries. Therefore, relative to the rest of the world, we will continue to decline.

Indiscriminate protection, and that includes indiscriminate import replacement and indiscriminate use of government purchasing, will essentially impede the development of international competitiveness. By themselves, those sorts of strategies have some merit, if they are targeted to particular industries that have export competitiveness potential, but an indiscriminate approach will simply distract attention from the main game, which is international competitiveness, and will ensure that we effectively reintroduce the tariff wall by another means.

I am not so much critical of notions such as import replacement per se. I argue that we have to ask: what imports are we replacing? There are certain imports that we should not be trying to replace. It is a logical strategy to pursue others which offer potential competitive opportunities for Australia in order to boost our export opportunities.

A key issue which the government has to confront is that we have not yet outgrown the obsession with costs. We discovered 10 or so years ago that we have a bit of a problem internationally which we have to deal with. The basic mistake we are making is assuming that the only problem we have is with costs and that, therefore, everybody is trumpeting about micro-economic reform, the Hilmer report and various other things. That is a backward looking strategy. If people read Michael Porter and various other works, they will see why. It fails to address the real issues with respect to competitive advantage, such as quality, innovation and research and development.

We may be able to reduce our costs to business by having lower electricity prices. Big deal! Exactly the same types of things will be going on amongst our competitors, in spades. The issue is: are we improving the quality of our product? Are we developing new innovations that lead the world? That is where the real gain is. Unfortunately, the obsession with costs is creating a situation in which people in business are able to blame everybody else but themselves for Australia's economic problems.

There is an incredible culture in business of people believing their own propaganda. They believe that it is all the government's fault, that it is all this regulation and that it is all these additional cost burdens and the like. There are certain situations in which that is true, but it is a minor part of the equation. We have to shift the focus away from those things and divest ourselves of our obsession with costs. We need to tackle the problems; that is fine. But we need to focus on the real game.

Currency manipulation is another issue which is basically a bit of a dead end. It can produce short-term results, but again it does not really affect the key factors in international competitiveness in the longer term. We need to be a bit wary of things such as industry plans, which sound good and had significant success in the 1980s in certain sectors. Industry plans in the TCF, vehicle and steel industries were very good. Those industries are mature industries that were in crisis at the time. They are fairly highly unionised and are capable of a tripartite approach. A lot of the emerging industries are not in the same situation. So if we are to have things called industry plans, I suggest they will be radically different.

We need to be wary of cargo cult attitudes to things such as big projects. In my view, Australia has not ever psychologically recovered from the Snowy Mountains scheme. We are all searching out there for the Holy Grail of the great big project that will save the day. We need to be wary of getting into dutch auctions with other countries for the favours of multinational corporations. At the end of the day, their decisions will largely be driven by basic factors such as the quality of our work force, the stability of our political system and our access to markets rather than particular tax breaks that are offered. There is probably a place for some of that, but we have to be very wary not to get too far into that. If we do, we should be getting good deals out of it, such as the Taiwanese do.

Indiscriminate tax concessions such as the research and development tax concession worry me a bit. On balance, that tax concession has probably been a good thing. It has probably made a significant contribution, but I feel it is much more effective to target things such as that pro-actively. Therefore, in my view, the types of initiatives that the government should be pursuing are things like substantially boosting the cooperative research centres program.

I recommend that honourable members visit the cooperative research centres in their areas. I have already visited a couple and I am going to a couple more. Some of the work that is going on there is very worth while. It is bringing together some of the innovative companies with people in universities, the CSIRO, et cetera, who are working on innovation and developing new products and new techniques. That sort of work will form the basis of Australia's international competitiveness in the future.

The government is just starting to get involved with stimulating networking. The Danish experience here is stark. A relatively small investment of $30 million in a networking program has been a key factor in a massive turnaround in the Danish economy in the past few years. There are a number of other examples, such as more intensive export assistance and more direct expenditure in education and training. There needs to be much greater commitment in that area. Breaking down the segmentation between different disciplines is also important. Concentrating on the export prospects of our services industry such as the law, engineering and education should also be vitally important.

The key thing is to deliver assistance indirectly through things such as marketing assistance, management consultancies, the cooperative research centres and technology advice, as has been done effectively throughout our history by CSIRO and the agricultural departments with people in the rural sector. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The appropriation bills give members the opportunity to canvass economic and social issues of interest and concern to the nation. It is also a time to focus on the changed economic and social objectives of this Labor administration. A few recent events which have claimed public attention offer some clues. The first is the wharf strike still in progress in Sydney, which has crippled our export trade. The second is the sports rorts affair. After all the uproar and compelling evidence yesterday that both the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) have misled the House, we saw the scandalous situation this morning where the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) refused to allow the bringing on of a censure motion against the minister, who after all was in the building, because she came into the chamber to vote when that procedural matter was voted on.

PARA.TAB: I refer to two pieces in the media this morning about the sports minister. The editorial in this morning's Herald-Sun states:
Nor has Mrs Kelly said anything to change the view that she has forfeited her right to remain in the Ministry.

SPEECH.PARA: The political correspondent in the Australian states:

PARA.TAB: Ros Kelly showed by her performance yesterday that she is no longer just an isolated figure of fun in politics but a serious, continuing liability for the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: So, under those circumstances, and with the media baying like that, I have to say that it is quite extraordinary that the Leader of the House would not allow us to bring on a censure motion this morning.

TALK.START.PARA: —She is an embarrassment to democracy.

—She is an embarrassment to the government and the nation. The third event is the government's response to the Burdekin report on mental health. The fourth is the government's creation of a nanny state style kindergarten police that now prohibit kindies from singing Christmas carols. The fifth is the panic response—and this will strike a chord with the minister at the table, the Special Minister of State (Mr Walker)—to the Mabo issue, which now means that the whole question of native title will be tied up in the courts of Australia for years and years to come. The final event is the crass backdown by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) as witnessed in the new industrial relations legislation.

PARA.TAB: It is not all bad news for the government. Federal Labor has become good at three things: selling what we all know to be pork pies to the electorate, capitulating to the trade union bureaucracy, and caressing the activist classes in the special interest groups. The current Labor Party is not the party of Curtin and Chifley. Curtin united a nation. Chifley stood up to the trade union wreckers. Even Evatt said that he would not be dictated to by sectional interests. The three of these large Labor figures also had a profound respect for the parliament and its traditions, a respect that is not accorded to the parliament by the current Prime Minister.

In a matter of days it will be the anniversary of the greatest pack of lies ever told to the Australian electorate; the anniversary of the Prime Minister's most gigantic lies of all. Can honourable members imagine Curtin or Chifley behaving as the present Prime Minister—
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The honourable member for Bruce should withdraw that expression.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which expression?
—I think you referred to lies.
—Indeed, I said the Prime Minister's lies.
—You will withdraw that expression.
—I did not say he was a liar.
—You will withdraw.

—I withdraw. In a matter of days it will be the anniversary of the Prime Minister's greatest distortions of all time in what he said to the electorate at the time of the last election campaign. Can honourable members imagine Curtin or Chifley behaving as the present Prime Minister did in the last election? Can honourable members imagine them basing their cases on the deliberate misrepresentation of their opponents' major policies—not on the consequences of the policies but a deliberate misrepresentation of their major policies—and then compounding the electoral felony by lying about their post-electoral intentions? The present incumbent cannot claim to be a part of the tradition of Curtin or Chifley. He is really in the tradition of Jack Lang and Billy Hughes. He shares Lang's contempt for parliament and the rat cunning of Billy Hughes. Like Hughes, he will chase any special, narrow and unrepresentative interest group down a burrow for a vote. Does any member of this House doubt for a moment that the Prime Minister and his office were up to their necks in the sports rorts affair? Of course not. Their speciality is using the funds of hardworking Australians to bribe sectional interest groups.

PARA.TAB: Furthermore, the response of the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) to the Burdekin report is instructive. Burdekin found, among many other chronic problems, a crisis among homeless young people, and mounting problems among those afflicted with psychiatric illnesses such as manic depression and schizophrenia. Burdekin, who has a long association with Labor personalities, has been both shamed and ashamed by the government's response. The so-called party of compassion has responded with slow derision to his clear manifestation of the plight of the homeless and the mentally ill. Frankly, as far as the homeless young people and those with psychiatric illnesses are concerned, the government could not care less.

This is not the tradition of Curtin and Chifley. It is now the tradition of Keating and Lang. If there are no votes in it, it does not exist. Many of the homeless do not vote. It is a bit hard for them to get on the rolls if they do not have an address. Many schizophrenics do not vote. But if the homeless and schizophrenics were able to form themselves into clubs in a couple of marginal seats, the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, the Deputy Prime Minister and the Prime Minister would suddenly be knocking on their doors with a big grant. The whiteboard would be out again.

There are not only grants and bribes for organised special interest groups; there are well-paid jobs. The Deputy Prime Minister has a conditioned response when it comes to reacting to the requirements of the social worker industry, the health policy industry and the nanny state industry. If people do not get top jobs with the chattering classes, the Deputy Prime Minister will give them a lucrative consultancy. One person close to the Deputy Prime Minister has made more than $1 million in consultancies to this government.

If the Deputy Prime Minister's books are full, do not worry. Switch across to the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley). If people are single, belong to a minority preference group, despise the traditional family, call blue-collar workers rednecks, hate Christian hymns and carols, they can get a job with the kindergarten police.

Former ALP Senator Walsh has done a great job of exposing the kindergarten gestapo, but even he missed one thing: the kindergarten police can turn up and enter a kindergarten or creche at any time they choose. They do not need permission to break in. They do not have to make a phone call. They do not have to go to court. They do not have to get a warrant. They can break in, trample through the place terrorising the teachers and the children, seize the books and take off. The minister has surrounded herself with the little KGB which intends that people play the politically correct message or else.

But the interest group dearest and closest to the Prime Minister's heart is the trade union movement and its special interest hierarchy. The greatest capitulation of all was the Keating-Brereton retreat on the industrial relations reform package. Instead of freeing up the labour market, increasing our international competitiveness and creating jobs, they have increased the veto power of the trade union bosses.

In Australia's current economic situation, nothing can be more important than having a more responsive labour market. We simply cannot deregulate the financial markets and deregulate the product markets without also deregulating the labour markets. If we want Australia to maintain its economic growth, to improve its competitiveness, to increase its exports and—as the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) just said—to allow more import replacement, it is vitally important that we do something about making the labour market more responsive to market conditions. What the recent industrial relations package does is not to make that market more responsive to competitive pressures but to give the trade union hierarchy increased veto powers.

In individual cases some trade unions can perform a useful assistance and advice function. But collectively they now act as an albatross to the interests of workers and their families. They extort money from many workers by compulsion. They spend large sums of those funds on a political party that most of their workers do not vote for. They support politically correct causes which are hostile to the harmony of Australian families. They stand in the way of agreements which suit the needs and individual desires of both employers and employees. They are a heavy tax on our export industries. They are now encouraging taxes on jobs. The trade union movement is proposing a jobs levy. It will be yet another tax on jobs which will make it more difficult for Australia to export and, relatively speaking, it will cost jobs in the long run.

There is almost no function of modern trade unions which could not be better performed by government safety net arrangements, voluntary agencies, workplace agreements and codes of conduct. The ACTU is a Jurassic relic, but it still stomps the earth assisted by a jungle of legal and de facto compulsions—and when the ACTU bites the Prime Minister jumps.

The Keating government no longer represents traditional Australian families. Indeed, it penalises mothers who stay at home to care for their children. It no longer represents unskilled, semi-skilled or white dust jacket workers. The government cannot take them to view second empire clocks. It no longer represents Christians, voluntary welfare agencies, independent trades and professions, recreational bushwalkers, weekend tennis players, small shopkeepers, traditional families or those incapable or uninterested in forming a pressure group. The Keating-Howe Labor Party is the party of the new class, the chattering class, the handout class and the urban white-collar class which thinks amateurs can conduct Mahler, the Bible is to be read as literature and that toddlers singing Christmas carols might lose it ethnic votes in the marginal seats.

The tragedy of the Prime Minister is his desperation to join this new class. What else would explain his pathetic attempt to put on a show of learning to make maximum publicity out of the fact that, along with millions of others, he actually listens to serious music? Chifley read books, but he did not have to boast about it in the media. Calwell was proficient in a number of languages, but he did not put that fact up in neon lights.

I raise these matters not because it gives me pleasure to be mildly critical—there are some things about the Prime Minister I quite like—but because he has caught the wrong tram, and he has caught the wrong tram for the country. He craves popularity, but thinks he has to court the tertiary graduates of the sociology and political marketing schools to get it. In the meantime, while Australians endure the ambitions of the new yuppies, the process of reform, initiated by former Senator Walsh and others, comes to a halt like a Mahler coda.

What has happened to dealing with chronic unemployment? Too hard. What has happened to industrial relations reform? Stopped. What has happened to waterfront reform, as we have seen in recent days? Halted. What has happened to taxation reform? Dead. What has happened to welfare targeting? The government has lost interest. What has happened to health and hospital reform? Gone, as Dr Blewett has gone. What has happened to privatisation? Slowed to a crawl. What has happened to law reform? That is going to be impossible after the sports rorts affair. What has happened to administrative services reform? It stopped at a cost to the budget of $240 million a year. What has happened with cooperative federalism reforms? That went with Bob Hawke. Despite the Prime Minister's platitudes yesterday, we will find that cooperative federalism, which is very important in our nation—which came together as a federation and is the compact of our federation—has also stopped.

The clear message from those answers is: the Prime Minister and his mates started with the reform agenda but got waylaid by the yuppies, the media agenda settlers and the special interest groups on the way. Social and economic reform has stopped, but the big handout bash is on. If you cannot get re-elected by respect; get re-elected by lies and bribes. This is a sad story for a caravan which began its journey with such hopes. The Prime Minister must face the dreadful fact for his ambitions: his relentless pursuit of power and his popularity amongst favoured interest groups has isolated him from his native Sydney. He is now out of place without the power of the public purse, so he intends to buy his way into what he calls culture. We will shortly get a cultural statement from the Prime Minister and one of his speech writers. The title is already abroad—in honour of the dead poets society it will be called the bought writers society.

It is clear this government has been told by its minders that there are two priorities between now and the next election: increase the grants of Australian family taxes to the special interest groups, and give the ACTU the lot. But there is some emerging panic in government ranks because the Prime Minister no longer has an economic policy with Walsh and Dawkins gone. He is permanently unpopular with the electorate. The great majority of the work force does not want the ACTU and its Halfpennys and Keltys, as evidenced by declining interest in trade union membership. The Prime Minister's act of pretending to be a Bankstown Mitterand is a joke to most of Labor's remaining believers.

We had hoped that these appropriation bills would give some indication of the government's directions, but the Prime Minister's minders and the ACTU interactive communicators are already in election mode. Since they have no broad social and community goals they will have to sustain a difficult campaign of appeal to minorities against the interests of the great majority of Australian families.

The coalition parties, robbed once, will fight for the constitution and the flag; the values of traditional Australian families; the right of schools and kinders to say prayers and sing carols; less interference from Canberra; no discrimination against women who raise their own children; honest elections without bribes and lies; a massive program of government and voluntary care for the homeless, the mentally ill, and the victims of violence; and the kind of economic expansion which brings not just job opportunities and new jobs but lasting careers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a couple of matters that the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Beale) referred to in his speech to which I want to respond but, in the first instance, I make the point that Appropriation Bills Nos 2 and 3 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) do provide, as has been observed by a number of honourable members, an opportunity for honourable members to range across economic, social and political issues about which they are concerned. It is one of those few occasions I suppose when legislation lends itself to that type of approach.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, I congratulate the new honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) on his maiden speech yesterday. The honourable member follows in the great tradition of his predecessors in Werriwa. The former Labor leader and Prime Minister Gough Whitlam, a great Australian and a man of great and exceptional vision, represented Werriwa. He was followed then by John Kerin, one of the most successful and highly regarded ministers for primary industry from any party this parliament has had since Federation. The honourable member's contribution yesterday makes it clear that he is an appropriate inheritor and custodian of those traditions in Werriwa.

There is a marked contrast between the younger people that the Labor Party brings into this parliament and the people that the opposition brings into this parliament. Of course, this is one of the reasons now why people are increasingly recognising the fact that the opposition is largely devoid of talent, largely devoid of depth on its backbench and has a deficient but overflowing front bench with all of the problems associated with that.

The honourable member for Werriwa is a graduate in economics. He has done a lot of research work. He has been involved in local government. He was a young mayor of Liverpool. He has a very strong background and experience and has been able to develop all of the necessary talents for him to make a contribution not only to his electorate and those people that he directly represents but also to this parliament and to this nation. He will do that. I would not agree with all of the things that the honourable member said yesterday nor the emphasis that he placed on them, but it was an intelligent assessment, an intelligent statement.

Our members and our new members come in here with some spirit in their soul, with some fire in their bellies and with some brains in their heads. That is why this government undoubtedly will be in office for a long time despite those absurd amateur theatricals that we saw this morning from the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) and the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson). They were nothing more than amateur theatricals. At least one of those honourable members is positioning himself for the leadership tussle which is under way now, and which everyone knows must be resolved if the opposition is at least to settle back into its usual sloth and complacency. Opposition members were attempting this morning to lift their profiles. They are making their bids for the future and they are doing it on very tenuous and very shaky grounds. We were not fooled by that burlesque. We were not fooled at all.

I said before in connection with the sports grants affair that there was no necessary form of administration for ministers to adopt. There is a responsibility for ministers to carry out the tasks with which they have been charged and to act in accordance with the legislation under which they operate. The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) clearly did that. She exercised the discretion which is rightly given to ministers. She administered a $30 million program. A great deal of continuing criticism has been made about the way in which the minister chose to make those decisions. She had a responsibility to make those decisions—and she made them.
The assertions that have been made are pretty shallow. I am one of those people who, like most members of the government, like to keep an eye on what the opposition is up to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The table is headed `Coalition's Rebuild Australia Fund: Promises and Implied Commitments'. Reference has been made in the House to that promise made on the run by the Leader of the Opposition about providing a university at Cairns for a total cost of $30 million—the total amount of the sports and recreation program. Honourable members should hear about some of these projects. By the way, in the table I have identified the project, indicated who made the promise, indicated when the promise was made, given the source—so if people want to question these they can go back to the source, the newspapers—and indicated the cost.

PARA.TAB: The first project is the very fast train—$1,500 million. That is half of the rebuild Australia fund in one hit. That promise was made by the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp) and the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran). The second project is a four-lane highway from Sydney to Orange. Honourable members will recall that I was Minister for Land Transport at that time. That project was costed between $600 million and $1,000 million. There is not much left in the rebuild Australia fund, but the list goes on.

The next project is the Alice Springs to Darwin rail link. The Leader of the Opposition made a promise to put $1,500 million into that project on 10 February last year, just before the election, but that was superseded by a commitment made on 6 March by the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) who had a more sensible estimate of $300 million—and it was endorsed by the Leader of the Opposition.

Other projects are a special infrastructure package for South Australia, $300 million; Goulburn-Canberra to complete the four-lane highway, $160 million to $260 million; and Cairns-Port Douglas light rail, $70 million. The cost of the Pichi Richi rail is unstated, so we can add whatever that unstated amount is to the total that I will indicate shortly. The total will stun you, Mr Deputy Speaker Andrew, because you are a man of perception. The honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), who has a genuine interest in rail, promised National Rail expenditure over three years of $774 million.

The next project on the table is Badgerys Creek unspecified transport infrastructure—$50 million. Honourable members will recall infrastructure associated with the sugar package—$23 million. The next project is the Cairns university, which we have been hearing a lot about. When the Leader of the Opposition was asked how he estimated that $30 million, honourable members will recall that he wrote on the back of an envelope, `10 by three'—$30 million. The next project is to compensate New South Wales for uniform heavy vehicle registration charges—$14 million to $75 million. Another project is a capital projects `kick start' grant to Tasmania. We know what the opposition was seeking to do at that time in Tasmania—hold the seats. We grabbed another two back. So Tasmanians were not fooled by this nonsense. That project was going to cost $80 million. The next project is the Alice Springs to Darwin rail link that came back in March last year—$300 million.

The honourable member for Farrer, the rail enthusiast, promised an annual boost to rail of $258 million. Just before the election, the opposition looked at the map of those electorates and said, `What type of commitment can we make now to clean up all of those electorates between Nambour in Queensland and Melbourne?'. It said, `Let's make a commitment to a four-lane highway', which it did—$3,500 million. The rebuild Australia fund was going to provide only $3,000 million and here the final project was going to cost $3,500 million. The total cost of the projects, which were to be financed out of a $3,000 million fund, is $7.6 billion—more than twice the amount that was to be provided in that fund.

In the context of claims made by those opposite that this government has been using funds of hardworking Australians to bribe interest groups and that the opposition in government would have honest elections without bribes, this table will go into the Hansard now as a permanent record, and my colleagues can refer to it from time to time. There was only one reason that that rebuild Australia fund was mentioned: it was to be a vehicle for the opposition in election mode to go around this nation dispensing promises like confetti—as it did. Those opposite all know that when the interest groups came to them in the campaign and suggested some particular project that they were interested in the response was, `That would lend itself well to our rebuild Australia fund'.

This is a list of those promises taken generally from state and national media. All those other promises that were made on the run are not on this list. If they were included as well I would hesitate to guess what the total cost would come to, but it gives the lie to some of those claims that have been made. It shows their superficiality. It shows that it is just a veneer of political rhetoric. There is no substance.

Every one of those projects that the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories approved is a project on the ground. They are visible to everyone. Let the Australian community not be fooled by the political rhetoric undertaken by the opposition. It is a sham. It is a fraud. It is not genuine. It lacks substance. It lacks integrity. There is no basis for those claims, and we simply reject them.

I want to make mention of something else which happened in the context of that last election campaign. We recall that things were really not going well for the opposition, as was shown by the election result. Things were not going very well for the opposition at all. So of course it was necessary for the opposition to blame someone. But it did not blame just one group or one person. He is the bloke who said that he wanted to come here and complete the duo of Abbott and Costello, the bloke who said he wanted to come in here in order to make sure that his electorate had an `Abbott' to match the Bishop next door. Of welfare organisations the Leader of the Opposition said:

So we can go on. I do not need any more time; my time is just about finished in this debate, not in this parliament. The fight we take to the opposition is a fight that we will continue. The Australian people, despite being referred to as mug punters by the honourable member for Higgins in this debate yesterday, elected us in 1983, 1984, 1987, 1990 and 1993 and they will do the same again next time because we deserve to be re-elected and the opposition deserves to stay in opposition.
