TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to these appropriation bills now before the House I intend to deal with several current and compelling issues of national security. These bills cover a number of key organisations vitally concerned with national security, principally the Department of Defence but also the Office of National Assessments, ONA, the Australian Secret Intelligence Service, ASIS, and the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, ASIO.

PARA.TAB: In the minds of some people, the collapse of European communism has substantially reduced or even eliminated national security concerns and consequently the need for a significant appropriation to defence and an adequate security and intelligence apparatus. Such an approach is naive and potentially dangerous, for an increasingly diverse and complex range of security problems remain even in respect of Russia itself.

We are all aware of the dramatic seizure of power in September 1993 by the Russian President, Boris Yeltsin, and his accompanying dismissal of the Russian parliament, the Congress of Peoples Deputies, which capped two years of endemic instability in Russia. Since Mr Yeltsin emerged as the most powerful political figure in the former Soviet Union over 2 1/2 years ago, we have witnessed an economic collapse of appalling dimensions as a decaying planned economy clashed head-on with the shock therapy, free-market approach of the IMF.

As no commonsense transitional arrangements between two diametrically opposed economic systems were ever effected, the result has been internal chaos, rising poverty and widespread corruption. As one measure of the corruption involved, it is estimated that the nomenklatura, the Russian bureaucratic military and business class, have set aside $US100 billion since the mid-1980s, most of it going into western bank accounts.

The excesses of the shock therapy approach have now been belatedly recognised with its principle architect, the first deputy prime minister, Yegor Gaidar, resigning on 16 January last. Other resignations have since followed, including that of the finance minister, Mr Boris Fyodorov. However, the damage has been irreparably done. Though communism as we traditionally knew it in Russia is now fortuitously buried in history, the revulsion of the Russian people against the state of penury to which their country has been reduced is undoubtedly giving birth to a new form of Russian nationalism.

Alexander Solzhenitsyn, the Russian intellectual who was long on the outer with the old communist regime, has given an excellent insight into two of the principle strands of thought that underpin the new nationalism. The first is a great thirst for order of which he has said:

SPEECH.PARA: The people have a right to power, but the people do not want power. Only 2% have the desire for power; before all else, they want order.

The borders determining what is Russian soil are for Solzhenitsyn the second element defining Russian nationalism. To him `our thousand-year history' means that contemporary Russia must have the borders of the ancient `Rus' or `Rossya', including the Russian Federation, Belarus, or white Russia, the Ukraine and also the Russian populated north-central Kazakhstan.

PARA.TAB: In this context it is worth noting that, under pressure from Moscow, Belarus is actually moving closer to ending its nominal independence and for all practical purposes is being reabsorbed into Russia. Moreover, its government is overwhelmingly in the hands of the former Soviet nomenklatura. Likewise, the Ukraine is moving back towards Russia, having signed on 17 July 1993 in Moscow the initial agreement for a Slavic economic union binding Russia, Belarus and the Ukraine. As well, the Ukraine was forced at the beginning of this year by combined Russian and American pressure to hand over administrative control of its nuclear arsenal.

Russia, it should be noted, is also heavily backing the ethnic Russian majority in the Crimea region of the Ukraine who wish to join Russia. In addition, the Russian military is believed to be covertly active in a number of the republics of the former Soviet Union, most notably during last year in the Abkhazia region of Georgia where it was allegedly backing local separatists against the government of Georgian President, Mr Eduard Shevardnadze. As a result, Georgia was forced into seeking support and assistance from Russia to deal with a siege situation which Russia, from all accounts, played no small part in creating and sustaining. Georgia is today still heavily dependent on the Russian military and navy to resolve local difficulties, as witnessed the defence treaty with Russia which Mr Shevardnadze had no option but to sign earlier this month. Moreover, on 18 January, only a few weeks ago, the Russian foreign minister, Mr Andrei Kozyrez, made it plain that Russia intended to maintain a continuing presence in the Baltic states.

This new and aggressive Russian nationalism, notwithstanding the fact that it is at this stage essentially confined to crudely exerting influence over certain republics of the former Soviet Union, is a matter still requiring an exercise of due diligence by the security and intelligence services of the Western democracies. Anyone with residual doubts as to such necessity should have them resolved by the rising prominence of the Russian ultranationalist leader, Mr Vladimir Zhirinovsky, whose Liberal Democrats' strong showing in the pre-Christmas parliamentary elections shocked people both inside and outside Russia.

We in the Western democracies should, in addition, be under no illusion that the Russian security services are alive and well, even if they have undergone massive reorganisation since the attempted coup in August 1991. A document produced by the Directorate of Intelligence of the United States Central Intelligence Agency, the CIA, entitled The Russian security services: sorting out the pieces and dated September 1992, clearly illustrates by text and diagram how then USSR President Mikhail Gorbachev dismantled the KGB and created different agencies from its various departments and directorates, how these organisations changed as the Soviet Union collapsed, and how they have stabilised at present under Russian jurisdiction.

The first of the four principal Russian security organisations identified by the CIA was the ministry of security of the Russian federation, the MBRF, which was established in January 1992. The MBRF oversaw internal security, counter-narcotics, counterintelligence, counter-terrorism and economic security. Since early June 1992, it did also have responsibility for the Russian border troops. During its first 18 months, the MBRF was headed by Colonel-General Viktor Barannikov, who was dismissed by Mr Yeltsin in July 1993. Failure by the MBRF to assess the growing strength of the ultranationalist Mr Zhirinovsky, caused President Yeltsin to disband the organisation a few days before last Christmas. A new federal counterintelligence service has been created in its stead, headed by Mr Nikolai Golushko, former chief of the old Soviet KGB in the Ukraine.

Foreign intelligence is now collected by the Russian foreign intelligence service, the SVRR. At the time of the compilation of the CIA document, the director was Yevgeniy Primakov who, it is understood, still runs the SVRR today. Primakov's earlier service was largely with the first chief directorate of the KGB, the body once responsible for foreign intelligence gathering. He has publicly claimed that the SVRR will reduce intelligence collection in the west. This claim is debatable. On the most generous interpretation there has simply been a greater emphasis on industrial and economic espionage, previously by the first chief directorate of the KGB and more latterly by the SVRR.

The third main organisation detailed by the CIA is the ministry of internal affairs, the MVD, which is the successor to the Russian MVD and the USSR MVD. Its functions are the same as those of its predecessor organisations and, in some areas, the now defunct MBRF, that is, maintaining prison facilities and fighting narcotics, organised crime and terrorism. Lieutenant-General Viktor Yerin was head of the MVD in September 1992.

FAPSI, the federal agency for government communications and information, is the fourth main security organisation. This agency combines the cryptography, communications interception and communication departments of the former USSR KGB. It is also responsible for maintaining secure communication lines for the President and the security services. The general director of FAPSI in September 1992 was Lieutenant-General Aleksandr Starovoytov.

Over the decades following the Second World War and now, Russian diplomatic personnel have played a major role in foreign intelligence gathering, most especially in the Western democracies. So overt was that activity between 1970 and 1987, 691 Soviet intelligence officers were expelled from various countries around the world. Even neighbouring New Zealand, limited in size and population as it is, found it necessary to throw out six Soviet diplomats during that same period. In marked contrast, Australia has taken little action against Soviet diplomats known to be hostile intelligence officers, except for the Petrov affair in 1955 and the Coombe-Ivanov affair in 1983.

The admission of Valeriy Zemskov to Australia in early 1986, which I dealt with in some detail in the grievance debate of 20 October 1988, is a classic illustration of Australia's inaction. In the months preceding his arrival, Mr Zemskov was identified as a member of the elite KGB special reserve yet, against security advice, was allowed by the federal Labor government to take up his post as minister-counsellor at the Soviet embassy in Canberra and serve out his term. During his time here, Mr Zemskov was left free to pursue the then Soviet objectives of undermining the ANZUS military alliance with the United States and push for the entry of Soviet trawlers to Australian waters.

Notwithstanding the collapse of European communism and the disintegration of the former Soviet Union, the new Russian federation has still maintained a substantial intelligence presence in Australia and, in fact, increased it over recent years. Right up to last year there were believed to be up to 10 to 12 Russian intelligence officers in this country, with up to six of them on the diplomatic list. Most were members of the new Russian foreign intelligence service, the SVRR, and some were members of Russian military intelligence, the GRU. The SVRR is, of course, the Russian successor to the KGB, as discussed earlier, while the GRU has remained organisationally intact, despite the dramatic political changes in Russia. Until the middle of 1993, the head of residence for Russian foreign intelligence in Canberra was Mr Vladimir Grouzdev, shown as a counsellor on the diplomatic list of 12 July 1993. One of his key lieutenants was Mr Mikhail Tchoupakhine, who was on the same list as a third secretary, consular.

Continuing security vigilance by Australia is therefore crucial, especially when it is pointed out that several Russian foreign intelligence and military intelligence officers have had to leave Australia from both the Russian embassy in Canberra and the Russian consulate in Sydney. The departures have involved at least three Russian foreign intelligence officers and at least two GRU officers. Moscow has been informed by the Australian Department of Foreign Affairs that these exits of Russian intelligence officers were to take place over an extended period, that these officers are not welcome in Australia ever again, and that reprisals by Russia are unwarranted. This is no great hardship because no Australian intelligence officers operate under diplomatic cover in the Russian federation. In fact, despite all that is now happening in Russia, nothing is apparently done by Australia covertly that might upset the Russians.

Those Russian intelligence officers being asked to leave Australia have been engaged in espionage against the Commonwealth of Australia, most particularly counterespionage against the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, ASIO. All this fervent activity is in the wake of vital information received about the extraordinary extent of Russian intelligence activities in Australia from other Western intelligence services.

—No doubt this general concern motivated the government's appointment of Mr Michael Cook, former Director-General of the Office of National Assessments and, more latterly, Australian Ambassador to the United States, to head its present inquiry into national security. PARA.TAB: However, this situation is all too familiar under a decade of Labor. We have yet another internal bureaucratic inquiry in which ministers and senior bureaucrats scramble to protect each other's backsides from the wrath of potential public indignation as to their failure of public duty. Only a more open judicial inquiry into Australia's internal security will resolve a lot of the outstanding questions in relation to this matter. —The debate on the appropriation bills can cover a very wide range of subjects, although I was surprised at the nature of the discussion by the previous speaker because it was only very tangentially related to the bills that we are debating. PARA.TAB: In his Australia Day speech the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) rightly said that unemployment is the principal problem facing Australia at present, and I do not think that anybody in the community would disagree with that. Fortunately, the government has commissioned and has now received a report on what can be done about unemployment: the green paper on restoring full employment, which was tabled in this House at the end of last year. That report is very significant because it begins by saying that today the nation's No. 1 priority is to find jobs for unemployed Australians. It goes on a little later to say that full employment is the ultimate goal. The green paper is absolutely right in asserting those goals.

It makes some recommendations about policies for increasing employment opportunities for the long-term unemployed and for changing the way in which income support is provided. It also contains a number of other subsidiary policies. The green paper rightly says that the principal requirement for the reduction of unemployment is sustained strong economic growth. We must continue to aim for that. But it also says, quite rightly, that that alone will not be enough.

The points that I want to make in this speech relate to additional policies which might contribute to increasing employment opportunities as well as strong economic growth. I think a number of points have been missing from the public debate about these issues, and I will mention them. The principal point is that most of the employment growth has to occur in service industries. About two-thirds of the Australian employed work force are now working in the service sector. Lots of people imagine our manufacturing sector, or our primary sector, or our construction sector to be larger than one-third of the work force. In fact, two-thirds of the work force are employed in services, mostly in human services. There are some very good examples of that in both the private and the public sectors.

A service area of particularly strong growth in the private sector is tourism, which is now one of the fastest growing industries in Australia. In fact, estimates published early in the 1990s were that during the decade of the 1990s about an additional 200,000 people would be employed in tourism, mainly in small businesses—in many parts of Australia—contributing to tourist opportunities for both Australians and overseas visitors.

Another very important private sector industry in the services area which is growing strongly is information technology—computer software. That growth is very important to Australia's development as a competitive international economy and should be welcomed very strongly. A large part of the growth in employment will have to occur in the public sector as well. Before I discuss that, I note that there are a number of things that the government can do to enhance employment growth prospects in the private sector, of which perhaps the most important is ensuring that interest rates are as low as possible so that funds can be borrowed for expansion at as low a cost as possible.

Also of vital importance is the availability of funds. A major problem that many small businesses have had in recent years is getting access to funds when they do not have physical assets to mortgage against additional borrowings. That is a very common problem in the computer software area. What those companies have to offer is the technical expertise of their staff. It is vital for Australian development that banks and other lending institutions take account of the expertise and the order books of small and medium businesses when considering whether to increase overdrafts or make other lending arrangements. So those are two areas where the government has been active in trying to create a facilitating environment for private sector growth and development.

It is also true that a large part of the employment growth will have to occur in community services; in human services; in large employing areas such as education and health; in police services; in care for the aged, the young and the disabled; in library services; in the arts; and in the environment—those areas which do most to improve the quality of life. We have tended to forget that one of the observed tendencies of economies as they develop is that, as incomes rise, people want to spend an increasing proportion of their incomes on human services.

When people feel more economically secure, they are able to spend more time on education and to afford better education for their children. As incomes rise, and as the population ages, the proportion of income which people want to spend on health tends to increase. As incomes rise and people's opportunity for leisure grows, the proportion of their income that they want to spend on cultural activities, leisure activities, sport and recreation, and preserving and enhancing the environment tends to increase as well. Therefore, governments must recognise that there is community support and demand for increased opportunities in those areas.

In many areas of Australian society, there is a much higher demand for the kinds of services I have just mentioned than is currently being met. A particularly good example is the applications for technical and further education. At the beginning of last year, about 150,000 more applications were received for places in TAFE colleges—institutes of technology—than were able to be provided. That means that 150,000 people—mostly young, but some older—were not able to be given the access to opportunities for post-secondary education which would have increased their skills generally in ways of great value not only to them but also to the whole economy. So their life chances were restricted. That is a tragedy. There has been very little publicity or public discussion about it, although there has been quite a lot of public discussion about the greater demand for university places than is available.

It would be a good thing if university places could be expanded even further. Of course, the number has grown strongly in the last 10 years. The number of students at universities has gone up from something like 350,000 about 10 years ago to 550,000 now, which is very strong growth indeed. The same growth has not occurred in the technical and further education area. With an increase in the proportion of students finishing secondary school—close to 75 per cent of all students who enter primary school complete year 12—there has been an explosion in the number of people wanting to go on to further education, either of a post-secondary technical kind or of a tertiary kind, yet those opportunities have not been increased sufficiently to meet that demand.

If those places were being provided, not only would 150,000 fewer people be unemployed, because they would be in training; there would be many more opportunities, perhaps in the region of 10,000, for teachers, lab staff, administrative staff, and construction workers building new buildings. There would be a whole panoply of people providing those sorts of educational opportunities. I particularly mention that because it seems to me to be an enormously high priority. The same kinds of points can be made about other parts of the education system.

At present in various states we have the tragedy of cutbacks in the number of people employed in primary and secondary education. What the Victorian government is doing is extraordinarily destructive to the quality of the public education services available in that state. This comes at a time when we should be trying to build up opportunities for teachers and support staff and to improve the quality of our education system so that we can have an outstanding and excellent education system rather than a minimal one. So, perversely, the Victorian government is going in exactly the reverse direction to that which this country should be going in.

Not dissimilar points can be made about health services. The government has quite rightly aimed to improve the efficiency with which health services are delivered. There are very difficult questions about how to do that. How much do we spend on extraordinarily costly high technology health equipment, for example? What level of staffing do we provide in hospitals and health centres for the general public? They are very difficult technical, professional and ethical issues, but I think we have neglected the point that as incomes rise and as the population ages, the proportion of income which people want to spend on health tends to go up. We have tended to say that, while we are spending about eight per cent of our national income on health services, that should set a limit. But we could argue quite responsibly that it would be very natural and proper if that proportion rose slowly and gradually over time, particularly because of the ageing of the population and also because people want an excellent, high quality health service. That requires the provision of additional resources.

The same kinds of points can be made about quite different areas of our life. They can be made about services for families. One of the real tragedies of our society at present is that we are spending so little on conflict resolution within families. We are spending about $20 million on marriage counselling at present. A committee of this House has recently recommended that that be quite sharply increased—a recommendation that I strongly support. It seems to me that the enormity of the cost of family breakdown in Australia is not being matched by the kinds of services that should be provided freely to families that are in conflict. We all know that such conflict is very common and natural. So that is another very high priority area. That would also contribute to reducing the terrible incidence of domestic violence and violence against children.

A quite different area, just to mention another, is the arts. We are a society that is putting quite high value on cultural development. We cannot do that if the arts are underfunded. Our principal cultural organisation, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, has had its funding reduced by about a third as a proportion of national income over the last seven or eight years. That is a very dramatic reduction in its funding. There is a large proportion of the population who listen to or watch the ABC and who would like to see that trend reversed.

The same could also be argued for the environment. The environment committee which I chair made a recommendation about a year ago for an extension in the system of protected areas to ensure that all major Australian ecosystems were adequately represented in protected areas and therefore that their future was protected. That requires additional funding. The management of those areas will generate additional employment. That overlaps again with the point I mentioned right at the beginning of my speech about the growth of tourism. One of the strongest growing areas of tourism is ecotourism, people wanting to visit and study the natural environment. There is a lot that could be done to improve opportunities for that.

It is all those kinds of reasons that are the justification for some kind of jobs levy. We are now the lowest taxed country in the Western world. If we want to increase employment, we will have to allocate some additional resources to that. It seems to me quite natural in this crisis situation we are in—the worst crisis since the Second World War—to expect those who are at the upper end of the income scale and who are in secure jobs to make some small additional contribution to providing the resources which would ensure an increase in the number of jobs in high priority areas where improvements in services are desperately needed. That is the purpose which a jobs levy should be put to.

There are many proposals for that. I do not want to go into details. It seems to me to be reasonable and sound to begin a jobs levy at about average weekly earnings, which immediately excludes 57 per cent of all income earners, at one per cent and perhaps move it up to a couple of per cent on higher incomes. A levy of that kind would generate somewhere between $2 billion and $3 billion and those $2 billion or $3 billion could be used for the kinds of permanent improvements in human services for which the community is asking. Provided they were used in those ways, then community support for the levy would, I think, be quite considerable.

No-one, of course, likes paying any increased tax, but a temporary modest levy of that kind makes entirely good sense at a time when we are wasting enormous resources through high unemployment. If we could reduce that unemployment in the ways I suggested—by increasing employment in desperately needed areas—then that would be of benefit to every person in Australian society. Not only would the quality and accessibility of services be increased, but the compassion, humanity and decency of our society would be improved. I hope and expect that the government will give very serious consideration to this proposal in that kind of context because I am quite sure that there are many people in the community who would like Australia, through this method, to have much lower unemployment and much improved community services.

TALK.START.PARA: —As always, the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) says it as he believes it is. He says it from the heart. That is not to say that I agree with what he has to say; I very rarely do in terms of his philosophy and ideology. Nevertheless, a point that he made at the start of his speech is very valid. I think in this particular debate a number of people, perhaps on both sides of the House, have exercised undue licence in the subjects that they have canvassed in the context of these appropriation bills. So I agree with the honourable member for Fraser that we need to concentrate a little more on the specifics of the three bills before us and that is what I intend to do in the time allocated to me. Nevertheless, if I get time I will to come back to some of the points that the honourable member for Fraser made and counter some of his arguments.

PARA.TAB: I refer the House to some specific entries in Appropriation Bill (No. 3) which call for gross additional estimates of about $175 million in the Defence portfolio and specifically $71.7 million for defence housing, reflecting advanced rental payments to the Defence Housing Authority and an additional capital subvention for the Defence Housing Authority. I would like to take just a few minutes of the House's time this morning to say a bit about the Defence Housing Authority. I notice my colleague the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) is in the House. I think what I have to say is something about which he has a lot of knowledge, and I hope he will agree with my comments.

The Defence Housing Authority is one of the rare successes of government business enterprises. It is indeed a major success. The Defence Housing Authority was formed in 1988 under the Defence Housing Authority Act 1987 to take over the responsibility for providing housing for defence personnel from the Department of Defence. Much of the housing that DHA inherited from the department was in poor condition and the systems in place for managing this housing, acquiring new homes and maintaining old ones were patently inefficient and clearly inadequate.

The DHA's mission is to provide defence personnel and their families with good housing that is consistent with community standards and that will contribute positively to their quality of life. Thus, while being required to act commercially, the authority has a strong commitment to the welfare of the tenants of its homes. It operates as a landlord, leasing all its homes to the department at market rates. It is up to the department to set rents and to subsidise them, if necessary.

The DHA was established as a commercial enterprise for the purpose of assuming the management of the defence housing stock of 24,000 units located in all states and territories. The authority has a staff of a little over 360, most of whom are located at the housing management centres, which are established close to the areas of defence housing concentration.

In the mid-1980s, the outstanding features of the defence housing stock were its generally poor quality and, as I said previously, its management. The total stock of defence housing was transferred to the authority at its inception. In the 5 1/2 years of its existence, the authority has provided nearly 12,000 houses to community standards and has disposed of about 10,000 units of unsatisfactory stock. It has instituted a rolling repairs and maintenance program that involves regular consultation with its tenants.

The arrangements with the Department of Defence enable the authority to apply entrepreneurial approaches to the defence housing requirements while still meeting the needs of the customer. The charging of market based rents to the department has enabled a total transparency in the cost of the defence housing function and has provided the needed discipline for the setting of housing entitlements and deciding the level of subsidised rents charged to Defence Force tenants.

The DHA observes commercial accounting practices. Its financial statements provide a full disclosure of the success of its operations and its rate of return on the assets employed. Nevertheless, it has not let its commercial orientation cause it to lose its sense of purpose in providing service families with good housing which will contribute positively to their quality of life and morale, with which I am sure the right honourable member for New England would agree.

I refer specifically to the capital subvention included in Appropriation Bill (No. 3). Special financial arrangements apply to the authority during its first decade of operations. It is exempt from paying taxes or dividends. The government has guaranteed that it will have available $750 million at 1986 base prices in real terms for capital expenditure. In so far as profits and non-cash expenditure fail to provide the needed funds, the DHA receives interest bearing loan subventions from the Department of Defence. In addition, the authority is able to borrow on the private capital market with the approval of the Treasurer.

Major factors in DHA operations have been an extensive involvement in joint operations with the private sector and the renegotiation of a longstanding agreement with the states under which much of the defence housing stock has been leased to the Department of Defence. I draw the attention of the House to the very poor quality of some of that stock when it was passed over and passed back. A lot of Defence Force personnel were expected to live in it for a long time.

All the funds initially provided to the authority by the government were in the form of loan funds. When the ratios of interest cover and debt to equity fell seriously below prudential financial management levels, $165 million of the authority's debt to the Commonwealth was converted to equity. Departmental subventions to the authority for 1992-93 and 1993-94 comprise 70 per cent equity and 30 per cent debt. But after 1993-94, assistance to the DHA will be only in the form of loans. The resulting capital structure is considered by the DHA to be appropriate to its needs.

It may also borrow from the private sector with the Treasurer's approval. At June 1993, the authority had $331 million in borrowings from the Commonwealth and $209 million from the private sector. A trend towards the private sector is expected over the next few years.

Major factors in the DHA's operations to date have been an extensive use of the private sector, which must meet its exacting standards; renegotiation, as I said earlier, of longstanding agreements with the states under which much of the defence housing stock has been released to the Department of Defence from the states; joint ventures with private developers, which are providing an economic supply of serviced lots for the authority's needs; and profits from sales of other lots.

The DHA places much store in continuous consultation and feedback from Defence Force families to ensure that the organisation is responsive to their reasonable requirements. In each full year of its operation, the authority has exceeded the real rate of return of five per cent on assets agreed with the government. Despite targets on the return of those assets having been met, historically the net yield has been too low to attract institutional investors with a view to privatising a significant proportion of the authority's asset base.

There is little doubt that its successes in the Defence Force housing arena have been a major factor in the retention of service personnel and the maintenance of reasonable levels of morale in the Australian Defence Force. That morale is again being questioned and is under serious risk as a result of other things.

John Graham, Bill Kirkby-Jones and their team need to take a well-earned bow. I do not want to be too dramatic about it, but it seems to me that at long last they have brought defence housing into the 20th century. I am sure that the right honourable member for New England would agree with me on just about everything I have said. The opposition, therefore, has no objection to the additional estimates sought under the defence portfolio or any additional funding called for under Appropriation Bill (No. 3).

However, in recent days one little dark cloud has appeared on the horizon in defence expenditure on the new submarine project. The Auditor-General's report No. 22 has been tabled in this parliament. It is currently under review by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, of which I am a member. Therefore, it would be inappropriate for me to go into detail on some of our discussions about that report.

However, there was some mention a couple of weeks ago about question marks over the project, particularly the sudden departure of Dr Don Williams, the managing director of the Australian Submarine Corporation. We have been assured in various quarters that there was nothing untoward about that. Nevertheless, there were a few question marks about some aspects of that project.

I take the opportunity in this place today to ask the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) to once and for all clear up any possible apprehensions about that project. For a number of us who have been to Adelaide, no-one could be less than impressed with what is being done. However, there are a few question marks, and they have to be settled. The man with the responsibility for doing that happens to be the Minister for Defence. In the context of this debate, I say to Senator Ray that he should let the public know quite clearly and quickly whether that project has any question marks about it and whether he is satisfied with it from an accountability and operational point of view. He should do that as quickly as possible.

I now turn to Appropriation Bill (No 4). It covers a multitude of sins—if that is the right wording—some of which I will quickly run through. The first one is in relation to a capital grant of $50 million to New South Wales for infrastructure enhancements at Homebush Bay for the 2000 Olympics. I do not think any reasonable person would have any objection to that. I think it would have unanimous support of this House and of this parliament to make sure that that happens and happens quickly.

The second refers to a little over $25 million which is involved in the Midford Paramount case. This has been canvassed in this place before but I would just add a comment that it is indeed one of the largest scandals that we have seen for a long time. It has been acknowledged in this place at ministerial level; it is now is acknowledged financially in terms of compensation with the heavy hand of the customs service involving financial ruin and broken health for a number of the principals involved in that particular case.

The third point is in relation to a little over $20 million, which is additional funding under the rural adjustment scheme. The rural adjustment scheme is something that we should have. Unfortunately, a lot of constituents in my electorate have had to draw on that scheme, not to keep them on the farm but, regrettably, to take them off the farm. That is one of the disappointments of the scheme in that it seems to give too much emphasis on taking people off the land rather than giving them the wherewithal to stay on farm. Whilst we support that $20 million, we need to be assured that it will be $20 million well spent under a scheme which has a lot of question marks over it.

Another point is in relation to the little over $14 million for health initiatives, particularly for elective surgery waiting time reductions. I will give the House a little anecdotal example, which I hope the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) will take on board, of the problems that people have with elective surgery. A couple of weeks ago a gentleman came to my office and said that he had been looked at by a doctor in October 1991 for some sort of growth on the back of his knee.

By November 1993, two years later, he had got to the point where the doctor had decided that perhaps he had better have an operation. He was admitted on Monday 14 February to Toowoomba base hospital. He was prepped for the operation the following day and, of course, was not fed because of the operation. At 4 o'clock that afternoon he was informed, `Well, the operation is off. We have run out of time'. He said, `Well, what time tomorrow?'. The response from the registrar was, `We think we might be able to do it in two months'. That is indicative of what is happening in the elective surgery area with some of these waiting times.

Another local example was somebody who went in to have a pterygium removed from the eye at one of the surgicentres in the area. He was in in the morning, had it done and was out in the afternoon, whereas the waiting time at Toowoomba base hospital was 21 months. So do not let the government tell anybody that there is nothing wrong with the health system, because there is, and hopefully Senator Richardson will do something about it.

The fifth area in this bill relates to $7 million for bushfire assistance to New South Wales. Having visited, with a number of my colleagues, the bushfire scenes recently in New South Wales I believe that, again, no reasonable person should argue against reasonable payment to the New South Wales government for what was a very large catastrophe.

Finally, the bill allocates a little over $7 million to ATSIC for the preparation and presentation of native title claims. A number of my colleagues have canvassed that this morning. I do not want to go into any detail. I do not have time other than to say that the native title legislation goes far beyond the Mabo judgment. This government has still not answered how much is going to be in that compensation fund and who is going to administer it. To be cynical about it, I think that that legislation will put more children of lawyers and solicitors through private schools over the next decade than we can poke a stick at—but perhaps I am being cynical. Nevertheless, there is deep concern out there about the degree to which that native title legislation may be implemented.

Finally, I will cover a few of the points that the honourable member for Fraser made in his remarks. He talked about unemployment being a major factor. I think we would all agree with that. He made the point about the government having some confidence in strong economic growth and a low CPI number. I would make four points that the honourable member cannot get away from: firstly, over one in 10 of our work force are unemployed; secondly, in the last three years the number of long-term unemployed has gone through the roof. I think the figures used in the House in the last week were that about one-third of those who are unemployed are now long-term unemployed. The third point is that, whilst unemployment is a catastrophe and a scandal, we should be looking at underemployment where arguably 18 per cent to 19 per cent of the work force are underemployed; in other words, working less than 20 hours a week. That should say something about the inadequacies of our economy.

Finally, if we continue to go down the trading black hole, we will be going at the rate of over $1 billion per month. I do not see how the honourable member for Fraser could stand up and argue for a jobs levy. It is not the solution. It will simply cost more jobs—indeed, the bottom line of his argument is that unemployment is the major factor that has to be addressed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mrs Silvia

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today in the debate on these appropriation bills to draw to the attention of the House the absolute necessity for these bills to be passed. Some of the areas which have been discussed here today are testament to the ongoing positiveness in this country. Another area I would like to highlight today is the tourism potential. In that context I would bring to the attention of the House a situation in north-east Tasmania, which is part of the electorate that I represent. The particular situation there concerns a dam which is now known as the Mount Paris dam.

PARA.TAB: I will give the House a little bit of background. The dam was built in 1936 in order to supply water to the tin mine at Derby. Many people throughout Australia have heard of the tin mine at Derby in north-eastern Tasmania. This particular project has become a very dear to my heart project because my father was actually part of the construction team which built that dam in 1936. He was a carpenter. This was actually the subject of a speech that I gave when I was a member of the Jaycees in Tasmania. A couple of gentlemen who were part of that construction team were lost in an aircraft crash in the Glasshouse Mountains in Queensland. A heroic venture for one of those pilots was to save his mate under dire circumstances.

This particular dam originally had rather a nice name, the Morning Star Dam. It is about 250 metres in length and covers an area of 21 hectares. It is 16 metres high at its tallest point. Perhaps in today's context it is not a huge dam but it is a very important dam to that area. An article in the North Eastern Advertiser of Thursday 27 January highlights the current plight of this particular piece of history. The article states:

"A report from the Hydro Electric Commission has found that the Mt Paris Dam is structurally unsound and represents a considerable safety hazard, and for the Government not to act would be a failure to ensure its duty of care", Mr Gray, the State Minister responsible, said.
The HEC report said that even without water loads, pieces of concrete are being popped off the downstream face of the dam due to rust in the reinforcement and possibly through freeze/thaw action.
Mr Gray stated that the cost of demolition will be `. . . about $80,000, including $10,000 specifically allocated for the archaeological investigation and report.'
Since 1967 the outlet pipe of the Mt Paris Dam has been blocked on two occasions, and in 1984 to prevent further blockages, a hole was blasted in the dam wall.

`Expert advice to the Government indicates that for the dam to be fully rehabilitated it would cost more than $1.5 million, and would lead to a massive increase in the cost of water to irrigators downstream,' Mr Gray added.

SPEECH.PARA: The people of north-eastern Tasmania are outraged at the prospect of the Mount Paris dam being demolished. To remove such an imposing and historical structure would be short-sighted in the extreme. My office, in particular, has received many calls from citizens across north-east Tasmania who are irate at the prospect of losing such a landmark.

PARA.TAB: One prominent Scottsdale resident, Ms Jillian Archer, is in the process of organising a public meeting on this issue for residents of the area. I assure honourable members that it will be heavily attended, if the number of phone calls to my office are any indication. The residents of north-eastern Tasmania are bitterly disappointed because any destruction of the Mount Paris dam will represent a major policy reversal by the state Liberal government. The North Eastern Advertiser of Thursday, 27 January states:
During the 1992 State Election, the Liberals promised to recommission the Mt Paris Dam, claiming it would increase water storage available in the highly successful Winnaleah Irrigation Scheme.

Mr Patmore, Deputy Labor Leader, claimed that Braddon Liberal MHA Bill Bonde told the people of North-East that upgrading the dam would enhance the potential for installing a small hydro power generator.

`Many people in the North-East voted for the Liberals because of the promises they made. One of these was to protect the Mt Paris Dam from demolition. Election promises mean nothing to Mr Gray and his colleagues. You can't believe a word they say,' Mr Patmore said.
Local Legislative Councillor, Mr Colin Rattray who resides in the area, has also expressed his disappointment about the decision—

SPEECH.PARA: I have spoken to him about this—

PARA.TAB: In a letter written to Mr Gray, he said `It would appear that the efforts of the local community have been overlooked in this decision. The extra water that could have been available to the scheme over the long term would have justified the investment required by your government.'
Mr Rattray is hoping the Government will reverse the decision.
The Dorset Council considered the report from the Economics branch of the Department of Primary Industry and Fisheries in May last year. This report recommended that the dam not be rehabilitated.
The Council supported the retention of the dam, and Mr John Martin, the Manager Corporate Services, told The Advertiser that the Council's position remained unchanged.
It would appear that the Minister has taken the advice of the Rivers and Water Supply Commission since the ownership of the dam was transferred to it in 1985.

In a letter to the Winnaleah Irrigation Scheme Committee in 1991, Mr W M Jordan, the Chairman and Engineering Member to the Rivers and Water Supply Commission, wrote `The Commission and, more particularly myself as Engineering Member of the Commission, have an ongoing liability as long as the Mt Paris Dam remains in its present situation and condition. I therefore, must advise that after 31 May, 1991 I will take no further responsibility for the dam and will if no other person or authority has taken over responsibility for the dam, order its immediate demolition.

Sources within the mining industry have also been critical of the decision, and have claimed that the Mt Paris Dam is a significant part of the mining heritage in the area, and the decision to demolish the dam will also destroy the integrity of the site.

Mineral Resources Tasmania (formerly the Mines Department), has a policy of preserving mining sites, and it was dismayed when the Chintock Battery was removed from the Blue Tier to the Beaconsfield museum. It is unlikely that advice provided from the agency would have supported the demolition of the historically noteworthy structure.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the major problems associated with the course of action outlined are most eloquently expressed in the editorial of the North Eastern Advertiser of Thursday, 17 January 1994, which reads:

PARA.TAB: "How will the North-East benefit from the Government's decision to demolish the Mt Paris Dam?

Mr Gray, the Minister for Primary Industry and Fisheries, claims that the dam has become a safety hazard, and he has accepted advice that the cost of rehabilitating the dam far outweighs the benefits which the community might receive from the dam's reconstruction.
This decision is akin to using a sledge hammer to crack an egg.

The Liberal Party promised to look at recommissioning the Mt Paris dam prior to the last State election, but appears that advice from bureaucrats has overridden any consideration for the community of the North-East.

The Department of Primary Industry and Fisheries report commissioned by the Government claims that providing farmers on the Winnaleah Irrigation Scheme with additional water is an unacceptable burden on taxpayers who would ultimately pay the cost of rehabilitating the dam. But who paid the cost of building the Craigbourne Dam in the South-East which directly benefits only farmers in that district?
Quite apart from the missed opportunities in terms of improved agricultural practice by this decision, the tourism implications have been apparently totally ignored.

Another government agency (i.e. Tourism) has been active in suggesting how the township of Derby could be marketed as a tourist destination and issues such as the town's historic character and mining history were promoted as worthy of further consideration.
In fact, this issue may unite opposing factions in Derby who are presently struggling to agree on appropriate development for their township.
Surely the Mt Paris dam is a unique part of that area's heritage?
The recreational possibilities inherent in a rebuilt dam—fishing and associated aquatic pursuits—are other issues which have not been examined in any depth.
A mere $80,000 has been set aside (including $10,000 specifically allocated for the archaeological investigation and report) for the proposed demolition.
Thus far no information has been forthcoming about where the thousands of tonnes of concrete are to be dumped. Is the structure simply going to be destroyed and left as an eyesore?
Private mining companies are compelled to make good their mess. Government initiated works should meet the same obligations.

The decision is a short sighted one lacking in any direct or meaningful consultation with the community, particularly the township of Derby, or other government departments which have an obvious role to play in such a decision.

If the dam is demolished, it is no more and the North-Eastern Advertiser believes that more consideration should be given to such a decision which will automatically terminate all options mentioned above.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the tourism potential of this region is enormous, and it is via appropriation bills that we can instigate these sorts of things. North-eastern Tasmania has a long history of pioneering, mining and development. Many of the old mine sites in the area are at present being reopened, either to be reworked or to be used as tourist destinations. The Mount Paris dam is part of this development heritage. It is part of the ethos and mystique of the entire region. It does have structural problems; that is true. But to destroy it, simply throws the baby out with the bathwater.

PARA.TAB: I am also pleased to say that, due to the huge public outcry, the Tasmanian state Liberal government seems to have softened its approach to the total demolition of the dam:
The State Government is examining its options to make the historic Mt Paris Dam in North-East Tasmania safe.

The Energy Minister, Mr Gray, told Parliament that the Government would do everything possible to preserve the historic aspects of the dam. However, he said that all options involved `some demolition' of the dam.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Gray said that a report on the condition of the dam had confirmed that it was a danger to `people and property'.

He said that the options included lowering the level of the spillway, a bypass to divert riverflow, reopening the tunnel under the dam to double exit capacity, clearing the timber out of the dam, or a metal structure to prevent blockage.

So let us analyse exactly what has happened today. Firstly, this is a landmark of historic significance and tourism importance. Secondly, after repair it could become a working tourist attraction, increasing also the water storage available to the Winnaleah irrigation scheme. Thirdly, the state Liberals at the last election gave an undertaking to recommission the dam for exactly that reason. Fourthly, this was the reason that many people in the area voted Liberal at the last election. Fifthly, public opinion in the entire region is incredibly supportive of the retention of this landmark.

PARA.TAB: As I have already mentioned, it now seems that the state government has softened its approach to this issue and I am very pleased about that. But the issue should never have arisen. Surely if Tasmanians are serious about fostering the major growth industry of their state, namely tourism, the state government should never have contemplated the destruction of the Mount Paris dam. Public opinion will ensure that this does not happen.

Let us look at this situation in terms of the federal government's national tourism strategy and how the Mount Paris dam fits that strategy. The Minister for Tourism (Mr Lee) made a statement in the introduction to the National tourist strategy information progress report No. 1 which highlights this situation. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Tourism is one of the few industries in the world economy that has continued to prosper through a global down turn. The ongoing strength of the Australian tourism industry is of major importance to the future of the Australian economy.
Tourism growth means export dollars and jobs for Australians.
I have heard in this place today that jobs are of the upmost importance to both sides of this House. It continues:
It is important that we do not squander the opportunities the industry provides for economic growth.

That was a very appropriate statement. It is incredibly important that we do not squander tourism opportunities no matter where they lie. The destruction of the Mount Paris dam would be a squandered opportunity.

PARA.TAB: I repeat: public opinion in north-east Tasmania will not allow this to happen. I commend the people of north-east Tasmania for their strength of will in this matter. It is a very small community. I also commend the North Eastern Advertiser for the way in which it has reported this situation. It is through appropriation bills that we can ensure that these sorts of projects are funded, the future of this country is looked after and the future employees and job seekers of this country have somewhere to go.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having been in the federal parliament for some considerable time, I have spoken on the appropriation bills on a number of occasions. For a number of years I have studied government legislation and the effect it has on our society. It has always appeared to me that in relation to our basic unit of society, that is our family group, we have always been sadly wanting and, instead of being on the front foot and trying to keep that cornerstone of the nation together, we are always trying to catch up by way of welfare payments for mistakes that have been made.

PARA.TAB: In the International Year of the Family we have the opportunity to do something to try to remedy this situation. There seems to be some conflict today as to what constitutes a family. While some pressure groups will try to tell us something else, it is my belief, and the figures show, that most families in Australia today still consist of a mother, a father and children, and most Australians still aspire to that situation. That is not to say that other structures do not exist but, however they exist, it is to be hoped that their main role is one of nurturing the children born into that structure.

It is therefore important that we do all in our power to keep our family structures healthy and together because of the trauma caused to the people involved in separation, and particularly to the children. From an economic point of view, in 1985 these breakdowns cost the Australian nation $1.9 billion per annum. In less than 10 years the cost has trebled and we now spend the equivalent of three new parliament houses every year on divorce and its consequences. The real tragedy is that we spend about 1c for each Australian per year in counselling and trying to keep families together whereas we spend $175 per Australian per year aiding the breakdown and, if you like, the splitting of the loot and the children.

We all know there are many reasons why families break down and I do not think it is up to anyone to point the finger in this regard because many of us, if we have not been separated ourselves, have witnessed the breakdown of the families of relatives, loved ones and friends. While there are many causes for these breakdowns, from my own experience as a father and breadwinner in always a single-income family and from my observations as a parliamentarian, one of the greatest pressures on families has to be finance—or the lack of it. From the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures for June 1992 we find that there are approximately 4 1/2 million families in Australia. Of these 412,000 are one-parent families. Of these one-parent families 48,500 have a male parent and 363,600 have a female parent.

What do we do as a parliament to overcome this situation of family breakdown and what do we do to try to keep families together? Firstly, we have a government that brags that over the past several years we have experienced one of the lowest growth rates in real wages. The government really does have to get its act together and implement real micro-economic reform, particularly in the area of industrial relations, so that where employees and employers wish to enter contracts that result in higher earning capacity they are able to do so, if not for the economy then certainly for those families who depend on that income.

Secondly, we have to look at the way welfare is paid in this country and the disincentive this provides for the work force. It is my belief that we must lift the profile and the standing of the family in our society as the most important vehicle by which our children can be nurtured. It appears to me that, whether by desire or by default of the population at large, the family has been taken over by the government and the government now plays the role of child carer in many instances. I believe the importance of the role of those parents, whether mother or father, who choose to stay at home to nurture and care for their children while the other parent acts as breadwinner should be noted and given kudos wherever possible.

Thirdly, I believe that financial structures should be put in place to enable some assistance to be given to parents with children so as to allow one partner to remain at the home and care for the children, particularly in their formative years. This is not to say that a parent must remain at home, but in the case of women, in particular, it would at least give them a choice.

Then we have to look at the welfare system now obtaining, and the figures I quote are from a recent article in the Australian by Alan Tapper. If we look at equivalent final income figures, contrary to the popular welfarist belief, government trends have brought about something close to financial equality between married couples with children and sole parents on pensions. This is taking into account the value of all taxes and all government social services in education, health and housing. The figures show that sole parents and working married parents stand to gain very little from their part-time and full-time employment compared with pension payments.

In my electorate a woman phoned me in tears and said, `Mr Hicks, my husband and I can no longer support our children. My husband is the single income earner on an average wage. We have studied the situation and believe that if we separate we would be far better off economically.' I said, `I find this hard to believe'. She said, `I will send you a letter and let you know all my outgoings and my income'. She sent me those figures and, even taking into account the fact that she smokes and the cost of the cigarettes, she would be far better off separating from her husband. That is a terrible situation.

The figures actually show that sole parents and working married parents stand to gain very little from their part-time and full-time employment compared with pension payments. Without going into the detail of the situation, the figures show that the bottom 40 per cent of two-parent families earning an income would be as well off or better off financially if they separated and accepted social security benefits.

In 1988-89, on average, sole-parent families were subsidised by $11,648. Sole-parent families for whom the pension was their principal source of income were subsidised by $18,096. Two parent families by contrast were average net losers from all government transfers by $3,224. Two-parent families for whom earnings were their primary income were debited $5,096.

From my own experience years ago I found that a single income earner in a family, with a husband and wife living together, was certainly behind the eight ball. I think the situation has got worse. Working, married or de facto parents contemplating separation, and life for one on the pension, stand to gain from government a social wage of about $15,650, or about $18,500 in today's terms. Since the average duration on the sole parent pension is 3.3 years, couples who have separated are subsidised by more than $61,000. The only difference between married couples staying together and separating—while both are alive and still supporting children—is that they are not living together. Yet couples who have separated are subsidised by $61,000.

Most sole parents on the pension—about 80 per cent—are separated, divorced or have left a de facto relationship. Contrary to popular belief unmarried mothers make up only about 17 per cent of sole pension recipients, and three per cent of recipients of sole parents pensions are widows. In effect, about 97 per cent of sole parent pensioner families are families with children which, as I said before, in fact have two living parents. The introduction of the child support scheme may have reduced this subsidy a little, although evidence that it has done so is not yet apparent.

Today, the sole parent pension goes to 300,000 recipients with 500,000—half a million—children. This is at a cost of $3 billion per year, and the trend is currently rising at an annual rate of 7 per cent. But we still have not discovered a rationale for that. While I agree that these people, particularly the children, have to be supported—there is no doubt about that—I think there is something terribly wrong when, because of government support, it is economically better today to be separated than it is to be married.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is ridiculous.

—As the honourable member says, it is a ridiculous situation. We have to look at ways in which we can overcome these problems. A number of suggestions have been put forward. Let us first of all look at a suggestion put forward relating to family unit taxation, which is the French system. Under this system, each adult is regarded as a unit and children as half a unit and, if elderly people are supported in an extended family, they are also regarded as half a unit. Today, a single income family on $30,000 pays $18.40 a week more tax than a two-income family on the same family income. We can see there is definite bias against the single income family. The single income family on $40,000 pays $39.30 a week more tax than a comparable two-income family. A single income family on $50,000 pays $67.98 a week more tax than an equivalent two-income family. These figures were calculated on the tax rates effective from November 1993. So we can see there is a definite bias against the single income family compared with a two-income family. I am suggesting that one thing we look at is this unit system of taxation such as the French have. I am not saying that is the answer but it is one thing to look at.

PARA.TAB: Another suggestion, of course, is the income splitting scheme. I know that there have been some criticisms of that simply because it appears that those on higher incomes stand to gain more than those on lower incomes. But, surely, there must be some way of overcoming that situation. Where there is a will there is a way if we are going to try to keep these families healthy and together and provide them with an income that maintains a certain standard of living.

The other suggestion that is being mooted at the moment is a payment to the person who decides to stay at home and care for the child. It seems to me that we are spending a lot of money right around the nation on child care, and I think the best child care available is when one of the parents looks after the child. It seems to me that, in the Year of the Family, we have to do a great deal to try to overcome the situation in which we find ourselves.

Unemployment benefit is another issue I will look at. Whilst I was campaigning during the election, I went into a business house. The gentleman there told me that he and his wife were in business and that they took out $200 per week from the business, and no doubt there were other benefits also. They said that they tried to get someone to work for them because they had to provide a service. The business was not going really well but they decided to put someone on. Eventually, they interviewed a gentleman who had four children. This gentleman's story was that he had been in partnership, had broken the partnership and been touring around Australia for a year, had been unemployed for a year, and had then decided to get back into the work force, so he sought this job. When the person offered him a wage, which I think was $100 over the award, the gentleman looking for the job laughed at him and said, `This is ridiculous. I can be unemployed and get $20 less a week than you are going to pay me for working'. He decided that he would stay on unemployment benefits.

I think that that is another situation in which we have to look at where we are going. Certainly those people unemployed have to be cared for and they have to get a wage that will keep them out of poverty but, by the same token, we must make sure that those people who want to work are given some incentive to work.

I am proud to be a member of the Lyons Forum. It is a group of coalition members who got together—before the Year of the Family—because they believe, like I do, that the issue of the family has to be looked at. We have to look at all legislation going through the parliament to make sure that it is not detrimental to the family and, if there is any way that we can have an influence in changing policy—either in the coalition or in the parliament—we have to try to do something to make sure that families are cared for. As Dame Enid Lyons—who is the person upon which we based the name of the organisation—says, the foundation of a nation's greatness is in the homes of its people. We firmly believe this and we believe that in the past several years families have been going backwards and that we have to try to do something to keep them together.

The sad thing—and I was very surprised at this—is that we are seen as an extreme right-wing group and all sorts of accusations have been levelled at us. I am a parent of four children and a grandparent of six now—thank God—and, from my own experience and from the experience of my children and now my grandchildren, I see the problems they face in our society and the attacks that are being made on the family. I think we really have to have something to strive for—something to aim at—to try to overcome these problems. I think that if the cornerstone of our nation is attacked then our whole nation is attacked.

I am proud to belong to the Lyons Forum. We are going to have a look at legislation and investigate what we believe are ways we can help families in Australia and then put them to our parties and to the parliament. It is not an anti-Hewson measure, as some papers have stated, or a pro-anything else; it is just a group of people who are concerned. I ask the media in Australia not to attack us but, if they want to find out something about us, to approach us to find out what we are trying to do, and then to try to assist us if they believe what we are doing is right for families throughout Australia. We do not have closed minds, we have very open minds and we are a cross-section of the parliament trying to find out how we can help families.

I thank the House for its time. In the appropriations debate today, I think it is fitting to speak of Australian families; where we want them to go and what we want to do for them. I ask every honourable member of this parliament to think seriously about the family situation. We are all in different situations. Whether we are divorced, separated or married—whatever the situation is—I believe the main aim is the nurturing of our children. Having come from a dysfunctional family—and I know there are other honourable members of the parliament who have been through this—I can tell the House that a person never gets over the scars this leaves. Whatever we do, we have to try to keep our families together. If we cannot keep them together, we must try to do something to look after the children, in particular, because they are the future of this nation. I ask honourable members of the Australian parliament to keep this in mind and, in whatever legislation they are putting through the parliament, to keep the welfare of the children and the families of this nation well to the fore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe The Hon N.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr O'KEEFE
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not actually intend to speak on this topic but I would like to make a couple of comments on the observations on the family issue made by the honourable member for Riverina (Mr Hicks). I commend him for the suggestion that, particularly in the International Year of the Family, these things ought to be thought of broadly and in a bipartisan way. I agree completely with the honourable member that it is useless for members of the Australian parliament or anybody else to try to define what ought to be the ideal family situation.

PARA.TAB: In my speech on this topic on Australia Day I focused on what I think ought to be our three national priorities. Firstly, homelessness just cannot be allowed to exist in Australian society. It is just not acceptable that people should be left out there without friends, family or someone in their support base. Homelessness has to be a target.

Secondly, I believe that keeping our young people in touch with our older people in some way or other has to be a necessary process for the ongoing nurturing of a nation and its culture. If the young are mixing with the old, then something in the middle must be working. That is the way I look at it.

Thirdly, violence should not be accepted in any part of our Australian culture. To the extent that domestic violence and child abuse—those issues that occur in Australian families; as the honourable member says, many of us have experienced dysfunctional family situations—exist in our society, we should make every effort we can to reduce them. To my mind, that is the trifecta: homelessness, keeping the young in touch with the old and working to resolve peacefully difficulties between people. So I certainly join in the spirit of the honourable member's contribution.

In a much less bipartisan way, I turn to the topic that I intended to talk about—road funding—and, Mr Deputy Speaker Reid, as the honourable member for Bendigo, this would be very close to your heart. We have adjoining electorates and through the centre of our electorates is the Calder Highway. A very interesting situation has arisen in federal and state road funding relationships. I want to talk particularly about a declaration made by the Victorian Minister for Roads and Ports yesterday which illustrates—the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Crosio), who is at the table, will well understand the issue—the problem we face in the federal government in untying funds, giving the states more responsibility in the form that they ask for and then getting kicked in the backside for it.

The states asked us to untie road funds, to just give them the money without strings attached, and let them spend it where they want. We did that as part of the emerging federal-state relationship through the Special Premiers Conference. In Victoria, that meant about $100 million a year in funds that would have been dedicated to roads are now available for the state to do what it likes with them. Had we kept tying the strings, at least $20 million of that money would have been spent on the Calder Highway—because that was the ratio that the federal government was locking in.

Yesterday the state roads minister wandered into the heart of my electorate and announced—I read from his press release—very graciously that he had decided to spend some of the money that we had handed to him on the Calder Highway. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the State Government had moved to complete this major road project after the Federal Labor Government had irresponsibly abandoned its commitment to funding these roadworks . . .

He goes on to say that motorists are being ripped off and all that kind of stuff. Right through the press release he talks about us—because at the state's behest we have untied the funds: we have given them the money and the state is now spending it exactly where we would have spent it—having walked away from the commitment.

PARA.TAB: I am pretty sensitive to this, particularly in my own electorate, as you can well understand, Mr Deputy Speaker, and particularly when the Victorian state government, the Kennett government, made such a play in the run-up to the state election that this was a vital regional highway and it would give it top national priority. In effect, for the last 12 months the states have been negotiating with the federal government that we take over the national highway system and fund it completely and that, for state and regional roads, we give them the money and let them do their own thing.

In Victoria, we have taken over complete funding of the main national highways—the Hume Highway to Sydney from Melbourne, the Western Highway from Melbourne to Adelaide, the Goulburn Valley Highway from Melbourne through Cobram to Brisbane and the major western ring road linking the Hume Highway and the Western Highway. That was a key part of the agreement. In other words, in return for the federal government taking over full responsibility for the national highways, the state government would take over responsibility for construction of these regional roads.

If I am to be frank about it here in the parliament, there was quite a debate within the government about whether we should agree to this process, because every one of us knew that as soon as we agreed to this the state governments would turn around and start saying, `But you will not spend money on our roads'. The state road ministers are losing the argument against their cabinet colleagues within their own cabinet rooms. The other cabinet ministers are winning the battle and the money is being siphoned off to health, education, police, schools and all the other things that state governments have to use their funds on. Because they have progressively been losing the argument in their own cabinet rooms, they are now turning around and saying that the federal government is walking away from its responsibility.

This is just politics. The honourable member member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), who is sitting opposite me at the table, has been around a long time and he understands how all these things work—we all do. At the meeting of the Council of Australian Governments next Friday the states will once again put to the federal government that they want a freeing up of the financial relationships between the states and the federal government. They will want more freedom and more untied funds. All I can say to them is that they had better ring up the Victorian state transport minister and let him know that he is not doing a lot to help the argument.

As recently as yesterday the concern was raised within the federal government about handing over these funds untied and then finding that the priorities of the national strategies are not being carried through and that, instead, some state minister has his own little feel for what he thinks is important. So the capacity to drive what everybody calls for, national strategies, is handed over in a spirit of cooperation and all of a sudden we find that the states have to be dragged kicking and screaming to produce the dollars for roads that they said before the election they would put at the top of the list.

If state governments want an evolving `mature' relationship with the federal government—we have certainly shown our willingness to move in this direction—they have to play the game. I thought I would take just a few minutes in the parliament to make the point that there is a willingness to continue these reform processes in the interest of national coordination of policies and programs but that it has to be borne in mind that it is a two-way game. No doubt, Mr Deputy Speaker, you will find something of interest in that to use in your own pontifications in the seat of Bendigo. I certainly support the bills. I think the direction that we are moving in is important, but in the lead-up to the premiers conference on Friday I signal that it is a two-way game: if the federal government is being asked to play it, the states should play it too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1993-94 makes provision for additional funds needed to meet extra government expenses which have occurred since the last August budget and which are anticipated over the remainder of this financial year. In the main, the bill appropriates funds for capital works for defence facilities and defence housing.
