However, in addition, it makes provision for grants to the New South Wales government for infrastructure works at Homebush Bay in anticipation of the Olympic Games, additional funding for the rural adjustment scheme, extra relief for victims of the New South Wales bushfires, additional funding for child-care relief and extra resources for labour market programs.

PARA.TAB: Tucked away in the depths of this bill is the appropriation of funds to enable the government to make compensation payments to those parties involved in the Midford Paramount case. It is no wonder it is tucked away. The Midford Paramount debacle is one of the worst cases of bureaucratic bungling in this country's history. It is a source of great embarrassment to this government, and well it should be.

The actions of the Australian Customs Service in this instance had significant repercussions on our relations with the Malaysian government. Putting the Midford Paramount company out of business resulted in the loss of 200 jobs and cost some five people their businesses and their livelihood. The payment of compensation was prompted by the findings of the Joint Standing Committee of Public Accounts. Before I refer to these recommendations in more detail, it is appropriate to revisit the history of the Midford Paramount case.

The Midford Paramount company was a shirt manufacturing company established in the 1940s. It specialised in the production of school shirts for boys. Midford was a very successful business—so successful, in fact, that I venture to say that many members of this parliament today wore Midford shirts when they were at school.

In the early 1970s the Midford company established a factory in Malaysia to manufacture garments primarily for the Australian market; however, some production was destined for the American and European markets. Midford's Malaysian operations became increasingly unprofitable and in the mid-1980s the company decided to restructure that side of its business. Midford subcontracted out its Malaysian operations but retained the corporate identity in that country. In 1987 the Australian Customs Service raided the premises of Midford's customs consultant and subsequently claimed that it had found evidence to suggest that Midford had contrived to avoid duty of around $16,000.

In late 1987 Midford's Australian operations, both Wollongong and Sydney, were raided by the Australian Customs Service. Officers justified their action on the ground that they believed Midford was systematically undervaluing goods imported from the Malaysian factory. Based on the seized records, officers formed the opinion that Midford had sought to defraud the Commonwealth of some $4.5 million of duty through the invoicing of shirts at 30 per cent below production cost and by manipulating its import quota.

In the course of raiding Midford's factory and administrative offices, eight officers from the Customs Service spent five hours seizing documents relating to Midford's business operations. Officers cleaned out filing cabinets and confiscated box loads of documents, irrespective of whether they related to the importation of shirts or the Malaysian operations. In the process, they intimidated the workers of the factory, most of whom were female and of a non-English speaking background.

Actions of the Australian Customs Service, unfortunately, did not stop there. Another three raids on Midford were carried out with the seizure of 162,000 shirts with a market value of around $1.8 million. Evidence suggests that these raids were timed to have a maximum impact on Midford's business. In early 1988 Midford's import quota was cancelled and in mid-1988 the company was charged under the Crimes Act with conspiracy to defraud the Commonwealth. The company's assets, as well as the assets of the directors of the company and their tariff adviser, were all frozen.

But this bizarre story does not end there. Officers from customs then proceeded to Malaysia to gather further evidence and to support their charges against Midford. Without consulting the Australian High Commission, or any other representative for that matter, the officers visited the factory in Penang where it was believed Midford Malaysia operated. Again they searched the premises and seized documents relating to Midford's operations and again it was done without the appropriate authorisation or proof.

When Midford Malaysia took out an injunction seeking the return of seized documents, the officers from customs fled the country. Committal proceedings on the charges laid under the Crimes Act commenced in June 1989. It is interesting to note that this is one of the first cases where the Crimes Act was used rather than the Customs Act, as had been the normal custom. If convicted, the defendants faced sentences of up to 20 years and fines of $20,000 each. Following confirmation of arrangements made between Midford and the Fraser government, the charges were withdrawn. Costs of $365,000 were awarded against the Commonwealth.

Even then, the Australian Customs Service did not, unfortunately, give up. It investigated the possibility of bringing charges against Midford under the Customs Act 1901. Midford subsequently sought compensation of $9 million for loss of business and income lost from the seized shirts, along with the reinstatement of the quota. Its claim was rejected out of hand. Following protracted negotiations, Midford was eventually allowed to buy back the seized shirts and was allocated a token quota entitlement.

The end of this tale is that the combined effect of customs seizures of Midford stock, the withdrawal of quota entitlement and the unrecovered legal expenses incurred by Midford led to the collapse of a successful 40-year-old company.

Some three years after the final chapter on this saga and following a number of inquiries, the Labor government has finally admitted that it managed this affair very badly. While not apologising, the government has admitted its liability and will pay those involved in this case some $25 million in compensation. This bill makes provision for the payment of that compensation.

From the very start, the actions of the Australian Customs Service were based on error and misinformation. Facts were not checked, material was misread, events were misinterpreted, there was a lack of supervision of junior officers and pressure was put on officers to give the prosecutors the information they wanted to hear. Indeed, as I said before, the whole matter was extremely badly handled.

All of these comments were backed by the findings of the Joint Standing Committee of Public Accounts. In fact, the committee's report is one of the most damning indictments of a government ever to be delivered. The findings of the joint committee have more recently been confirmed by the Conroy committee of inquiry into the Australian Customs Service. It is disturbing to note that it found that the attitudes which led to the Midford debacle were entrenched in the Australian Customs Service and that drastic and immediate action was needed. According to the joint public accounts committee, the evidence placed before it indicated that the Australian Customs Service was at best incompetent and at worst deceitful. The report said:

SPEECH.PARA: Planning, management, reporting and accountability were all found to be deficient.
Overall, the Reports represented a terrible indictment on the ACS and it is a poor reflection on that organisation that many of the more fundamental matters raised therein needed to be said.

Some of the blame was placed squarely on the officers of the Australian Customs Service and the web of deceit which they had created to cover their actions. The committee uncovered evidence of serious shortcomings in the investigatory work undertaken by the ACS. It noted that officers all too often misunderstood or misconstrued evidence before them, jumped to insupportable conclusions and ignored or even deliberately suppressed evidence beneficial to explanations provided by those individuals subject to the investigation.

PARA.TAB: The committee, and more significantly the magistrate who heard the committal proceedings, noted that bureaucrats often had heard only hearsay evidence and were never in a position to prove the conditions. The magistrate further noted that the officers had misled the prosecution and had selectively provided information to their superiors. Two of the officers departed from their sworn statements in the course of the committal hearings. The joint public accounts committee found a range of inconsistencies in the process of gathering evidence. The committee said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it became evident that the Customs Officers misunderstood or misconstrued the eligibility requirements for the quotas granted to Midford, and that in some cases these basic misconceptions persisted right up to the time the Committee examined the individual Customs witnesses in the latter part of the enquiry.

Moreover, the committee found that material supplied by customs did not in any way support its actions. The committee itself was drawn into the web of deceit created by the Customs Service. The committee said in its report that it `reached the stage where it could no longer trust the answers provided by witnesses from the ACS'. The committee encountered `an excessive number of inconsistencies, inaccuracies and contradictions' in the evidence given by key witnesses from government agencies.

PARA.TAB: In reading the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, it becomes very clear that the ACS was on a witch-hunt. Indeed, anecdotal evidence suggests that the Customs Service wanted to successfully prosecute a high profile importer under the provisions of the Crimes Act rather than the Customs Act. There is a further suggestion that it was the reason behind the significant publicity given to the raids, laying of charges and subsequent court case. The report of the parliamentary committee states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Midford case arose from a government responsible for enforcing the Customs Act unwarrantedly judging a company as guilty of an offence and subsequently targeting that company.

It seems that customs had something to prove, but the price of this was the loss of livelihood of five highly respected men and the demise of one of Australia's oldest and most successful clothing companies. The other price of this debacle is one to the taxpayer: some $25 million of taxpayers' money will be spent in getting the Australian Customs Service and the government out of the mess which was, in fact, created by their own inefficiency.

PARA.TAB: Do not get me wrong. We support the payment of compensation in the matter; in fact, we consider that, since this matter has been going on since 1990, it is well overdue. But it is a case of concern that the taxpayer continually has to bail this government out of its mismanagement.

It is also cause for concern that there has not been any attitudinal change in the Customs Service and that, as such, a similar situation could occur again. As far back as 1990 concerns were being expressed about the culture of the Australian Customs Service—including its apathy, its view that all importers were crooks and its utter determination that fraud is common in the clothing industry. The Customs Officers Association has admitted that the culture of the Australian Customs Service is the core problem.

The most recent report on the Customs Service, released just two weeks ago, confirms that there is a problem of attitude within the service. The report suggests that the culture of the Australian Customs Service would only be revitalised by the injection of new blood, particularly at management level. To this end, it recommended a spill of all senior positions.

The coalition wholeheartedly supports this recommendation. I take the opportunity to urge the minister to implement this as a matter of urgency. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Crosio), who is at the table, will no doubt remind me that this has started with the resignation of Comptroller-General, Frank Kelly. I am aware of that, just as she must be aware of my belief that this is simply a token gesture and will do little to fix the ills that plague the Australian Customs Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another case of jobs for the boys.
—That is another concern. The gentleman concerned is now employed by DITARD; it did not really send the right message.

PARA.TAB: That the Midford situation has occurred at all is an unfortunate situation indeed. That the taxpayer has to foot the bill is equally unfortunate. However, the government must use this Midford case as a lesson. Firstly, it must take action to ensure that the procedures which led to the destruction of Midford's business are rectified and that this situation should never occur again. Secondly, it must implement the recommendations of both the Midford report and the recent Conroy report to develop a new and better focused Australian Customs Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak in support of the appropriation bills before the House today. I would like to speak on a number of aspects in relation to this legislation. As has been said earlier today, the legislation covers a range of areas consistent with the government's aims for Australia throughout the recovery process, which is happening at present. I believe that industry needs a lot of encouragement as we forge ahead. We should particularly be helping the unemployed.

PARA.TAB: The most important of the government's aims is reducing unemployment. Honourable members do not need to be told that, as they have been told it often enough. But it is an important area. The largest challenge we face as a nation is getting the unemployed back into the work force. We need to provide real hope for the unemployed, particularly the long-term unemployed. The green paper, which is on the agenda at the moment, will need to be responded to in a very positive way. My understanding, from the attitudes of my colleagues and government members, is that we can expect a very positive response when the white paper is delivered.

The people of Australia need to be assured that the government is doing all it can in getting the unemployed back into the work force. These measures will go some way towards doing that. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has stated on numerous occasions recently that this is properly the major focus of government policy—and rightly so.

The people of Australia need to be assured that the recovery which is under way will not pass the unemployed by and leave them with few job prospects in a time of increasing prosperity for the nation. The appropriation bills before the House are evidence of how seriously this side of politics takes its responsibility to those members of the community who are adversely affected by the recession. In this legislation, provision is made for an additional $49.3 million for labour market programs providing assistance to job seekers and industry.

Contrary to statements emanating from members of the opposition from time to time, these programs do assist in the task of helping people back into employment, back into the work force. They are complementary to the employment growth that is being provided by the recovery, an indication of which was exhibited by the ANZ job ads series in the January monthly economic and social indicators, showing a 34.7 per cent increase in job ads since January 1993.

There are many advantages in having these labour market programs. In my electorate, I have found that the benefits go beyond just the major stated objectives of providing improved job prospects for those who are in danger of falling out of touch with the labour market. The programs also serve to improve the quality of the labour supply in those training methods. They help in stemming the loss of motivation amongst the unemployed. One of the biggest problems is that, when people are unemployed for long periods, they lose motivation and become very disillusioned—and understandably so. As members of parliament we should always bear that in mind and be very sympathetic and supportive of these people.

People in the community say that the unemployed should have to work for their unemployment benefits. It is not always possible to do that. I think that is kicking the unemployed. They want to get out and get a real job. There is no simple answer to that. We need to train these people and get them into new and innovative work patterns so that they have some dignity. Many views have been expressed by the caucus employment task force, which is co-chaired by the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford), the honourable member for Lilley (Mr Swan) and the honourable member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith). I have been fortunate enough to be associated with that committee as well. The suggestions have been very positive and I hope they will be picked up by the government.

Some very good examples of the value of the programs which have been referred to can be found in my electorate and, I am sure, in many other electorates and probably in your own, Mr Deputy Speaker. But the concentration on providing practical skills and courses for unemployed youth has seen the establishment and growth of a Skillshare funded unit in my electorate called YUPI—young unemployed people of Ipswich. It is not to be mixed up with any other yuppie type word. This group runs courses as diverse as catering and fibreglassing for young unemployed people in the region. Importantly, these courses include running businesses in their curriculum—businesses such as the catering outlet called Tuckerbox and canoe hire at Lake Wivenhoe in the Brisbane Valley, which is now in the electorate of Dickson represented by the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch). This year the YUPI program will receive over $400,000 in funding to continue its work. I think it will be money well spent.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great program.

—As the parliamentary secretary at the table states, it is a great program. The executive officer of YUPI is a young man by the name of Paul Pisasale, who is also an alderman on the Ipswich City Council. Paul is an enthusiastic young man who works very hard in helping these young people with his very positive ideas. He is also the chairman of the Ipswich Regional Development Corporation. Paul is the Labor Party candidate standing for the position of mayor of the city of Ipswich in the local government elections to be held on 26 March this year. I am sure he will be extremely successful, given the support and the encouragement he has given many people in the local community. I wish Paul and his team well in the forthcoming elections. The sort of enthusiasm that Paul has been able to generate amongst these young people is very important.

PARA.TAB: There are many other success stories to which I can point. In the 12 months to September 1993, more than 1,600 people in my electorate were assisted by skillshare funding. In addition to this, more than $3 million was spent on very successful programs designed to find employment for Aborigines, Torres Strait Islanders and migrant groups.

The funding coming from the Office of Labour Market Adjustment, OLMA, has been particularly helpful in my electorate. This funding is designed to minimise the adverse effects of structural change in regional economies by increasing employment, education and training opportunities for unemployed people. This is a very successful program and I hope that, in the government's consideration of the green paper, that program will be enhanced because it has a lot of flexibility—something which labour market programs need.

The regional manager of my local DEET office is a chap called John Perry. The officers there work extremely hard in promoting this program and they have a lot of interesting and innovative ideas on the drawing board that will help people in their process of transition from training to work. The DEET officers are working on a very constructive program at the moment. I am sure it will work as they are dedicated to the work they are doing.

A significant proportion of the OLMA funding is being used to establish some local employment networks, better known as LEN, which are made up of representatives of business and the general community, and are designed to improve communication between the regional office of DEET and the local employers. That communication is very important. Often we hear criticisms that the CES, as an agency of DEET, is not necessarily responding to employers' needs. That is one area on which we need to concentrate. But there are some success stories.

Last year I set up an employment advisory group comprising people from my local community to make a submission to the employment task force which delivered the green paper and also to my caucus committee. Our group got together to talk about and identify the relevant issues. Whilst some problems were identified, many respondents said that a program designed to provide a job seeker with enthusiasm, good presentation, a hunger to work and a good work ethic was the best way to prepare the unemployed for a return to the work force. Several programs run by DEET, such as the community activity program—which I understand will be enhanced—jobclub, jobstart and LEAP, have achieved these outcomes in Oxley.

The other day in parliament, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) mentioned the enhancement of LEAP. If I recall, he said that another 80 positions had been approved that day. That is a very successful program. The minister made the point that it also encourages people to work in the landcare area. When time has permitted, I have had the opportunity to go out and see a lot of young people working on these projects. They enjoy the work. It is very encouraging for them and they get a lot of support. They really learn a lot about landcare, which is crucial to the protection of our environment. In a lot of ways, that is where we really need to start.

Last year LEAP taught skills including bush regeneration, plant identification, weed removal, selective tree planting, landscaping and horticulture. In addition, young people were given training in carpentry, the use of chainsaws—that might be a bit of a problem in some ways, but we do need to use those sorts of tools from time to time—and trail construction, where trails are put through areas of the bush for people's enjoyment. This program not only provided these young people with skills and improved job prospects but also led to an improvement in their attitudes. One result was the beautification of Denmark Hill Environmental Park, which is a hill in the middle of the city of Ipswich. The Ipswich City Council has established an environmental park there which LEAP was able to use. That is a very positive move. One of the chaps who was supervising this particular program had worked with the council under the jobskills program. He had his training there and then went on to supervise young people under LEAP.

The appropriations before the House mean that DEET can continue to extend its programs to achieve long-term sustainable employment growth. I again make reference to the OLMA program, of which I am obviously a very keen supporter. OLMA's strategic plan for the Ipswich region aims to create long-term structural change in the regional labour market. By establishing the local employment networks, OLMA aims to develop a series of strategically linked programs that will facilitate change. It will result in growth in employment opportunities through business migration, new business start-ups, growth in existing businesses and growth in training opportunities for the unemployed work force and the future work force. It will increase educational opportunities through increasing the access and relevance of educational options to people, particularly at the post-secondary level.

The major emphasis in these programs is on improving the connections between the government training providers and local industry. This is a reform that will certainly lead to better provision of services and greater emphasis on the relevance of programs to the needs of industry. There are signs that this process is already paying dividends.

I mentioned before that sometimes there is good news for the CES and one particularly good piece of news for employment—we often only hear the downside, but this is a really positive note—is that the Queensland based retailer Giant Supermarkets Ltd has agreed that the CES can recruit more than 600 staff for the next phase of Giant's major expansion in south-east Queensland. Last week Giant's management stated that it was impressed by the professionalism, cost-effectiveness and relevance of CES services in recruiting more than 300 staff for the company last year. Developments like this are welcome news as they show the commitment of the government to attacking the unemployment problem on all relevant fronts—both within the ranks of the unemployed and within the government departments and training providers—and to meeting the needs of industry. I congratulate the CES on its efforts and Giant Supermarkets for taking the initiative to use the CES as a very effective employment agency.

Another aspect of the legislation relates to the additional funding for the defence portfolio, which is also a matter of importance to my electorate. I make particular reference to the $71.7 million sought for defence housing, comprising rental advances and additional capital intervention for the Defence Housing Authority. Last Tuesday I had the pleasure of touring the new Fairview Rise Estate development in my electorate, which is not all that far from where I live. The estate is situated in a suburb called Flinders View, which is some four kilometres from the centre of the city of Ipswich. This development is a joint venture development of the Defence Housing Authority and the Mirvac Group. The composition of the estate is intended to be 50 per cent defence personnel families and 50 per cent civilian families. This is in line with the government's policy of integrating defence personnel into the community.

Most people who are familiar with the facilities that have been `enjoyed'—I use that word quite advisedly—by defence families in the past would agree that the current developments in defence housing are a welcome initiative. Fairview Rise, which I will have the great pleasure of opening next month, is set on 50 hectares of bushland and has some six hectares of parkland and five kilometres of running and walking tracks. The government's initiative in providing this improved housing for our defence people has been well received. Some of the housing, particularly in the Amberley area, was not up to scratch. This new development will certainly provide better housing.

Residents' needs are also catered for in this development by the close proximity of shops, schools and public transport. This will have the effect of reducing the amount of alienation often felt by some defence families and it will encourage settlement by civilian families. The homes being constructed are of a very high standard, and on each home site extensive landscaping work has been completed already. It is an ideal development for the members of my electorate who work at the Royal Australian Air Force base at Amberley—the home of the F111—as it is in close proximity to the base. There is a highway just behind the development that runs straight out to the base. Careful planning has allowed for a range of home sizes designed to integrate into the community environment and to avoid the look of sameness that some developments have. I welcome the initiative in the legislation before us today.

I will finish by talking a little about industry and the need for industry investment. In the paper that I provided to the various working parties on employment strategies, I highlighted the future of superannuation and the expansion in that area. I know there has been some talk about tax measures in recent times. I believe that what industry needs is a major boost and a lot of support. There is no need to be talking about more taxes and things; what industry really wants is to get on with the job now that we have more positive economic times before us.

The banking sector particularly needs to be more responsive to the needs of industry. Rather than lending to industry in the way the banks want to lend, the banks should be producing some innovative ideas to assist industry instead of, as happens on a lot of occasions, not assisting it. I have often pushed this barrow and I am pushing it again today: we need to look again at how we can best utilise the superannuation funds, because they are poised to grow over the years ahead. Figures from the ABS some time ago showed that in June 1991 assets of superannuation funds and approved deposit funds totalled $135,108 million, an increase of $10,781 million on the previous year.

The superannuation funds are now geared to move quite substantially. In fact, by the year 2010 it is expected that there will be $1,400,000 million in superannuation funds. If we could encourage superannuation funds, whether by legislation or by a voluntary process, to put one per cent into an investment pool for industry development, we would have to the tune of $1,351 million available straightaway to assist Australian industry.

There is a need to make funding available to a lot of our industries to help them, and I hope that someone will pick up on that idea. I encourage the government to look very critically at it. The bottom line is that we must ensure, through the right legislation, that the funds are well managed and the members' funds always protected. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleary Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Australian on 23 November 1993, the journalist Humphrey McQueen related a story about two young Americans searching for their favourite cheese in downtown Paris. They were not after brie, camembert or roquefort, the types that I am sure adorn the saladas of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on the laminex table in the Lodge. No, our connoisseurs were desperate for a taste of the thin stuff that comes in the plastic wrapper, the stuff that Humphrey McQueen so aptly points out comes from the triumph of supply over demand and the global company over local culture. Although French clocks and antique furniture did not get a run, McQueen went on to praise French taste in a manner which would have pleased our Francophile Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: This, however, is where the similarities ended. Far from attacking the French for their recalcitrance a la the Prime Minister at Villers-Bretonneux, McQueen lionised them for resisting GATT. This view has little currency in the federal parliament or the bureaucracy where, unless people adopt the pose of a football coach and rave about the beauty of competition, it is thought that they have just stepped out of the cave. It would seem that the French understand just who the big winners will be under GATT's new world order. In stark contrast with the French, our bureaucrats trip over themselves constructing arguments in defence of opening up our markets to all comers.

When the world falls apart around us, the Prime Minister and his frontbench inform us that a good set of numbers will be bobbing up any day now. Whereas the French believe they have something worth protecting—work and culture—we are more inclined to see ourselves as a dumping ground for overseas goods. All we need to do is push on with enterprise bargaining and labour market programs directed at the so-called unskilled and we will have the most competitive work force in the world, so the argument goes. I think the Prime Minister calls it the engine room of the world.

All the while we grapple with a balance of payments crisis and the economic rationalists tell us that those disappearing industries were inefficient and only offered dead-end jobs. If the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) has been quoted accurately in this morning's Age, even import replacement might no longer be fashionable on the Left. Yet if one were to cast an eye over some of the notables on our import list, it is obvious that a bit of import replacement might not be a bad idea.

For the year 1992-93, we spent $6 billion on imported road vehicles, $1.4 billion on imported paper and paper pulp, $2.1 billion on imported textiles, yarn and fabrics, $570 million on imported cork and wood, $500 million on imported footwear and $500 million on imported seafood. The list is depressingly endless.

With a bit of research and development and attention to quality, which were issues taken up by the honourable member for Melbourne, we might even be able to produce some of these goods ourselves. One of the great ironies in this debate—as confirmed yesterday in a speech by the shadow minister for finance, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello)—is that the coalition has failed to learn the lessons of the past decade. The honourable member concluded his speech by telling us that it was a tragedy the government had no idea nor the commitment to see the task through.

The usual suspects were rounded up along the way. The left wing of the Labor Party was accused of wanting to pick winners and engage in a spending spree. We were told that the labour market, which I suppose means workers and trade unions, was the major structural impediment to the solving of the unemployment problem. Presumably, what the honourable member for Higgins wants is a version of industrial relations of the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), and we all know what that means for working people.

And, of course, things would not have been the same without the predictable call for cuts to government outlays. I know that the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) is very fond of that one. Those of us who are unfortunate enough to be living in McCarthyist Victoria under the Kennett regime know what this means for the public sector and for the provision of community services. The great tragedy is that our dependence on foreign capital, a dependence lamented by the honourable member for Higgins, is a product of the very policies his party, the bureaucracy, those perennial grumps McGuiness and Moore, and the rump of Labor Party adore.

The honourable member, a self-proclaimed dry, might be amused to know that those much respected left-wing economists Frank Stilwell and Ted Wheelright agree that our dependence on foreign capital is a serious problem. The difference of course is that they would do something about it. They would probably re-regulate. He and his party would not, nor would the Labor Party.

The honourable member for Lilley (Mr Swan) was not about to let the honourable member get away with such myth making. The coalition policy, or lack of it, and the GST received a mandatory caning. By the end of his speech, I was almost believing it was the coalition and not the ALP which had been in power for the last 10 years.

If members of the Australian Labor Party believe there is no connection between government policy and unemployment, or if they think that the rise in participation rates or the alleged lack of skill of some workers explains the levels of unemployment, they must surely have rocks in their heads. Although solving unemployment—especially now that decisions about the location of capital are more often made in Tokyo, New York, London or Brussels than they are in Australia—is no easy task, we can do without the myth making.

A further problem is that it appears we now have an industry minister who thinks it has all been too easy and that regional economics, sectoral planning and an interventionist approach ought to play second fiddle to vague notions of international competitiveness. I ought to take him down to Wills to the seat of the former Prime Minister of Australia, Mr Bob Hawke. He could then see some of the unemployment first hand. There is a very real possibility that we will not have an industry statement at all. Maybe this is the real reason why the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths) is not on the front bench.

This comes in the wake of an article in the Australian Financial Review yesterday which pointed out that the slump in the manufacturing industry in 1991-92 was the biggest since the Australian Bureau of Statistics began collecting data in the area in 1968-69. The Prime Minister can flog the export of elaborately transformed manufactures till the pigs come home and the Minister for Tourism (Mr Lee) can extol the virtues of a bed-linen led recovery, but it is cold comfort for the unemployed in the former industrial heartlands of Australia.

As we all know, these very same heartlands became poor cousins to marginals when the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) doled out her money prior to the last general election. As I have said before, so much for social justice in the Labor Party. Labor Party members can justify it on the ground that Labor seats are worse off than Liberals, and that is certainly true, but there are plenty of anomalies in the minister's actions.

To compensate for its obsequious approach to industry policy the ALP will give us a white paper, a jobs compact and much agonising over a jobs levy, voluntary labour, transitional wages and work for the dole. Some on the Left, fearful that the Kelty plan will be shelved, are renewing their support for a more sophisticated approach to industry development.

Even the co-chairmen of the caucus employment task force, the honourable member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) and the honourable member for Lilley, despite the latter's great faith in the ability of Meals on Wheels and voluntary work to overcome some of the problems of unemployment, are worried about what is in the offing.

The honourable member for Perth is not too keen on a tax on capital, although it appears that some on the Left are now moving away from a tax on workers to a tax on capital. However, he is at least prepared to argue for an industry policy. Aware that current government purchasing policy is at best a joke and at worst a national disgrace, the honourable member for Perth identifies it as one of the four planks of industry renewal. The question is: is this consistent with the GATT?

The Australian Financial Review of 16 December 1993 identified a few possible problems under GATT for interventionist industry policy advocates. There is the partnerships for development scheme in the information and aerospace industries. There are the export enhancement and import credit schemes of the motor vehicle and textile, clothing and footwear industries respectively. There is the factor F scheme for pharmaceuticals and there is the industry development arrangements for telecommunications. They were all identified as some of the measures which could be outlawed under GATT. I am sure the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) would be most unhappy if the factor F scheme were outlawed. We could well be left with nothing but the tiresome rah-rahing that has accompanied all the guff about international competitiveness.

Only two weeks ago our GATT masters gave us a pat on the head for our liberalising approach to trade matters before admonishing us for not doing more to reduce tariffs in the automotive and TCF industries. Our anti-dumping legislation, we were told, was harmful to small exporters and our labour market too rigid. We have heard it all before, have we not?

The Indonesian ambassador chimed in with the warning that we should resist the temptation to cast off deregulation in the wake of the recession. Given the wage levels of Indonesian workers and the treatment dished out to trade unionists in that country, we all know what the Indonesian authorities mean when they talk of deregulation. It was recorded only too vividly in the papers recently.

Of course, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade was quick to confirm its commitment to deregulation. Mr Peter Grey, a senior official with the department, went on to say that Australia did not have strategic industry programs and that transitional protection in the telecommunications industry would be phased out in 1996. He had obviously been well worded up by the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan), who was about to tell the world that Australia would cut its tariffs even further if the rest of the world was willing to do so. Yes, we have heard that one before as well. It is funny, is it not, that immediately after the Wills by-election the Prime Minister, ever keen to score a political point, lampooned the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) over his zero tariff policy? We all remember the days of Captain Zero.

Recently there have been signs that some in the coalition are finally aware that the Labor Party has pinched the middle ground and that unless the coalition modifies its neoclassical obsessions it will be out of power for another 10 years. Strangely enough, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) has emerged as an unlikely hero here, pointing to the problems of foreign ownership of nationally significant industries such as the media. He is almost a Marxist in Liberal terms. The coalition, however, remains a long way off the main game.

I listened with interest to the comments of the honourable member for Melbourne this morning. I agree when he says that we should not have a preoccupation with Asia and that if we are really serious about exporting we would have Latin America high on our shopping list. In fact, I made this point on page 66 of the document `New Ways in Wills', which I produced more than a year ago.

It is also worth noting that many exporters who come into my office or whom I have dealings with complain about our preoccupation with Asia. The standard view is that there are similar opportunities in other parts of the world. The Prime Minister only needs to look at the globe. On the issues of clustering of industries, again I agree with the honourable member for Melbourne. On page 23 of the document which I wrote more than 12 months ago I had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Despite government policies there are strong and productive industrial clusterings within the region. Industrial concentrations such as those of Wills are dismissed as distortions in neo-classical theory. In Wills a reliable industrial workforce has been built up over generations. The skills and work experience of these workers are simply discarded under the policies of the major parties.

PARA.TAB: We all know of the success of the Italian textile industry. Matthews and Weiss in their research into the Italian textile industry pointed to the coexistence of competition with cooperation. They failed to find any Australian equivalent to the Italian general framework of support. Matthews, however, identified similar networkings in a group of small Sydney computer firms. The establishment of regional industry councils would facilitate such programs. If we could move them out of Canberra and get them into the communities, we might have half a chance.

Where I do not agree with the honourable member for Melbourne, if I understand him correctly, is his dismissive approach to import replacement, government purchasing policy and anti-dumping programs. Nor do I believe that the main game is international competitiveness. He would surely know that, although our TCF industry, for example, is as efficient as the best of those in OECD countries, it does not ensure competitiveness with countries using exploited labour.

That takes me to the question of dumping. Focusing simply on price is not all there is to the question of dumping. I would argue—and I am sure the honourable member for Melbourne and those on the Left, if they are still with us, would agree—that goods produced under exploitative conditions where, for example, trade unions are banned should be classed as dumped goods. I came face to face with this issue on a recent parliamentary delegation to the Indian subcontinent. It was the issue of child labour and many other aspects of working conditions that were a problem. In fact, the conditions in some of the factories I saw there would not be tolerated in Australia, nor should they be—except that the Labor Party allows us to compete with them.

Another problem in the approach of the honourable member for Melbourne is that he almost falls into the trap of suggesting that international competitiveness or comparative advantage is static. It is not. There is plenty of evidence to support the proposition that some industries which appear to have no place in the international scheme of things can, with the right policies, become successful. It is recognised by industry that government purchasing policy can have a key role in enabling local companies not only to acquire markets but to develop their skill and expertise in a way which facilitates their move into export markets.

Part of the problem with our purchasing policy at the present time is that it has no real commitment to, or understanding of, its role in the development of Australian industry. Because of this slap-dash approach and the cultural cringe mentality which dominates the thinking of our purchasers, many Australian companies are losing a great opportunity to take a step forward. I have come across companies in my own electorate that have suffered at the hands of government purchasing policy, or lack of. The joke of course is that most other countries know exactly what the value of smart government purchasing is.

On the question of indiscriminate import replacement, a couple of things need to be said to the honourable member for Melbourne. It is foolhardy to believe that one can do everything as efficiently as the next person or the next country. I remember well being in Nepal last year, where a particular minister asked whether there might be some value in the Nepalese breeding Australian types of sheep rather than importing the wool from New Zealand. The honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) thought this was a silly idea and advised the gathering accordingly, saying they should stick to carpet production—often done by children—and forget about growing wool.

There might be occasions on which efficiency is not the only imperative. For example, why have a car industry if we can import cars more cheaply? Why not give up the car industry? I do not think we would be happy about that. Some would, though; Des Moore would not mind. If you are French, why have cultured cheese when you can have the American transnational form which comes in the plastic wrapper?

So is international competitiveness the main game? Well, yes and no. International competitiveness is a reasonable objective; however, we have to be aware of the costs and we should not be driven by the logic of neoclassical theory. The honourable member for Melbourne dismisses neoclassical theory. However, by casting a shadow over the concept of intervention, he runs the risk of affirming the very logic that dominates neoclassical theory.

Frank Stilwell in his book The Accord and Beyond takes up some of these issues. Far from ignoring the questions associated with the internationalising of capital, the likes of Stilwell, Wheelright and the Melbourne journal Arena consistently point to the consequences of our dominance by international capital. This is precisely what Humphrey McQueen is on about with his anecdote about the cheese. I presume the honourable member for Melbourne is not taking a pot shot at Marxism here. Stilwell and Wheelright argued for tighter foreign investment review guidelines, re-regulation and planned or mutually beneficial trade. They do not blush at the mention of the words `interventionist industry policy'.

Like me, the honourable member for Melbourne represents an area that has been devastated by the free trade policies of the 1980s, policies which have left parts of the region with unemployment rates as high as 20 per cent. The honourable member for Melbourne says we face the risk of returning to the ad hoc policies of the 1970s. Surely the Left is not about to laud the policies of the 1980s, which were pursued without impediment in this place because of the bipartisan nature of support.

When the honourable member talks about support for programs involving links between industry and research bodies and the clustering of small enterprises, I am in total agreement with him. Unfortunately, there are a few other questions to be answered. I doubt that the honourable member will be able to explain to the people of Brunswick how it is that international competitiveness without sectoral industry policy will bring back jobs to that region. It could easily be argued that the honourable member for Melbourne is falling into the language of the neoclassicists.

A former Brunswick resident and Labor Prime Minister, John Curtin, used to talk about public ownership and the public good. All the honourable member for Melbourne can talk about is instinctive interventionism, and even that is dismissed. Strangely enough, this ideology runs counter to the spirit of the Brunswick Council, which has adopted an extremely participatory role in local economic and cultural life. The Brunswick Music Festival, an event sponsored by the council and attracting overseas capital in the form of internationally renowned musicians, is an example of this approach. Culture might be alive; the other parts of the economy have a few problems out our way.

The left needs to be reminded that the market and the economy are not outside the community but are things that belong to and should serve the community. The government has a role to play in this. The problem is that I am not sure whether the left understands this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dodd Mr P.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The hypocrisy and petty mindedness of opposition members never cease to amaze me, and that has been simply amplified by this debate. Instead of formulating and debating employment policy, industry policy or taxation reform, the opposition continues to focus obsessively on a $30 million community based grants program, totally ignoring the important policy issues that face Australia today. Of course, it is a very good diversion from the leadership struggle that is currently going on in the Liberal Party.
—I thought you would come round to that.

—The honourable member for O'Connor is probably the only member of the opposition front bench that no-one would wear. No-one would wear him as leader of the party. Everyone else is in the race but I guess the honourable member for O'Connor could rule himself out. The fact is that the coalition has no policies. Now that Fightback is well and truly in the bin, where it always belonged, the opposition has no policies at all and obviously it has no leader.

PARA.TAB: The current Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) is in the hot seat but he is not leading a coalition. His leadership days really ended on 13 March last year when his obstinate passion for a GST led the coalition to lose the unlosable election. For the last year I have watched the Liberal Party in this place slowly reduce itself to a leaderless, policyless rabble.

While those on the other side of the House have been busily self-destructing, the government has continued to pursue policies which have helped to lead Australia out of recession. I can proudly say that those policies of this government have particularly benefited my electorate of Leichhardt in Far North Queensland. The federal government has implemented policies that have ensured the continued growth and economic diversity of the Cairns region. This has necessarily involved focusing on the region's dynamic tourism industry.

The last decade has seen the tourism industry develop into one of Australia's key export dollar earning industries. Mr Deputy Speaker, you will be aware that in 1992 the tourism industry generated foreign exchange earnings of $8.2 billion. In 1991-92 the industry contributed around 5.5 per cent to Australia's GDP. There is no doubt that the tourism industry has played a major role in securing the economic future of the Cairns region. The tourism industry provided 25 per cent of the gross regional product of the city of Cairns in 1992, according to the federal government's Industry Commission report on impediments to regional industry adjustment released in September last year. In 1989-90, 18.7 per cent of international inbound passengers arriving in Queensland disembarked in Cairns, in my electorate. In 1980-81 that was a mere 3.7 per cent, so there has been enormous growth.

A report prepared by the Queensland Government Statistician entitled Tourism Statistics in Queensland, commissioned by the Queensland Tourism and Travel Corporation, shows that Cairns stands alone as the flagship for inbound international tourism. The report shows that since 1988 inbound international traffic to Cairns has climbed by a massive 228.5 per cent. The federal government can claim a lot of the credit for this remarkable performance.

As it happens, 1988 was the year of the federal government's successful nomination of the wet tropics rainforest on the World Heritage List. The establishment of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park and the world heritage listing of the wet tropics rainforest by the federal government in 1988 have ensured that international tourists know about these two great tourist attractions. That nomination to world heritage listing was opposed to the last dying breath of the National Party government in Queensland, which thankfully was turfed out in late 1989.

The Labor government has further assisted the tourism industry by the timely provision of infrastructure. In the Cairns region, the Civil Aviation Authority has spent $1.1 million on the control tower and associated radar works at the Cairns international airport. The federal government has also committed $50,786,000 to works on the Bruce Highway, including the Babinda bypass. In addition, we have spent over $66 million on the national arterial roads in the Cairns region, plus $2 million in the upgrading of the Daintree to Cape Tribulation road.

Initiatives contained in the 1993 budget will further strengthen the tourism industry in Cairns. For example, in the budget the government announced additional funding of $38 million over four years for overseas marketing and $2 million in 1993-94 towards the establishment of a partnership Australia initiative. More directly relevant to the Cairns region is the federal government's $23 million regional tourism development program. I am confident that a substantial amount of this funding will flow into the far north region of Queensland to develop an integrated regional plan for the tourism industry in the far north.

Just this week, the government announced a million-dollar allocation to boost overseas marketing of Australia as a destination for backpackers and budget travellers. This follows a budget allocation of over $4 million over four years to develop backpacker tourism and subsequent industry consultation through the government's backpacker consultative forum.

Cairns is already, as I think most people in this House would know, an extremely popular backpacker destination. The market is worth about $1.5 billion to the tourism industry and I am confident millions of those dollars come to Cairns. The interesting thing about backpacker tourism is that, though backpackers may not have as much money as other tourists, they certainly spend a greater percentage of their money in the local economy, so it is something that we should encourage.

The Bureau of Tourism Research data shows that in 1992 166,000 international backpackers visited Australia, staying an average of 78 nights, compared to 25 nights for all travellers, and spent an average of $3,267 compared with $1,760 for all visitors. The federal government has recognised the growing contribution of the tourism industry to the economy and has acted to capitalise on that. All the opposition has had to offer the tourism industry was a GST which would have devastated the economy in Far North Queensland.

And what is their tourism policy now? Who knows? Perhaps I should ask Bronwyn Bishop, or perhaps I should ask the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter), who said during the election campaign that the GST was okay because it would `rip a billion dollars off tourists', and who now says that there should be no federal money spent on Brisbane's new international airport. What a disgrace. I am sure that the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) cringes every time the honourable member for Kennedy gets up to speak about tourism.

This government's action on tourism has also meant action on jobs in the far north. The Cairns unemployment rate is now below the national average. More significantly, the region has a lower than average rate of long-term unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think they should have a university?

—The honourable member for O'Connor talks about the university. There was $30 million promised by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), 10 plus 10 plus 10. We know all about that. In the budget there are 15 million real dollars spent on the university in Far North Queensland, and it is going ahead. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) was in my electorate in January and we inspected it. It is going ahead. The honourable member for O'Connor is out of date. He does not know. The absurd promises of the Leader of the Opposition did not win him the electorate of Leichhardt. That is what upsets the honourable member for O'Connor, that all those promises, that 10 plus 10 plus 10, came to nothing, because I am in this place.

PARA.TAB: When the Minister for Employment, Education and Training visited Cairns in January this year, he made the point that one of the biggest labour market problems developing in Cairns is the skills shortage. Last week members of the Prime Minister's task force on employment opportunities got a very positive picture of the Cairns labour market when they visited Cairns. The committee met with representatives from local government, the Cairns Chamber of Commerce, the Confederation of Industry, Cairns Region Group Training, TAFE, Catholic Education, Skillshare and welfare groups. The task force report Restoring full employment: a discussion paper known as the green paper on unemployment is an excellent starting point to address unemployment in Australia.

I especially welcome the task force commitment to consultation, and not just with people in capital cities. The government has put its long-term employment programs on hold while the task force formulates its final position. Last month, a total of 47 jobskill training places were approved to help long-term unemployed people in Far North Queensland get back into the work force. The Cairns based Professional Staff Agency is coordinating 30 jobskill places, while the state department of environment and heritage is coordinating the other 17 on behalf of the federal government.

I welcome this initiative in my electorate. The jobskills formula has been successful. Jobskills has consistently achieved over 43 per cent positive results for graduates, either permanent unsubsidised employment or further training. We hope to increase these positive outcomes this financial year.

Another initiative that is working very well in my electorate is the North Queensland community rainforest reafforestation program. This government has committed $4.2 million to the program over four years. Eleven shires in the region are participating in the program, which involves planting rainforests and other timbers on private land as a resource base to the timber industry and hundreds of young people have been employed on the program through the landcare and environment action program. The scheme is also building up a skills base in reafforestation. There is unlimited potential for us to export those skills and to make the Cairns region the world centre for rainforest reafforestation. I was pleased to hear the Minister for Employment, Education and Training inform the House the other day about the allocation of placements for an additional 80 young people in the Far North.

I want to place on record in this House the fact that unfortunately the Cairns City Council is the only council in the region that has declined to participate in the scheme. I take this opportunity to call on all mayoral candidates and candidates for the council to get on board the CRRP.

The green paper on employment opportunities highlighted the potential for additional employment in the environmental sector. Once again, we are leading the way with such programs in the Far North. Mulgrave, Douglas, Mareeba, Herberton, Johnstone, Eacham, Atherton, Cook, Cardwell, Hinchinbrook and Thuringowa shires all participate in the CRRP. The CRRP helps protect the environment by preserving existing forests at the same time as it creates job opportunities for young people who are trained in plantation techniques through the landcare and environmental action program.

The minister visited with me a number of plantation sites around Babinda in January this year. We went with Mr Joe Baker, Chairman of the CRRP management committee, to Errol Wiles's property and the Boulders tropical fruit farm managed by Mr Pedro O'Connor, both near Babinda. I think Errol Wiles would be one of the most enthusiastic supporters of the scheme that one could meet. His vision is to plant his entire property under the program with his main objective being future timber production. Site preparation has been completed and 13 different rainforest species have been planted, including block plantings of hoop pine and teak. Twelve different rainforest species have been planted on five acres of land that was previously used for cane growing at Boulders tropical fruit farm. The bulk of the planting was carried out in February and April 1993.

The minister was very impressed with the importance and success of the scheme. The idea of young people working on landcare and environment projects makes a lot of sense, especially as those young people have been given work experience that they would not have had. CRRP is an excellent example of what can be achieved when the three tiers of government and the community work together to provide a future for Australia's young people.

While long-term unemployment is a problem in Cairns, like everywhere else, I am sure the region presented a more positive picture to the Prime Minister's employment task force in terms of jobs growth than perhaps other regions around the country. With a number of big construction projects getting under way this week, the job market in Cairns is set to expand. The residential construction industry alone is presently a $250 million a year industry in production terms. Cairns has the highest urban growth rate of the provincial cities of Queensland. We have been eclipsed in this regard only by the Sunshine Coast and the Gold Coast.

The sugar industry, of course, is still the major contributor to the far northern economy, and the federal government has committed $20 million over four years, matched by the state government, for sustainable infrastructure projects in the industry. That does not ignore—and I do not want to ignore—the mining industry.

Cairns's growing manufacturing and export trade has the advantage of close proximity to South-East Asian and Pacific markets. The federal government's task force on regional development, chaired by Bill Kelty, held public hearings in Cairns in August this year, and the report of the task force highlighted the growth potential of the Cairns region.

The Kelty report highlighted the long-term transport needs of Far North Queensland and I endorse the report's call for construction of a dual highway from Adelaide to Cairns in the next 30 years. I especially support the recommendation to develop fast train connections between key cities, and I think that this is obviously one of the transport modes of the future. The Kelty report talks about the importance of rail and I would not want to underestimate that.

To complement the Kelty report, the McKinsey consultancy on business development in regional areas will also appear. The Cairns-Townsville region was one of the first chosen. Senator Bishop, who I understand is shadow spokesperson for regional develop

SPEECH.PARA: ment in the coalition—or one of them—made an attack on the preparation of this report in the Sun-Herald in Sydney on 30 January. The study is designed to provide an understanding of the factors driving private sector investment or, conversely, non-investment in the north and the far north, and yet Senator Bishop knocks this. It will target a broad range of business types from retailers to lawyers to those participating in heavy industry. The pretender to John Hewson's throne rejects this consultative approach. I guess the only thing that can be said about Senator Bishop is that perhaps she could be called `she who must be obeyed'. She knows and no-one else can tell her.

PARA.TAB: Of course, the sort of rapid growth that we are experiencing in Cairns does have its downside. This Friday the Cairns Mulgrave housing network is holding a workshop on the subject `Tourism and affordable housing do not mix—or do they?' and of course there is a question mark there. The influx of job seekers to the region puts a lot of pressure on the regional market in Cairns and along the Marlin Coast to Port Douglas. The problem is exacerbated by the holiday rentals in places like Port Douglas, and prices do rise due to any local property boom.

Unlike the opposition, this government is developing policies to deal with these issues. Since elected I have been working very closely with the office of Mr Howe, the Minister for Local Government and Community Services and, of course, Brian himself to implement an appropriate planning model in Cairns. He was in Cairns in the middle of last year holding consultations in these areas.

There are important planning issues in the region that need a cooperative and planning approach, pooling skills of local government authorities and agencies such as the Wet Tropics Management Authority and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, state government departments and the local community.

The Far North Queensland region will continue to outperform other regional centres because we have a vibrant expanding tourism industry, a strong sugar industry, great potential for adding value to our primary products, a thriving horticultural base on the Atherton Tablelands and, most importantly, we have the policies on this side of the House that deliver the results.

When we make policy on this side of the House we go and talk to people. The Kelty task force came to Cairns and talked to people. Unlike Senator Bishop, we do not criticise consultation. The Prime Minister's employment task force came and talked to people. Cairns people will continue to have their say under the Labor government. Our policies are working in Cairns because we talk to the people who count; we deal with the real issues. In contrast, the leaderless rabble on the other side of the House continue to fight among themselves in a policy vacuum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make some comments today on these appropriation bills and on the strange speeches that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has been making about the need for micro-economic reform in the states. In judgmental statements over a period since April 1993, the Prime Minister has been holding forth to the states of Australia on the need for them to reform. At no point in any of these presentations has the Prime Minister acknowledged that the Commonwealth government needs to set an example if it expects other governments to follow.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister laid down four principles as part of the proposal for the Council of Australian Governments meeting in Hobart next week. Firstly, there should be recognition of the role of the states in the federal system. Secondly, there should be a commitment on both sides—that is, state and Commonwealth—to use reforms for their own sake and not as bargaining chips in future negotiations. Thirdly, there should be a willingness to enter into genuine discussions on the roles and responsibilities of the states and the Commonwealth. Fourthly, there should be a blanket refusal by the Commonwealth to entertain any substantial transfer of Commonwealth taxing powers to the states.

Each of those points needs serious investigation. Those points that are proposed as matters for discussion at the Council of Australian Governments in Hobart need close scrutiny by state governments. I have noticed with interest that already the Premier of Western Australia, Mr Richard Court, has condemned the federal government for the way in which it is seeking to make, as he calls it, `a grab for power'. When one examines the principles stated by the Prime Minister, one would have to agree with that observation by the Premier of Western Australia.

When micro-economic reforms were proposed in Victoria by the Kennett government, when the Kennett government moved to recover the disastrous situation left by an incompetent, wasteful and fraudulent state Labor government, they were blocked at every turn by the Prime Minister of Australia who said, `We will not allow the Victorian government to move ahead with its program of micro-economic reform'. What nonsense is it that the Prime Minister is now presenting to the premiers of Australia in claiming that he has a new-found interest in micro-economic reform?

One needs to examine the four points. However, it becomes pretty obvious fairly quickly that while the Prime Minister does mean reform, he means reform for the states but not for his lifestyle, his behaviour, his treatment of the parliament, his treatment of the Australian people, or anything that resembles micro-economic reform. None of those is on the Prime Minister's agenda. The only thing that is on the Prime Minister's agenda is to continue to squeeze the states harder for as much money as he can get out of them for this difficult budget, to squeeze them as hard as he can and to give away as little as he can of his own revenue. He wants to hold it all centrally in Canberra and use it at his whim.

The recognition of the role of the states in the federal system is the first point. What does that mean? It is a bland statement that means that the states have a role, but if it is Mabo legislation that is being dealt with then they get rolled. It means that anything that the state governments stand for is ignored if it is something that the Prime Minister designates as being of national significance.

The ministers at this table would not be taking part in these negotiations, but they range across things such as regional development, legal services, workers compensation, electricity charges and the electricity industry, industrial relations, and a whole range of other things that the Prime Minister wants to put on the table.

I can understand Premier Court being distressed when contemplating what the Prime Minister has in mind because the fact of the matter is that he has experienced the Prime Minister's regard for state governments, and he does not want any more recognition of his state government's role in the Commonwealth from this Prime Minister, so he rejects quite roundly the first point. I do not know how the other premiers are going to confront this, but I believe that Jeff Kennett would be pretty concerned if he got any more recognition from this federal government as far as industrial relations and the powers of the Victorian government are concerned.

The Prime Minister's statement proposes that both sides make a commitment to use reforms for their own sake and not as a bargaining chip for future negotiations. In fact, that means that any state government that has made a successful reform cannot hold it up to the federal government and say, `We have been good at what we have done. We are reducing our costs and therefore we need some recognition to be able to keep our state government going'. It means that those who remain inefficient are the ones who will continue to be rewarded and those who have made reforms cannot hold them up for credit at any future meeting of the Council of Australian Governments. So the reforms are entered into for their own sake.

It also is a process that seeks to protect the Commonwealth government. The Commonwealth government is not going to consider advances made as part of micro-economic reform as laudable or to the advantage of the Australian nation. What the Commonwealth government is saying is that there will be no recognition of reforms and they will not be used as bargaining chips. That means that the Commonwealth government itself need not make reforms. It cannot point to its own example, it cannot say to the state governments, `Why don't you follow the practices we have instigated?'. The fact is that the Prime Minister has no intention of having the Commonwealth as a pacesetter; his total intention is to screw the states as tightly as he can.

The third point made by the Prime Minister in the statement yesterday related to the willingness of the states to enter into genuine discussions on the roles and responsibility of the states and the Commonwealth. I have been reading an interesting article in today's Financial Review by Prudence Anderson, who seems to be a writer for the Prime Minister's office because there is so little analysis of, or critical statement about, the Prime Minister's speech. According to the article, the issue that former Prime Minister Hawke raised of the reduction of duplication in state and Commonwealth services is back on the agenda. But, in this instance, according to Prudence Anderson:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . this time around it will be broached as a sectoral exercise to try and clean up functional duplication in the health and community services area.

That is what it has always been about: the relationship between the Commonwealth and the states on providing community and health services. That was the sticking point under Bob Hawke. It was never possible to get past the point where both Commonwealth and states wanted on the one hand to retain the delivery of services but on the other to dispense with the delivery of services. The cooperation needed to achieve that is massive. Mr Keating is stomping around and saying, `We are going to go back in there where Bob Hawke left off, but this time we are going to get it right. We are not going to be able to use any of the systems that Bob Hawke used, so what we will use'—he is saying in small type—`is the power of the purse to achieve these objectives of ours'. That is what it is about.

PARA.TAB: The fourth point raised by the Prime Minister for discussions with premiers at the end of the week is a blanket refusal by the Commonwealth to entertain any substantial transfer of Commonwealth taxing powers to the states. There is no responsibility given to the states: make them mendicant dependants upon the largesse of the Commonwealth government, make them prepared to settle for the abuse heaped on to them by the Prime Minister, make them prepared to understand that words like `the Commonwealth was prepared to adequately resource the states' mean what they say. Of course, they do not—the Prime Minister's words never mean what they say. He has never once in this parliament, or out of it, meant what he said and done it.

So the Commonwealth cannot in any way bring the states into an area of control except by the power of the purse, and it is no wonder that the state governments are really concerned about what the Prime Minister intends to do at the Council of Australian Governments meeting. His intention is to squeeze the budgets of the states, to allow the Commonwealth budget to continue to grow, and to instigate no micro-economic reform, the sorely needed micro-economic reform that can be given direction and impetus by the Commonwealth. He has refused to do anything about that. One has only got to look at the port strike and what has occurred over the last couple of weeks to see the inadequacy of this government in dealing with any of it. It has not got a plan, it has not got anything. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) says, `Well, I have achieved a lot'. The strike is still on in Sydney. Hooray! He started the process, went through it, everything stopped around Australia and we came back to the stoppage continuing in Sydney. What has been achieved by the Minister for Industrial Relations strutting the stage of Australian politics saying he has fixed things up? That is this government's idea of micro-economic reform.

There are two dominating agenda items for this Council of Australian Governments meeting. The first is the states' demands for an overhaul of federal-state relationships. Yes, that must happen. It has been Keating-speak that has gone on, the screwing down of the states, giving them no responsibility for any area of taxation but doling out money to them as the Commonwealth sees fit, but then not applying any rhyme or reason or judgment as to the way in which those handouts are made.

What has happened in the past is that, if it is a Kirner government in trouble or if it is a Bannon government in trouble, there is extra money there. That is the way those decisions are made. It is not a matter of straight economics or efficiency or micro-economic reform, it is a matter of whether one is a mate or not. A state government in the past has received additional funds if it is a mate of the Prime Minister. With the change in the voting pattern around Australia, with only one Labor state left in Australia, it is no wonder the states are saying, `We want to get down to real issues. We've tried to make economic reform, but you want to come in and control the electricity grid or you want to control our industrial relations by writing laws here in the Australian parliament for builders labourers, rather than allow the Victorian government to do it'. That is the sort of control that the Commonwealth wants. It is no wonder that the state governments, headed by Mr Court, want an overhaul of federal-state relationships.

The council has another major agenda item that will be considered by the premiers, and that is the Commonwealth's insistence that the states pick up their own performance on micro-economic reform. I have heard the Prime Minister making these statements, and the Prime Minister's judgment is that the states have made no micro-economic reform. In my state of New South Wales there has been reform after reform, consistent changes, and for some time the people of New South Wales have borne those changes and can see the benefits of them. But there is a limit to the patience of the people of New South Wales with the reduction in staff in all types of government agencies and consistent cutting of the budget. However, the one thing that comes through from these processes adopted by New South Wales governments, starting with Nick Greiner, is that New South Wales fared better in the recession than any other state because it was better placed to do so.
