It did far better than the Commonwealth government, far better than the Victorian or any other government around Australia, because the reforms were started in time, well ahead of any contemplation given to these matters by the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister has just plucked something out of the air, saying, `This is a way to encourage economic reform—we will cut state budgets'. The state budgets have been consistently cut for a long period of time in order to force economic reform. It is time that the Commonwealth itself got serious about economic reform.

One of the reforms that stands out is the one that the Minister for Industrial Relations and the Prime Minister refused to make to Australia's industrial relations. They are passing legislation through this parliament to make things worse, to tighten union control of the way in which decisions are made between employers and employees.

I attended a speech given by the Prime Minister on 21 April 1993 to the Institute of Directors in Melbourne. The Prime Minister said in that speech that decisions on wages, working conditions and salaries should be made by the workers themselves, their employer and the union—a three-way contest. What a strange sense of proportion this Prime Minister has.

In the same speech, in passing, whilst talking about the way the Commonwealth is so well equipped to establish changes in regional development—another major so-called proposal for the Council of Australian Governments—the Prime Minister says:

SPEECH.PARA: In Alan Griffiths, we now have a senior Minister in Cabinet charged with regional development. As a result, the regional dimension of all Government policies will come under constant focus.

That was some minister! That was some sandwich shop! Where is the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths) today? He could not run a sandwich shop and yet he was being touted by the Prime Minister as being the person most likely to lead Australia into a blinding new future with his attitude to regional development. As the Prime Minister says:
Existing programs will be reviewed, including to ensure harmonisation with State programs.

We had the Kelty report. Mr Kelty wandered around Australia visiting some areas and then presented his report on regional reform. He visited western Sydney for one day. Western Sydney has a population of between one and two million people. Mr Kelty spent one day there. He thought that was enough time to look at that regional area, and then he left.

PARA.TAB: There are huge problems in western Sydney. Last night we heard a major speech from a new member, the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham), about those problems. Honourable members should understand the problems western Sydney has with its burgeoning population, and yet Mr Kelty and his staff spent only one day there. So this is the brand-new day the Prime Minister is talking about for regional development. The only thing that was proposed for western Sydney that was of any consequence was that the international airport should be pressed on with and that a new freeway should be built. There was very little else.

Those proposals are very wrong. When it comes to considering the Prime Minister's views on what should be done in micro-economic reform, the whole process is just a blind. What the Prime Minister is endeavouring to do is to cut state budgets and grab more power for Canberra. Not one element of this program needs to go on the agenda for a discussion of this type. All of these programs can simply be effected by the Prime Minister and the Commonwealth government putting into action some of the Prime Minister's rhetoric and applying it to his area of responsibility.

The micro-economic reform espoused by the Prime Minister should start at home. It needs to start, firstly, with industrial relations. Then it should cover the management of government resources and government enterprises themselves. The whole process of privatisation has stalled due to union movements which are demanding that the government not proceed. The government itself has been stalled by the Clerical Workers Union on the reform that it is proposing for Australia Post. Outlandish claims have been made by that union, and the government has baulked at going further ahead.

I think the whole process that government proposes for the Australian states will drag Australia further down. This Prime Minister has no understanding of leading from in front. All he does is manipulate and control and then seize the front-page headline. All he is interested in is whether or not he gets the headlines, whether he gets the front page, whether his words are up front. It means little to him whether there is any progress or advancement or change which is to the benefit of the Australian people.

I cannot think of a more incorrect headline than the one which says `New deal for States in PM's plan'. There is no other headline that I have seen around Australia today which so totally misrepresents the ultimate goal of the Prime Minister than this one, because the Prime Minister's only purpose is to control the states, cut their budgets and grab power for Canberra. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, honourable members would be aware that this time roughly corresponds with the end of my first 12 months as a member. In my position, being a new member in this parliament, this is when I reflect on my first 12 months as a member. In doing so I will state that it will definitely not be my last period in government. I intend to win quite a few elections and I will have a side bet with the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) that I last longer than he does.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Newell)—Order! The honourable member will confine his remarks to the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be remiss of me not to concentrate on what is definitely the major issue concerning the people of my area. If I stood up here and said roads, roads, roads, roads, I would not be saying it enough. I am in a regional seat and quite frankly the majority of our roads, whether they be controlled by the state or by local government, are dog tracks. In fact, they would probably be better described as goat tracks.

PARA.TAB: Mr Deputy Speaker, in my first speech I made reference to Wally the Whale, the then Minister for Roads in New South Wales, and I had a good shot at him about the Tomerong bypass. It so happens that Wally just could not resist and the Tomerong bypass is a reality now. It has been constructed.

The thing that I find interesting about that is that when I suggested that Cooks Constructions was going to do that work I was told by the state government that the allocation had not been made. Yet, at the exact time that I said that Cooks would be there, the announcement was made, and it was Cooks Constructions. I wonder whether there may be some corruption in the New South Wales government because I knew that it had let a contract out but it did not. It is a matter I am taking up with ICAC.

I had reason to talk with the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Fahey, the other day and I brought up the matter of main road 92. The response from Mr Fahey was, `Not in our lifetime, son'. Well, I have got news for Mr Fahey. It will happen in our lifetime whether he likes it or not. The point is that he will not be the Premier for much longer and when we get some sense and reality into the picture in New South Wales the state government will see the economic importance to my electorate of main road 92. It is a road which is now in an unsealed condition, but the major bridges have been erected. It would give access from Canberra to the coast in just over two hours.

I might add that it does not involve significant passes, tunnels, or any major hassles with the escarpment because basically it goes through only one large hill near Sassafras and that is it. The economic benefits that that would generate for my area in terms of tourist dollars, in terms of a two-way flow with Canberra, in terms of accessing at a very cheap rate the route from Canberra to Port Kembla—in fact the whole south-east of New South Wales to Port Kembla—would involve a massive boost for these areas.

For the Premier of New South Wales to say `Not in our lifetime' is a very shallow and narrow attitude. But, as I say, he will not be there for long and I am sure that I will be able to talk sense with Bob Carr when he becomes premier.

That conversation did bring up one salient point. We have made a grave mistake and I am sorry that this government is part of it. Our grave mistake has been to give untied money to the states because they cannot be trusted. If we look at the priorities that they have, particularly in roads, those priorities involve pork-barrelling.

I see the honourable member for Mayo smiling, but I find it outrageously hypocritical that he should give the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) a hard time about anything that happened, in view of the record of the New South Wales government. One could find no more corrupt pork-barrelling in the world than in New South Wales. One would not have to go past Premier Fahey or past the National Party to find it. I will give a few further examples later on in my speech.

If we look at the reality of it, the roads out in the west of New South Wales are four-lane highways which hardly anyone uses, while my area has people who need those funds for access to decent transport, but who get absolutely nothing. That may be a situation that the Liberals and the National Party like, because in fact they do not hold the seats down in my area. They are Labor held and independently held, and for that reason we get the short end of the stick. I will go through this matter further with regard to health, but I can tell Mr Fahey directly that we will get funding for main road 92. By hook or by crook, it will be done. If the only way it can be done is to bring back tied grants and make the New South Wales government spend them, then that indeed will have to be the way that we go.

I now turn my attention to fuel prices. There is a 20c variation in price. Before anyone starts whingeing and screaming and going on about the federal government's levy, it applies equally to the whole of Australia. If we now have equal legislation throughout Australia, can opposition members tell me why in my electorate I should have to put up with a 20c variation per litre in the price of fuel? I can tell honourable members that it has got nothing to do with freight. It has got nothing to do with anything other than the marketing practices of individuals and individual companies. I cannot and will not stand for it.

I have asked the House transport and communications standing committee, of which I am a member, to require that it receive a brief on this matter, because something smells in this regard. When I can go 10 kilometres and find a 20c variation in the price of fuel, then I think that honourable members should take note, as should everyone in this country. I know that the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile) is concerned about this, because we have talked about it before. He is one member of the National Party who understands that people in rural and regional Australia need a fair deal. What we are talking about here is a consumer rights issue. People blame freight costs, but that is total garbage. There are cartels in operation within the service station industry, and there are cartel operations going on within the producers—

TALK.START.PARA: —And the trade union movement.
—The honourable member blames the trade union movement, but it is not the trade union movement that turns around and directs market prices, and he most definitely knows it.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Newell)—Order! Honourable members will cease interjecting. The honourable member for Gilmore will not respond to interjections, please.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now move on to some further instances in relation to fuel prices. For example, I totally support the organisation representing the truck transport industry in its recommendations for diesel pricing, and I will do all that I can to see that its recommendations come to fruition. Another issue is the effect on the maritime industry of the diesel hikes. The Maritime Union of Australia is another great ally of mine, because many of its members live in my area. The Seamen's Union of Australia, now incorporated into the Maritime Union of Australia, went to great lengths with restructuring to change the manning levels of our ships, and to change practices so that its members would get some profitability back into that industry, so that their jobs could be assured in Australia's future. An unfortunate by-product of our fuel price changes is that many of those profits have been swept away by the increases in fuel prices. Because I value my comrades in the Maritime Union of Australia and their contribution to this country, I will do all I can to protect their interests and the interests of this country.

PARA.TAB: Transport is the main equity issue in my electorate. If one looks at the cohorts of mature Australian women, one finds that many of them, through no fault of their own but through the socialisation that they have experienced in life, have not obtained driver's licences. That may not seem like a great burden, if one lives in one of the major cities with public transport. But if one lives in regional Australia, as I do, where there are vast areas of rural landscape, one has no public transport. We do not have access to public transport. So when dad dies and mum is out there at 65, and she does not have a driver's licence, she is left on her own. That creates a whole range of problems.

When we talk about equity, social justice, access to services, access to work and to community needs, it all comes down to transport because the young people, the unemployed people, in my electorate will all benefit by access to transport. I am fully supporting the reinstallation of the urban public transport program and the black spots program in the next budget. Transport issues are major issues that affect the people of my electorate, and I will do all that I can to assure them that they will be represented.

The next matter is the electrification of the rail service to Bomaderry. The state minister, in a very sleazy act, tried to say that the former minister, the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), had promised funding in a pork-barrelling exercise for electrification of the rail link to Bomaderry. That was a complete lie. Linking back to the roads question and Mr Fahey's `never in our lifetime' statement, the former Minister said, `It is back to state priorities'.

The reality is that the major part of my electorate is held at the state level by Mr Hatton and Mr Harrison, and Mr Fahey actually holds one section of that. Amazingly, those parts of the electorate get a very good deal. Those areas have got their hands in the cookie jar every time. I do not take that away from my people in the top end. I support all the services delivered to them. But what about the people in Kiama and Nowra? What about the people in Ulladulla? The reality is that the pork-barrelling that is going on in New South Wales is such that my people are not getting the services that they require.

I move on to health. Here is an example of the reality of what has been taking place in my electorate and the areas surrounding my electorate. Let us look at the scenario of what is happening in the Labor seats: Coledale hospital—closed; Bulli hospital—closed; Port Kembla casualty—closed; Shellharbour hospital—beds restricted; Kiama hospital—closed; Berry hospital—under threat; Shoalhaven hospital—under-funded.

Now let us turn to the areas that my electorate covers, where there are Liberal members and a National Party member: Moruya-Bega—$8 million increase; Bowral, the Premier's own seat—$10 million. If those people on the other side have the audacity to start talking about pork-barrelling, tell them to have a look at their own governments. Tell them to have a look at Kennett and what he is doing in Victoria and, more to my concern, what Fahey is doing in New South Wales. It is absolutely outrageous what these people are trying to pull off.

What we are talking about is consumer rights issues. The health consumers of my electorate, in the Labor held parts and in the Independent held parts, have got just as much right to services as the people who are in the Liberal sections. Those people should support that, but they do not because they think it is all right as long as they are getting away with it. That is what they are doing. The reality is that my people demand access to bulk-billing and access to 24-hour medical service but they do not get it in significant parts of my electorate. It costs them $32.50 for a consultation. If they have not got the bucks on them, it is $5 extra. And if they cannot guarantee that they will pay, they do not get seen. That is reality. This issue of access to services and to decent hospitals is such that over 7,000 people have signed a petition in Milton-Ulladulla urging updates of that hospital and more facilities for that area. They are going to be laughed at by the state government because they do not happen to be in a Liberal seat. Consumer rights are the issue, and I will stand up for my people. If the state Liberals will not do it, then I will.

I would like to turn my mind to employment. The Liberal loser in the last federal election turned around and made some outrageous statements because of the fact that 130 jobs were lost in the Shoalhaven paper mill. He wrote this outrageous letter which he sent around about what the honourable member for Gilmore was doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you doing?

—I will tell the honourable member what I was doing. On the very day that halfwit wrote that, I was at Amcor in Melbourne discussing with Mr Don Macfarlane, the General Manager of Australian Paper Manufacturers, how to increase his involvement in my area and to get more jobs. That is what I was doing. Where was he? Bleeding away and trying to get publicity on the backs of poor unfortunates who have had their livelihoods taken away from them. I find that sort of activity and those sorts of actions absolutely outrageous. I have in writing on Amcor letterhead the results of that meeting with Mr Don Macfarlane. I will be taking the results of that meeting to the people of Shoalhaven through the Shoalhaven City Council and other organisations which will be involved.

PARA.TAB: These are some of the issues that were raised. We have had a council there that has wanted ocean outfall—for God's sake! In this day and age, they want to pour effluent into our oceans. Let us just go through a couple of things that that does to the economics of my area, apart from anything else. One of the biggest industries in the area is tourism. Whether that effluent pollutes or does not, it is the perception in the minds of the tourists who come to our area. I can tell honourable members that tourists do not want to come to an area where they are swimming in their own excrement. They do not want to. If there is one lesson to be learnt about the tourist industry around the ocean areas, it is that people do not want ocean outfall.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, do something about it! Don't just stand there and talk about it!

—I am not just standing here and talking about it. I have done something, whereas the honourable member has done little more than make loud noises. I have seen the people in the industry. I have seen Wollongong University, Greenpeace, ACF, Amcor, the South Coast Labour Council and CFMEU. I have got some agreements and some written conditions. They are vitally interested in farm forestry. We need to get these industries on the go because that is where increased employment will come in my area plus a whole deal of training and future jobs.

PARA.TAB: I would go further and suggest that I have some support from the local areas for the New South Wales big bike ride. I am hoping for an announcement in the next few days as to whether or not we have been successful. That will involve between 2,500 and 4,000 people bicycling through my area for 10 days. The organisation spends on its own up to $600,000 plus what the people themselves spend. That is what I am doing about employment in the area. I have this Liberal loser from Gilmore asking me what am I doing. All he is doing is trying to ride on the backs of the poor unfortunates who have been thrown out of a job, and it is despicable. It is absolutely despicable.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! I have asked the honourable member for Sturt to refrain from interjecting on a number of occasions. I now warn the honourable member for Sturt.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been asking the labour market to re-endorse our actions on employment. My involvement came after the election and a change was already set in motion. I have had to intervene. I have tried to force the agenda to turn around because I need a few things. I need a directory. The concept of a directory prior to that was to get the yellow pages and pull out all the Sydney numbers; that was the directory of manufacturing in my area. That is the level of some of the thinking. I need a directory which tells me the CEOs. I need their phone numbers. I need their fax numbers. I need to know what they produce. I need to know where they source their raw materials. I need to know where they are located. I need to know how many people work for them. I need to know what their machine capabilities are. I need to know where their markets are and how they access their markets and I need to know—
—Why don't you find out?

—How do I find out? I have to find out by going through these processes, and I have been able to do that too. The honourable member talks smugly from his desk. I am doing things in my electorate and we have already started to move in that direction. Extending from that, we have got a number of people involved interested in setting up mariculture in that area. (Time expired)

—I have been rather fortunate this week; this is the third time I have spoken in the chamber and I think it is the second time that I have been blessed with the opportunity to follow the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Knott). It is interesting that we both have had the opportunity to speak just prior to question time this afternoon when there are a few people in the gallery who have been fortunate, or unfortunate, enough to witness the ravings of the honourable member for Gilmore when he comes flying in here like a bat out of hell.

PARA.TAB: I will comment in a moment on a couple of the things that the honourable member for Gilmore touched on—or thumped. I do agree with the honourable member for Gilmore about the disparity in fuel prices not only around Australia but around New South Wales, but I do not necessarily agree with him on the cause of that.

The debate is really about appropriation bills Nos. 3 and 4. There are some interesting figures in those if we have a look at the funding that has been appropriated. Obviously the opposition is not opposing these bills, but I would like to raise some questions about some of them. I will just run through some of the appropriations in bill No. 4. There is a $50 million grant to New South Wales for capital works at Homebush Bay. Obviously, everybody in Australia is going to support the contribution towards the year 2000 Olympics.

There is a $25.2 million appropriation for compensation for defendants and others in the Midford Paramount case. This is a sad indictment on the lack of ministerial control over a government body, the Australian Customs Service, and what that organisation did to Midford Paramount. I had the fortune or the misfortune of becoming a member of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts—

TALK.START.PARA: —Good fortune.

—It is good fortune, I suppose. I came in on the tail end of its inquiry and recommendations with regard to the Midford Paramount case. It seemed that it had been going on for quite a few years before this government and a new minister were prepared to grasp the nettle and address the serious situation that had affected that organisation. A number of people that were involved in that affair had their health detrimentally affected.

PARA.TAB: On a related issue, it was brought to my attention recently that in my electorate of Lyne we have an operator who was in partnership with the CSIRO in some research and development project that seemed to come asunder. It has been reported in the Canberra Times and the Australian back in January that, following a lengthy court case between that private company and the CSIRO, the CSIRO paid out an out of court settlement of allegedly almost $10 million. It has also been alleged that there is probably a legal bill that has been underwritten by CSIRO, and ultimately the taxpayers, of a further $10 million. On the back of the Midford Paramount case, that is another sad indictment of the way this government runs the country.

In the appropriation bill there is $20.7 million additional funding for the states under the rural adjustment scheme. We certainly welcome that. Those of us that represent rural and regional areas of Australia where the drought has had a devastating effect on a lot of our primary producers would have liked to have seen more money and more consideration given to these people in their time of need.

There is $8.9 million for the development of a package of measures to reform the private health sector. That is a very interesting appropriation. It is going to be interesting to see what the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) does as far as reforming the private health sector is concerned. It is going to be interesting to see what the Minister for Health does in consultation with those organisations, the medical fraternity and the service providers throughout Australia, and how he goes about reforming the private health sector.

Regarding the $7.3 million in additional assistance to those affected by the New South Wales bushfires, I do not believe that that is enough money. From those bushfires we have seen some of the greatest devastation in New South Wales in the history of this country. We have seen the inadequacy of essential services to mount a decent defence of residential areas—of life, limb and property—during those bushfires. The Victorian bushfire brigades that came to the assistance of the bushfire brigades in New South Wales during that time have commented since that they were amazed at the age and the poor condition of the bushfire fighting equipment that is used by bushfire brigades in New South Wales.

An amount of $7.3 million might seem to be a lot of assistance, but it has to go across the board to assist a lot of areas. At some stage this government must consult with the New South Wales government about the provision of equipment, and not just ground equipment. We had to borrow aerial firefighting equipment from New Zealand, for goodness sake—our poor cousins across the Tasman—to help fight the fires.

It is terribly important that, perhaps in the budget this year, we look at the provision of more funding for those essential services, and not just in New South Wales. We have seen some devastating fires in Victoria and South Australia in years gone by, and we certainly need to pay more attention to the protection of people and those areas as well.

An amount of $7.3 million to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission for assistance in the preparation and presentation of native title claims is a fair swag of money, in anybody's terms. For the benefit of the people in the gallery, this funding is not for any form of compensation that may arise but it is just for the preparation and presentation of native title claims.

The next element in the appropriation bill is $5.4 million for payments to states and mainland territories to reduce the waiting time for elective surgery. This funding relates to another sad crisis that the present government is in, but will not admit to, regarding health care in Australia. We have just heard the honourable member for Gilmore having a fair bit to say about the provision of health services and the health services infrastructure in his electorate, and firing a broadside at the New South Wales government in that regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —And so he should.

—And so the honourable member for Gilmore should. But what the honourable member should also remember is that the funding ultimately comes from here. So he needs to talk to his Prime Minister (Mr Keating) before he goes to the heads of government meeting on Friday to deal out the money and find out how he is going to deal with the Premiers around Australia, particularly regarding health care in Australia in the future.

PARA.TAB: An amount of $5.4 million to alleviate the waiting list for elective surgery is the federal government's own indictment of its health care system. We realise that the Minister for Health is going to undertake a review of the health care system. We saw an increase in the Medicare levy this year, but we still have long waiting queues for elective surgery. We still have a lack of funding coming from the peak taxing body in this country—the Commonwealth government—to the state governments, as was pointed out by the honourable member for Gilmore, yet the government has to make extra appropriations to alleviate the problem that it has caused. I urge the Minister for Health in his considerations for the restructuring of the health care industry in Australia that he seriously—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Gilmore was saying that the people in his electorate cannot bulkbill and he was blaming the New South Wales government. It is not the New South Wales government; the Commonwealth government is responsible for bulkbilling. The honourable member knows that, and it is no good standing up here and hammering away at state governments—

PARA.TAB: Mr Knott interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Gilmore!

—It is all right, Mr Speaker. Let the honourable member go; it is quite interesting. It will be interesting, as we approach the budget to be presented in May, to watch the decisions that evolve from this government—particularly from the Minister for Health and particularly in the budget considerations—relating to the provision of health care services in Australia.

PARA.TAB: While I am on the matter of the criticisms that the honourable member for Gilmore was making about the New South Wales government, it seems to be a bit of a trademark of all the members, particularly on the government's backbench—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 3.00 p.m., the debate is interrupted. In accordance with standing order 101A, the debate may be resumed at a later hour. The honourable member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance and Leader of the House. I draw the minister's attention to this advertisement that ran during the election campaign. It says, `One man can make a difference . . . for local sport'. It is a very becoming picture of the minister with a baseball bat.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will put the poster down now.

—I do not want him to forget it. Given that the reason he is now the Minister for Finance is that he won the seat of Swan by 294 votes, can he advise the House of his estimate of how many of those votes were bought by the $552,000 in grants bestowed on him through the sports rorts program? Is the contribution made by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories to his being Minister for Finance the real reason why he is now covering up for her?
—I wish the ad had been that big in the newspaper in which it emerged; I think it would have been even more useful.
—Why are you moving to another electorate?
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo will cease interjecting.

—I totally and completely owe my election to the honourable member for O'Connor, who took a whiteboard to the Ascot raceway in the week before the election and attempted to explain the GST to the electors of Swan—or at least to that section of the electorate of Swan that was interested in the racing industry. Subsequent to that, I had a whole series of approaches from members of the racing industry who had never voted Labor before telling me that they were going to vote for me. I think that is one reason why I won the electorate of Swan.

PARA.TAB: I think the second reason why I won the electorate of Swan was the extraordinary policies put forward by the Leader of the Opposition. It is no secret at all that the Labor Party was in some trouble in Western Australia during the last election campaign, but again he came nobly to our rescue. So I thank the honourable member for O'Connor and the Leader of the Opposition for the 200-odd votes by which I subsequently won the seat of Swan. As they are the reasons why I won the seat of Swan, no other explanation is required.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the minister aware of recent comments about Australia's industrial relations system by the distinguished American academic and former US Labour Secretary, Dr Ray Marshall, who is presently visiting Australia? Can the minister explain the reasons for Dr Marshall's visit and the significance of his reported comments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brereton The Hon L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Lilley for his question. I noticed the comments attributed to Dr Marshall—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The minister might resume his seat for a minute. The minister has barely got out three or four words when interjections from my left have started again. For the last couple of days, in the settling down of the new arrangements, I have been prepared to display some tolerance. I am not about to do that today.

—I noticed the comments attributed to Dr Marshall in the Australian, and I subsequently had a chance to meet with him and discuss industrial relations on Friday last. His comments are worth noting, and I think the whole House should note them. Besides being a very well-known international academic, he is a member of President Clinton's Dunlop commission, the 10-member tripartite mission that is looking at the proposed reforms to the United States industrial relations system. He chairs that commission's internal working group, which is looking at selected overseas countries in order to draw some ideas for the reform of the US system. I think it is worth pointing out that only Australia and Germany have been chosen for such study. In Dr Marshall's own words:

ANSWER.PARA: We are not going to any country we do not think we can learn anything from on worker-management relations. We are not going to the United Kingdom, for instance. We are going to Australia and we are going to Germany.

When he was asked what the US could learn from Australia, he pointed out such things as occupational health and safety and the growing emphasis in the Australian wages system on the question of productivity. His most telling observation was that the Australian system was superior to the US system in that it makes it very difficult to pursue low wage strategies—that is what he said. He also said:
Companies in Australia were forced to concentrate on productivity while in the US—
he went on to say—
we don't have those adequate safety nets and therefore workers are forced to take whatever wages they can get.

This is the learned academic from the United States visiting us to study our system. This came on top of John Prescott's comments only a couple of weeks ago about IR not being a problem in terms of Australian productivity. All of this must be very galling indeed for the opposition, particularly for the high priest of individual contracts, the honourable member for Bennelong. In the AAP release that I got just before coming to the chamber for question time this afternoon, under the heading `Clinton advisor endorses Australian IR model', the following words are attributed to Dr Marshall:
I would like to have your system,—
that is what he said; listen to this—
I'd do anything for us to get the Australian system of collective bargaining.

Does the opposition like that? The opposition has to face the reality that the world's greatest power, representatives of which have already been to Australia to study our health system, now has in Australia representatives studying our industrial relations system. Not only that, but Dr Marshall was able to tell me that the study is not just on the administration because the House of Representatives Majority Leader, Richard Gephardt, has said that he is planning to introduce legislation based upon the Australian best practice scheme.

PARA.TAB: I conclude by saying that it is high time the opposition stopped bagging this country's IR system. It is about time the opposition started listening to people like Dr Marshall and John Prescott. The world certainly is not looking at the opposition's policies. The world has already well and truly passed it by.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Has the minister's department expressed any concerns regarding the administration of the community cultural, recreation and sporting facilities program? If so, what concerns has it expressed?

—Firstly, I should explain that my department does not actually perform an audit function in relation to any program of government. The department is responsible for providing advice to government at the time new policy proposals are being considered and it will, of course, have comments on programs at that point of time. From time to time, we will have discussions with the Auditor-General on activities that the Auditor-General is interested in. The department has a general responsibility to ensure that there is expenditure against appropriation.

PARA.TAB: As I understand it—I only entered the department recently—from time to time the department has had concerns with regard to the community cultural, recreation and sporting facilities program. Those concerns have largely revolved around the fact that the program has regularly underspent. The program has regularly underspent because basically one of the checks that are in the system means that until the money is actually spent by the recipient organisation and until there is, if you like, something to show for it at the end of the day, then the money cannot be appropriated. This is why there are no new approvals being given, including in the forward estimates, even though the program has been completed. There is a substantial overhang in subsequent years.

As I understand it, the department occasionally expressed concerns about the initial stages well before the current Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories was appointed to that position. But, at the same time, it came to the view that, because of the checks that were put in place, such as the one I referred to, by and large it could proceed.

The fact is that the daily audit function related to the operation of the grants is not a function that is performed by the Department of Finance. It is a function which properly rests with the Auditor-General. My department comes to a conclusion, in terms of giving advice to government, on the basis that it gives advice on most programs or new policy proposals that are suggested, that they should not go ahead.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Consumer Affairs to the education campaign explaining the government's proposed system for Australian labelling which was launched by her. Can the minister advise the House of the public response to that campaign so far?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. This very popular decision on the new labelling is going through two stages. The first is an information campaign. I have just sent out an explanation of how the scheme will work to the many thousands of people who inquired after this scheme and put in proposals when we were discussing it with the public. We have distributed thousands of leaflets so far. The response has been extraordinary. We are having to reprint and reprint because so many people are interested in our proposals.

PARA.TAB: A few people have criticised the scheme because they would like something added. For instance, people promoting Australian owned products would like us to add to our labelling information whether the product is owned by an Australian company. The scheme sets the baseline. If people want to add that their company is Australian owned they can certainly do that. If the National Food Authority wants to add extra information about food, it can do that.

The basic scheme is so simple. We will just have two categories: `Product of Australia' or `Produce of Australia' for all Australian goods and `Made in Australia' for goods made in Australia but from imported ingredients. After that, the manufacturer will have to describe the stage or process that takes place, such as `Assembled in Australia from imported goods' and `Packed in Australia from imported goods'.

So the scheme is very popular. We are getting indications that business is already coming onside by wanting to comply with the new terms. The next stage will be an extensive education campaign for business and consumers once the legislation passes through the parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General and refers to the fact that, as the first law officer of the land, he is responsible for legislation which requires businesses to keep adequate documentation required for the purposes of a company audit. Does he agree that ministers should also be required to keep documentation sufficient to provide an audit trail for the Commonwealth Auditor-General? Specifically, in relation to this, what documentation, correspondence or other record does he have of his lobbying of the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories on the grant made to the Pine Rivers Youth Band?

—There are a number of elements to that question. I might take first the last one regarding the Pine Rivers Youth Band. My office was contacted by the band when it was first seeking funds for its re-equipment program. My office advised the group of the program, gave it the application form and it subsequently made an application.

PARA.TAB: I was subsequently contacted by the group when it received advice from the department that the application had been knocked back. The group sent me a copy of the letter, which it then sent to the minister, asking for a reconsideration. I believed that the group had a fair case. I contacted the minister's office, spoke to one of her advisers and said that I fully supported the case that it had made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Written representation?

—It was an oral representation; I telephoned the office. In relation to the earlier points in the question: the Auditor-General in his reports has obviously made comments about deficiencies that he believes occurred in the running of this particular program. The minister has said on a number of occasions in this House that I have heard, and I think elsewhere, that she accepts those criticisms and that, if any program of this nature were to run again, then those criticisms and suggestions for improvement would be incorporated. I obviously endorse that.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport. What is the latest information that the minister is able to provide the House in respect of domestic aviation passenger movements? Secondly, what are the implications of that information for Australia's transport program generally, and for Australia's vital tourist industry in particular?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. I am very pleased to be able to inform the House today of the results for the December quarter 1993 which show a record number of passengers flying in Australia's skies. These are quite fantastic figures showing enormous success. Almost 5.5 million passengers flew domestically in Australia to the December quarter of last year.

PARA.TAB: Following upon the aviation reforms announced in our One Nation statement, we have seen substantial changes in the operation of Australian aviation. None has been more important than the international services opened up by Ansett Airlines and the dedicated carriage of domestic passengers by the airline Qantas. So we have seen those two great changes.

In real terms we have now seen an increase of five per cent in the passenger numbers for the calendar year to 31 December 1993. That is really a great result when we consider that 1993 followed upon what was an all-time record year for domestic aviation in 1992.

The most encouraging aspect of all this is the number of passengers visiting some of Australia's great tourist destinations. I can tell the House that in those last figures we saw an increase at Uluru and Yulara airport of 42 per cent. At Alice Springs we saw 17 per cent more domestic tourists.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were very welcome.

—The honourable member for the Northern Territory knows what great economic advantage that 17 per cent increase in tourists to Alice Springs brings to his constituents. For the Queensland members: in Proserpine in Queensland the number of tourists was up by 14 per cent in the last figures. In Tasmania—never to be forgotten—we saw growth up substantially, with Launceston up 11 per cent and Hobart up nine per cent.

PARA.TAB: These results are another example of the government's aviation reforms coming through to benefit the country, to benefit tourism and to benefit trade. The BTCE has reported that the net economic benefits, which are now $100 million per annum, have arisen from the government's domestic aviation reforms. This is truly a great illustration of the government delivering on transport and delivering on economic reform, something, I might say, that all those members sitting opposite were totally incapable of doing for all those years that they occupied the government benches.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Finance to the departmental guidelines and selection criteria for the community cultural, recreational and sporting facilities program which state that projects costing more than $50,000 must have at least a dollar for dollar contribution from the community group involved. Did the Department of Finance oversee the implementation of this requirement and ensure that the requirements were met before advancing funds? Is the minister aware that a grant of $56,700 was made by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories to the Bundaberg Netball Association without any matching contribution? In light of this fact, as Minister for Finance, is he satisfied that the guidelines of the program have been fully implemented?

—Specific questions like that should be put on the Notice Paper. I do not spend my time working my way through the difficulties of the Bundaberg Netball Association, I am afraid to say. I do take an interest in the netball association that my daughters play in, but I do not take an interest in the netball association in Bundaberg.

PARA.TAB: I would have thought the particular proposition made by the honourable member would be a matter for the Auditor-General, not my department. My department's principal concern is to check expenditure against appropriations; in other words, there is an appropriation authority for a particular program, and an expenditure which is being undertaken is an expenditure against that appropriation. My department cooperates with the Auditor-General, but it does not do an Auditor-General's job. So I would assume that the particular—

TALK.START.PARA: —Pontius Pilate.

—It is not a question of being Pontius Pilate; do not be stupid. That is why we have an Auditor-General; it is not a department of finance. If we did not have an Auditor-General, then we would probably have some other department of state that did it. The Department of Finance is not the Auditor-General's office. The Auditor-General is an independent statutory authority. The department gives advice and assistance to the Auditor-General from time to time, but that sort of detailed surveillance of policy is the responsibility of the Auditor-General.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. What action is the government taking to respond to concerns among professional groups, such as auditors, about their potential exposure to unlimited damages claims by their clients and the associated spiralling costs of professional indemnity insurance?
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I believe that question distinctly asks the Auditor-General to announce policy and, as such, is outside the standing orders.
—For a start, the question is directed to the Attorney-General, and I do not think it asked him to announce policy.

—I do not know whether that is a promotion or a demotion. Honourable members might be aware that the governments of New South Wales and Western Australia have announced their intention to proceed with professional standards legislation, which will set out particular standards which professions should meet and, given that the standards are met, propose to introduce a capping regime on the amount of liability which can be awarded against these professions.

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth shares with those two state governments a deep concern at the levels of liability which professionals now face, and that is a broader question throughout the entire community. The Commonwealth also agrees that there needs to be reform in this area of the law. However, at this point, the Commonwealth does not favour the introduction of capping regimes on the liability. Rather, the path which the Commonwealth is exploring, in conjunction with the government of New South Wales, is an examination of the law on joint and several liability.

Last week the New South Wales Attorney-General, John Hannaford, and I announced that Professor Jim Davis, a leading academic tort lawyer from the Australian National University, would be undertaking a review of the law of joint and several liability to see whether there is a case for reform. This is a particular concern for auditors. For instance, if it is found that an auditor may be five or 10 per cent responsible for the losses suffered in some corporate malpractice through some failure of the audit function, nonetheless that level of responsibility does lead to 100 per cent liability. This has led to widespread concern, particularly from auditors but also from other professions.

The government would ask the states of New South Wales and Western Australia not to proceed with capping legislation at this time and to allow this process of examination of the area of joint and several liability to go ahead. A working party of the Ministerial Council on Corporations is looking at the question of liability. Hopefully, from that particular process ministers from both the Commonwealth and the states will have in front of them options for reforms which go to the real cause of the problem, rather than looking at the symptom, which I think capping legislation is designed for.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the honourable member for Eden-Monaro.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are too slow. I call the honourable member for Eden-Monaro.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I have given the call to the honourable member for Eden-Monaro because when I looked to the opposition side of the chamber no-one from the opposition was standing.
—Mr Speaker—
—There is no point of order. The right honourable member should resume his seat.
—There is a custom in this place to which you are obligated.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The right honourable member for New England rose and as he was about to say, `Point of order', you said that there was no point of order and sat him down. My point of order is that you had not even heard what he was raising before you ruled him out.
—The right honourable member for New England said that it was custom and I said that there was no point of order. There is no point of order in relation to your matter either.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the government aware of the rising fundamentalism in Egypt and the Egyptian government response? Will this affect the PLO-Israeli negotiations?

—I am glad to be able to answer this question, which I would have thought would have been of interest to members of the opposition as well. I acknowledge the interest the honourable member has taken in this very important question.

PARA.TAB: The government is aware that over the past couple of years there have been a number of violent incidents in Egypt in which the Egyptian authorities, as well as foreign tourists and businesses, have been targeted by Islamic extremists, notably the group known as the Gama'a El Islamiya. These violent attacks which do pose a serious problem for the police and the military nevertheless remain the work of a small minority, and their effects on the stability of the Egyptian government should not be exaggerated.

The government of Australia is concerned about the violence which has occurred and the effects it is having on Egypt's economy and on social harmony in that country. We share the hope that the Egyptian government can convince militant extremists that resorting to violence is not the answer to political discontent. In that context, we warmly welcome President Mubarak's recent call for national dialogue, with an inaugural meeting which, I understand, is scheduled for April this year.

The government appreciates the difficulties which the Egyptian government faces in dealing with armed militants but will continue to make representations to the Egyptian government on human rights issues, as appropriate, consistent with Australia's firm stance on this matter.

We are also concerned at the pronouncements by Islamic extremists earlier this month which advised foreigners to leave Egypt. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is keeping a close eye on this situation, maintaining contact with our embassy in Cairo in order to be able to offer to Australians planning to travel to Egypt advice on the security situation.

In answer to the second part of the honourable member's question about whether this would affect negotiations in the Middle East peace process: we do not believe that Egypt will be distracted from this important role by the actions of a violent minority. We were greatly encouraged by the signing of the Cairo agreement on 9 February, as I believe all members of the House were. We took it as an indication that both sides were working to adhere to the 13 April deadline—
Mr Tim Fischer interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —for the withdrawal of Israeli forces from Gaza and Jericho. To answer the interjection, I have a copy of that.
—Table it.

—I shall in a moment. I am also encouraged by statements by senior Israeli and PLO officials that a full agreement may not be far off. That was reinforced by the view expressed by Israel's chief of staff, General Barak, that the Israeli army is ready for a speedy withdrawal once an overall agreement is concluded. This government has acknowledged from the outset that the declaration of principles signed last September was only the first step on a long and difficult journey. It will continue to impress on both sides the importance we attach to the timetable set out in the declaration of principles. In answer to the Leader of the National Party: I am happy to table the most recent consular travel advice for travellers to Egypt.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the honourable member for Bennelong moving forthwith that this House censures the Leader of the House for manipulating the question time roster and other aspects of the management of this House so that the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories has been shielded from questions on matters directly relevant to her responsibility and has generally been able to escape accountability for her appalling ministerial performance.

SPEECH.PARA: There is only one game in this town and that is how long the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) is going to last. The only game in town at the present time is how long this pathetic, incompetent, stupid, dishonest minister is going to last. That is the only issue and that is the issue that should be concerning this parliament today. Nothing else should be taking precedence over the role, performance and behaviour of this beleaguered minister, who has been guilty of the most appalling political corruption—I repeat, the most appalling political corruption—that I have seen in this parliament over the last 20 years. There has been nothing more pathetically blatant than the behaviour of this minister in handing around taxpayers' money without any trace of responsibility and without any guideline other than the maximum and at all times the total political convenience of the Australian Labor Party.

PARA.TAB: In those circumstances one may have thought that today it would have been possible for this incompetent, dishonest minister to be dragged before the bar of this parliament and questioned. One would have imagined that it would have been possible for us to ask the minister to explain how it was that she implicated the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) yesterday. She might have been able to explain to us why it was she misled the parliament for the third occasion yesterday. She may have been brought before this parliament to be further questioned by my colleague the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) about her stewardship of $30 million—not of her money, not of Labor Party money, but of the money of the taxpayers of Australia.

This morning, believing the importance of the occasion demanded the attendance of the minister, I wrote to the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley). In the letter, which I will table, I said to the Leader of the House that it was clear from the ongoing public concern about the performance of the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories that she should attend question time today in order to answer questions about her stewardship of our money—not about the Labor Party's political convenience but about what she did with the money of the Australian people. I got this unbelievable response:

SPEECH.PARA: Thank you for your letter dated yesterday—
which of course it was not; that is just a minor technical detail, we do not worry about that—

While you are at least consistent in the point you make I remind you that on several occasions yesterday I informed the House that the Government would persist with its roster system under the terms and conditions announced last week by the Prime Minister.

I might interpolate there that this is a roster that has been rigged to protect an incompetent and stupid minister. This roster has got nothing to do with the accountability of ministers before this parliament. Mr Speaker, if you think for a moment that this roster has not been designed to suit the political convenience of the government, I will read the text of a message I got from a senior officer in the department of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean):
Crean has asked his department for 3 to 4 proactive "cute" (his word) questions on the days on which he will appear before the House (Monday and Tuesday)

This is a message from a senior officer. That is the measure of the contempt that this crowd opposite has for this institution of parliament. They do not care about accountability. If the accountability of a minister before parliament means anything, that minister should have been in here this morning to answer that censure from the honourable member for Higgins. That is where she belonged. She was in the building. For heaven's sake, she voted in the motion, but she was not here to answer it, any more than she has appeared on any of the major news programs to be interviewed about her handling of her responsibilities.

PARA.TAB: She is a discredited, politically corrupt and politically dishonest minister. She is a minister who ought to be dragged, screaming if necessary, before this parliament to be made accountable for the way in which she has abused the trust placed in her by the representatives of the people—because that is what she has done. Our complaint is very simple and very fundamental. That complaint is that all of the arrangements that have been embraced by the Leader of the House and the Prime Minister over the last few weeks have been designed to rig parliament to protect weak, stupid, incompetent ministers from accountability before this parliament. That has been the design and it has been put together by a very arrogant Prime Minister, aided and abetted by a very arrogant Leader of the House.

This Leader of the House knows darn well that, if this parliament is to mean anything when a minister is really on the rack, that minister ought to be in here answering questions. If we had gone around all the press this morning, we would have seen time and time again columns and news reports suggesting that the minister was swinging by a thread, that the minister's political career was very much on the line. What do we find when we come here this morning? We find a Leader of the House who is absolutely unwilling to require this minister to come and answer questions.

It is not a question of whether she is going to be here tomorrow. When we have widespread public concern and when we have allegations that she has misled the parliament, she ought to be in here today—not tomorrow, not next week and not yesterday. That is the request that we made to the Leader of the House. That he knocked that request back with the normal arrogance and contempt that he displays towards the opposition, mirroring the contempt that his leader displays towards the opposition and the rest of the Australian community, only serves to underscore the fact that all of these arrangements have been designed to protect the incompetent from the scrutiny of parliament.

That is what the new roster is all about. The new arrangements are all about protecting ministerial failures like the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. The only reason that she is hanging in there by a thread is her close factional friendship with the Prime Minister. Everybody up in the press gallery and all of those opposite know that she is hanging in there. Half a dozen members opposite have told a few of us that that is exactly how they feel. They know that she is dead meat in political terms, she is dead meat ministerially, and that all that remains is for the carcass to be cut down.
Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, we are not allowed to use that language! I see. Those opposite find that offensive. I do not think the Australian public regard it as offensive to use the language that I have used about her because she has run away with their money in political terms. That is what she has done. She has handed it out like confetti as though it came out of her piggy bank instead of out of the Treasury of Australia. That is why she ought to be in here answering questions. That is why this issue will dog and haunt those opposite until she is cut down and thrown off the treasury bench of this country. If you, Mr Speaker, and any of those sitting on the right of you imagine for a moment that she is going to be able to escape the censure of this parliament over the days and weeks to follow if she continues, then you have made a very sorry mistake.

PARA.TAB: You would have done yourself a very great service if you had brought her in this morning and then voted with us in the censure motion because, sooner or later, you will have to dump her. The sooner you dump her, the less pain you will suffer. If she cared for the future of the party that has given her everything, she would have been gone by now instead of hanging on in such an indecently contemptuous fashion as she undoubtedly has.

TALK.START.PARA: —The right honourable member for New England to second the motion.

PARA.TAB: Government members—The old team.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my right! The right honourable member for New England.

—The stench of Kellygate hangs over the government. All one can say is that Australia Inc. is about to replace WA Inc. The nature and character of everything that has been done by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) in the administration of this cultural affairs rort, the sporting allocations that were not made according to the premises laid down in legislation, are such that the minister must be here to answer the charge.

PARA.TAB: If you thought that her absence was for any reason other than the willingness of the government to hide behind the procedures of this place, all you need to do is look at the fact that the minister has not appeared in this House at any time other than to vote—not against a motion of censure but against the suspension of standing orders this morning. We need to understand that the minister appeared not to answer a condemnation, properly moved, of matters newly arisen, but arose only to stop the motion from being debated.
We have no choice but to move this motion. This whole concept of government trying to hide behind changed standing orders—
Government members interjecting—

—I can see from your colleagues, my friend. Your problem is that you have a minister who is following exactly the track of Brian Burke, a minister who is following exactly the track of every one of those corrupt Labor governments that have fallen on their own sword. Your trouble is that you are not prepared to expose her to the proper scrutiny of this parliament.

PARA.TAB: Even this afternoon we have had in the other place a major announcement about a judicial inquiry. The change to these standing orders is such that there has not been one word in this House about a fundamental matter affecting national security. You talk about nature and character; you do not make policy statements in answer to questions. The way this government is going, Mr Speaker, you would think standing orders did not matter. We on this side of the House can see that the government is hiding behind a panoply which is designed to shield all those who are incompetent from proper scrutiny.

Take today. This morning the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) sent a letter to the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) asking whether it would be possible for the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories to appear in the House. He got that perfunctory reply that has just been read to the House. There is no reason why the minister should not appear in circumstances in which the interests not of government money but of the taxpayers' money is at question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well you might ask. You have already had your finger in the till. You are one of those people who are to blame because the public purse has been squandered.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

—I talk to farmers. Farmers are walking off the land because there is no earthly chance of your treating them fairly. When you talk, my friend, you ought to look at your own very blemished record. There is no doubt that within the Labor Party there has been a tendency to usurp the powers of office, to abuse the responsibilities of office and to abuse the requirements of legislation. We have a minister at the table who today does not know whether or not he, as Minister for Finance, is responsible for determining whether the legislative requirements of grants are met.

PARA.TAB: In every program of any department, my friend, there is a requirement, not that you be Auditor-General but that you ensure that programs are complied with. Within your own department there are questions about the administration of the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I can assure you that, if you had been a minister in our day, you would have known about it.

The whole crux of this motion is that there should be an opportunity for everybody to recognise that the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories is an embarrassment to everybody. The minister for sports rorts should go. The minister for sports rorts is a disgrace to the ministry, a disgrace to Australia. She is politically corrupt, she is a political embarrassment and has no right any longer to exercise or hold the rights of a minister in any government of Australia. These standing orders must be changed to allow her appearance in this place so that she can properly respond to any matters that should be within her bailiwick. There is no basis for her not appearing here this afternoon.

TALK.START.PARA: —When you are going to sling mud in this place, you have to put up your cleanskins to do it; you cannot put up the two whom you have just put up. Being lectured by the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) on the subject of parliamentary proprieties and proprieties in relation to whether or not executives are going to be—

PARA.TAB: Mr Sinclair interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You have had good reason to. I will concede that point straightaway. We do not have to debate that one any more. The last piece of advice you gave anyone on this particular subject was to give detailed reasons in writing only as to why you would not appear before parliamentary committees as a minister when the committee called you to do so. At least the person you describe as gutless and corrupt had the guts to go before a committee for hours and hours and be asked 300 or 400 questions, while you hid in a coward's castle at the time you had to do it.

PARA.TAB: Then we had the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) getting up. I at least have enough of a memory to know day after day when he was in this place receiving telephone books full of evasion, massive evasion of tax in his department when he was administering it. Did he get up and describe himself as a carcass twisting in the wind that ought to have been severed in order to give the government of the day a go—if he had been prepared to operate as a carcass twisting in the wind—after he presided over the massive devastation of the taxation system? For all you might think about this particular program, it does not even begin to compare in its impact on the public purse or the situation of the ordinary taxpayers of this nation.

The honourable member for Bennelong rocks into this place with all the guts of a bear. He stands up here and hopes that none of us remember 11 years ago when he was standing in here as a carcass, being protected by his Prime Minister of the day, presiding over the massive rorting of the taxation system. The mere fact that the ordinary PAYE taxpayer had to carry the day for all the Liberal Party financial rorters was neither here nor there. This is not a problem that we need to worry about! You were a carcass twisting slowly in the wind and the Australian public severed you at the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you have been a carcass twisting slowly in the wind on one or two occasions, too, and you were rightly severed. Then you come in here and say that the whole reason for these arrangements for rotational questioning of ministers was to protect, in your words, weak and incompetent ministers. I seem to remember when I was debating this two days ago that this was to protect the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) from questions. That was the explanation on Monday. PARA.TAB: But the Prime Minister took the view that, in fact, there ought to be an opportunity for some degree of accountability for the whole government and that he would absent himself on at least two of those days in order to provide you with an opportunity to ask a few other people questions. Opposition members interjecting—

PARA.TAB: The other part of the confected indignation of the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong, was that, somehow or other—I think this must be the implication of what he is saying because he wants to censure me for it—something has happened this week that was not put quite clearly at the time when the roster was first announced by the Prime Minister and subsequently discussed in the parliament.
