INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The manipulation of the question time roster to protect incompetent ministers.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker—

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Beazley) agreed to:
That the business of the day be called on.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, I present the report of the committee entitled The National Crime Authority and James McCartney Anderson.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I draw attention to the fact that my colleague the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) also wishes to make a statement on this matter. This report is the result of an inquiry by the committee as constituted in the previous parliament. Although now its chairman, I was not then a member of that committee so I did not hear or anticipate any evidence which forms the bulk of the report.

PARA.TAB: The report concerns a matter of great importance, not just to the National Crime Authority but to law enforcement bodies throughout Australia, be they state or federal police bodies. It involves the use of what are commonly known as criminal informers and, in this case, a particular criminal—James McCartney Anderson. There is no doubt whatsoever that, without the use of informers, law enforcement and the detection and conviction of major criminal activities would be severely diminished. Indeed, over a number of years there has been no question that many major criminals have been detected and put behind bars simply because those in the criminal field have acted as informers for a variety of reasons and assisted in the process.

There is no doubt that James McCartney Anderson is a person who one could not say a nice word about. He is a person of low repute, criminality and with very dubious antecedents to say the least. Nevertheless, there is no doubt that McCartney Anderson was of use in the circumstances of his involvement with the National Crime Authority.

I think all honourable members of this House and, indeed, the public need to be kept aware of the fact that any person who has been involved in law enforcement understands fully that those who wear the uniform deal with those who are quite often the scum of the earth. In that sense, they quite often have to literally go into the gutters to mix with these people in order to get the information that we in this House want which produces the results we want. My colleague from Western Australia, who is also a former member of the Western Australian police force, understands fully what I am talking about.

Whilst honourable members of this House may sometimes wonder at the use of informers and wonder why police and the NCA associate with people like McCartney Anderson, nevertheless they are important. This House and, I believe, this report recognises that fact. I urge all honourable members to read it. It could also be called the novel about the story of McCartney Anderson. It is perhaps a bit larger than I, the current chairman, might have wished it to be. Nevertheless, in my view, it is an important report and one which I urge all honourable members to read.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I thank the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport (Mr O'Keefe), who I acknowledge was a member of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority at the time of the production of this report. Following comments from the present chairman of the committee on the report entitled The National Crime Authority and James McCartney Anderson that has been tabled this afternoon, I, as a former police officer in the Western Australian force, also concede quite readily that informers are a very important part of police work and have been ever since the formation of modern policing techniques. I for one would never want to contemplate a law enforcement or justice system where informers were not a part of it.

PARA.TAB: The important thing about the report and the inquiry that led to this report is the peculiar relationship between James McCartney Anderson and the National Crime Authority at the time, the development of that relationship, the sort of milieu in which it took place, aspects of McCartney Anderson's background and, in particular, the unsolved mystery of the disappearance of Juanita Nielsen in Kings Cross on 4 July 1975, which Anderson was suspected of being involved in. Certainly it is a matter that ought to have been considered much more thoroughly by the National Crime Authority when it considered entering into a relationship with—as the present chairman of the committee, the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland), has quite rightly pointed out—a person of virtually no credibility, a person who is a readily self-admitted criminal and a person who has been involved in notorious activities in Kings Cross for, I believe, as long as he has been in Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —As long as Saffron.

—Not quite as long as Saffron. He has certainly been involved in the underworld. I suppose that in the years when corruption was more rife in that part of Sydney he was involved in the upper world of the Kings Cross nightclubs, drug trafficking and standover methods. In those days, all those sorts of things went on—they probably still do to a certain extent—in Kings Cross in full view of the police. To a certain extent, Anderson's antecedents, as we in the police force like to call them, should have alarmed the National Crime Authority when it decided to enter into a relationship with Mr Anderson.

PARA.TAB: I, too, recommend that honourable members read the report. To use a cliche, it is a darned good read. It gives a very good insight into that period of New South Wales's social as well as criminal history. It particularly explores the mystery that surrounds the disappearance of Juanita Nielsen in 1975.

As some would know from their knowledge of that period, Ms Nielsen was an heiress who ran a newspaper in Kings Cross. She campaigned during a period when there was a fair amount of redevelopment in the area. I suppose that she started coming up against the people who were anxious to reap the rewards of development in the area. At that stage—I suppose at the peak of that difference or opposition—she disappeared. The last place she was seen was the Carousel nightclub in Kings Cross on 4 July 1975, where she was alleged to have gone to discuss advertising in her newspaper with an employee of the nightclub.

It is interesting that in 1983 the jury in the inquest which looked into the Juanita Nielsen disappearance found that it was not able to say how, when or where Nielsen died. It added this sensational rider to its findings:

SPEECH.PARA: There is evidence to show that the police inquiries were inhibited by an atmosphere of corruption, real or imagined, that existed at the time.

Over a long period we conducted a thorough inquiry. We were assisted to that end by the services of John Basten QC who acted as counsel to the committee during that inquiry. I would like to personally thank Mr Basten for the assistance he gave me as a member—and of course to the committee as a whole—in dealing with the enormous amount of material that was available and that was used as part of the background to our inquiry and also during our hearings at which there were a number of witnesses. A total of 20 witnesses appeared. They were drawn from amongst those who worked at the authority from 1984 to 1988, but they included eight persons who had never worked at the authority. As is mentioned in the report, Mr Anderson himself appeared before the committee.

PARA.TAB: A number of conclusions were reached by the committee following the hearings and assessment of that information. I must point out that in the first instance the committee concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee did not find that any breach of any statute had occurred in the Authority's dealings with Anderson—
I think it is important to point that out—

However, the committee did not consider that its sole criterion of assessment ought to be whether a statute had been breached. The Committee also asked whether the Authority had acted in accord with the dictates of sound management and administration.
We found:

The Authority did not conduct any formal assessment of whether it should use Anderson as an informer or witness before entering into its relationship with him. The Committee considers that such an assessment should have been made.
The conclusions went on to state:

The Committee considers that this assessment would have shown that using Anderson in the way that the Authority did was clearly a very marginal proposition. In the Committee's view, the assessment would have noted the de facto immunity Anderson would gain from his relationship with the Authority in respect of his past criminal activity; the real possibility that he was engaged in criminal activity in late 1984; his suspect motivation; his questionable credibility; and the lack of a compelling need to use him as a source of information and evidence on Saffron.
Mr Abe Saffron was target No. 1. Another conclusion stated:
The Committee was told in November 1992 by the current Authority that, under procedures now in place, it would not commence the relationship with Anderson in the way that its predecessor did in 1984.
The committee also found:

Anderson used his relationship with the Authority to try to blackmail Saffron. Anderson claimed Saffron owed him a large sum of money . . . The Committee considers that the Authority's failure to respond—
that is, to allegations surrounding that—
was totally unacceptable. It should have terminated its relationship with Anderson immediately it found out what he was doing.
The committee also found:

Both the Authority and Anderson obtained only limited benefits from their relationship . . . Anderson provided the Authority with information of very variable quality in relation to other aspects of its Saffron investigations . . . The logic of his position as a Crown witness, however, ensured that he would not be prosecuted along with Saffron for his part in the conspiracy to defraud the Commonwealth of tax due.
It also commented in those findings:

Anderson may have obtained some de facto immunity from investigation and prosecution for other alleged offences. If this happened, it would have been because of two factors. First, it was not in the Authority's interest to investigate Anderson while he was providing information and evidence to it. Secondly, there are tacit understandings among police that one officer does not interfere with another's informer, unless a serious offence is involved.
In that relationship, Anderson in fact travelled and lived overseas at the expense of the authority. The committee concluded:

The Committee does not consider that the Authority should have assisted Anderson to travel and live overseas. If Anderson insisted on living overseas for security reasons, the Authority should have done without his assistance.
The committee also considered that the payment to Anderson of a sum of $US12,000 was not justified on the termination of the witness protection arrangement in November 1988. The report stated:

PARA.TAB: The committee considers that the above criticisms of the Authority should be read in the light of three modifying factors. First, when the relationship was entered into the Authority had just been established, and some allowance has to be made for this fact. Secondly, the Committee recognises that Authority staff dealt with Anderson in the way they did as the result of judgments they made in good faith about what was most appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: The third aspect of that is the context in which the relationship had occurred. We pointed out:
In the early 1980s, there was an emphasis on the benefits of using informers as a means of tackling organised crime, and the negative aspects were not given equal emphasis.
We concluded by stating:
The Committee believes that law enforcement agencies are now far more cautious in dealing with informers. The Authority's 1992 informant management procedures are one indication of this.

Members of the joint standing committee have, as part of their duties, an obligation to oversee the activities of the National Crime Authority. This particular reference was given to the committee on 28 November 1990 following a resolution of the Senate.

PARA.TAB: The report is a good way of assessing the peculiar environment, atmosphere and circumstances in the early part of the 1980s as the evolution of the National Crime Authority commenced. The authority's reference No. 1 was granted to it on 19 October 1984. Following that, on 20 December of that year, Anderson was first interviewed by authority lawyers and investigators. Perhaps far more trouble ought to have been taken in looking at Mr Anderson's antecedents, examining in particular the disappearance of Juanita Nielsen and the allegations surrounding Anderson in relation to that disappearance and the other aspects of Anderson's criminality and his activities or behaviour that should have alerted the National Crime Authority at least to have very severe reservations about the use of Anderson as an informant.

I mentioned at the outset that I agree with the current chairman that informants are a very valuable part of the police system as well as the justice system. I think that under the circumstances which prevailed during that period, perhaps there was a lack of clear managerial control over the use of Anderson. Because of the evolution of the authority, its particular structure at the time and the way in which the operations were conducted within the authority, perhaps there was some detachment at the top from the area which was actually at the coalface or dealing with people like Anderson. Under those circumstances, I think it was quite right of the committee to have examined this particular relationship with a view to looking at that particular aspect of Anderson's background and his involvement in the 1975 disappearance of Juanita Nielsen, a matter, I might add, that is still unsolved.

I would also like to acknowledge the assistance given to the committee by Steve Curran, the acting secretary of the committee. He spent a lot of time assisting with material compilation for this particular report. The report has taken a long time to get through and eventually be tabled. I could make some comments about that, but I will not. The fact that all of that information is included in the report is of benefit to honourable members who want to inform themselves of this particular period in the history of the NCA and also want to look at the circumstances surrounding that evolvement of the relationship between the National Crime Authority and James McCartney Anderson.

I would like to point out that the inquiry was triggered, to a certain extent, by some articles that appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald written by Peter Rees and Arthur King. Those two gentlemen visited the authority in 1986 to put to it their concerns about Nielsen's disappearance. Their dedication in trying to find out the facts behind the Nielsen disappearance is to be commended.

I thank the House for giving me the opportunity to make these comments under the circumstances. May I also acknowledge the former chairman of the committee, the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay). I think that he did well in chairing the numbers of hearings and discussions that we had. I would also acknowledge Senator Crichton-Browne, who was the mover of the original motion in the Senate which gave rise to the reference to the committee, and also other members of the committee who participated in the long hearings during that period.

I think the report is a darn good read. I recommend it to honourable members. It still leaves unresolved one of the great criminal mysteries of the 1970s. It is incredible that, considering the time, the circumstances and the peculiar atmosphere of corruption and crime that existed in Kings Cross in those days, it is a mystery that still merits investigation by some agency to ensure that the person or persons responsible for the disappearance of Nielsen are at some time brought to justice. It seems incredible to me that, with all the resources at the disposal of the New South Wales police and, following that, the National Crime Authority, we are apparently no closer to solving that particular mystery than the people who comprised the jury of the 1983 Nielsen inquest.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my concluding remarks yesterday, I made reference to the community housing sector and the aims and objectives of the government for its development and expansion. We intend to double the size of the community housing sector to at least 25,000 units of housing stock by the turn of the century. We view this sector as being well placed to meet the housing needs of low income earners and those with special needs in the community. For this sector to fully develop its potential in this regard and to achieve the growth necessary to meet these above needs, greater effort needs to be undertaken in the training of voluntary managers in the sector and in financial planning that will underpin its long-term growth.

PARA.TAB: One great advantage of community housing is its flexibility in meeting the local housing needs of special groups in the community. It has the capacity to link effectively with support services needed by many in the community. For example, throughout 1993-94 the program will build upon initiatives already developed in the provision of housing for persons with physical and mental disabilities and other measures to assist those persons in their transition from institutional to other forms of care.

The government also believes this program can provide more services to clients who leave supported accommodation. Therefore, the government has asked the states to allocate at least 10 per cent of the community housing program to the provision of housing for people with specific housing and support needs. The government has made a financial commitment to the community housing sector and its expansion in the strong belief that this sector can play an important role in meeting the special housing needs of many in our community.

I would like to take up a few points made in this House by the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan). She huffed and puffed about the fact that the government had not engaged in extensive consultations with the opposition on the amendments proposed to the Housing Assistance Amendment Bill. She made several points which were quite outrageous, considering she is the spokesperson on the opposite side of this House.

She had the hide to criticise the government for not making some headway in reforming the public housing area. Obviously, she has not read the Industry Commission report. It said two interesting things: one was in a general sense and the other was in a more specific sense. In a general sense, it endorsed the notion of public housing as a cost-effective way of meeting the housing needs of low and middle income earners in Australia. In effect, the government, through its budgetary allocations and the priorities it has set in this area, believes, as the IC does, that public housing is a most cost-effective way of meeting the housing needs of many Australians.

That view is not shared by the opposition. In Fightback the coalition, in its so-called wisdom in this particular policy area, sought to emasculate the housing expenditure of the Commonwealth by some $450 million. One does not have to be an Einstein or an intellectual giant to appreciate the impact that would have on the ground in the states and in local communities throughout the length and breadth of Australia. It would simply mean that the state housing authorities would not be able to increase the public housing stock nor maintain it. They would have to off-load it, which would simply mean in the long term that many Australians who rely on the provision of public housing to meet this basic human need would not have access to either affordable or appropriate housing.

At the micro level, we agree with some of the comments made in the past about the state housing authorities. They were developed in the 1950s and they are centralised in quite bureaucratic structures. They have not been as responsive as they could have been to the needs of people in regional communities. The IC conceded that, over the term of Labor governments, both at the state and federal level, we have made giant progress in making these housing authorities even more responsive to the needs of constituents. We have seen significant improvements in the management and delivery of public housing in the states. So it is a bit of a furphy for the honourable member for Moncrieff to come into this House and level criticisms at this government for not undertaking reforms in public housing. The financing of public housing is central to Labor's belief that federal governments have a role to play in the provision of affordable and appropriate housing for Australians who are not able to meet their housing needs in the private market.

I have ranged across many issues in my speech. My colleague the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Quick), who sits to my right, will certainly be taking up some other issues with regard to the Housing Assistance Amendment Bill. So I conclude my remarks at that point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Housing Assistance Amendment Bill, I do not want to refer so much to that which members of parliament or politicians have in connection with the whole aspect of housing throughout Australia. I wish to refer to what is on the public record by way of audit reports, Human Rights Commission reports and Industry Commission reports. It indicates a degree of criticism which is valid in many ways.

PARA.TAB: In audit report No. 6, the Auditor-General talked about Commonwealth-state agreements. Quite a few comments indicate that there is a lack of definition and clarity with respect to the guidelines of these agreements which makes it difficult to determine how these programs will operate and how the funds will be used.

With respect to the timing and method of payments, the Auditor-General indicated that, by adopting such practices, it was estimated that about $50 million could be saved annually on the $1 billion paid to the states under the agreement. There seems to be considerable scope for improvement in this area, as the Auditor-General's survey of specific purpose payments indicates that payments were made monthly in less than 20 per cent of the cases.

When talking about specific purpose payments it is interesting to note that the Auditor-General found that the Commonwealth needed to be more involved. Obviously, the dollar for dollar arrangements for these specific purpose programs would be the responsibility of the Department of Finance. We have been talking lately about the sports grants given by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly). There was a need for a dollar for dollar arrangement to exist with some of those sporting clubs and cultural bodies, yet that dollar for dollar arrangement was not supervised by the Department of Finance, as the minister indicated in question time. The Auditor-General indicates that there should be an awareness by the Department of Finance in this regard.

We then realise that over many years the Commonwealth has subverted the states' responsibilities in regard to specific purpose grants and so on. Richard Court, the Premier of Western Australia, will be putting the proposition to the other premiers that over a period of time the states' sovereign rights have been undermined in many ways. These agreements are just one of the ways that has been done. I look forward to his presentation of that argument when the state premiers next meet with the Commonwealth because I believe it is a real issue.

I will now turn to the subject of the Industry Commission report which has been floated in this debate. The criticisms that are levelled at that draft report, as recently as October 1993, suggest to me that the Commonwealth's desire to take over the whole operation of the housing industry, even though it is supposed to be a dollar for dollar arrangement with the states, has led to much concern in the community. In my area there is a very active group called the Mackay Tenants Group. This group met with two of the commissioners in Mackay to discuss the draft report and they were far from satisfied with the responses they obtained. The response the group received from the commissioners was, `We are here to hold these hearings. But it does not really matter what you say. We are going to continue on the way that we were going'.

While it was agreed that there were some valid and interesting points made, there did not seem to be any reassurance that there would be any changes. The Mackay Tenants Group said that its concerns included the security of tenure, rent setting, allocations and departmental splitting. They believe department splitting would mean that people would be accountable to many other areas and this would increase the inefficiency that might already be prevalent. A newspaper article in Mackay quotes the leader of the group as having said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the security of tenure proposed by the commission would only guarantee tenure in an area and not in a particular house. It would also tie young couples to two to five year leases.
The article went on to say:
. . . the commission wanted to turn the Department of Housing and Local Government into a huge property developer/manager and extend the Family Services Department to include tenant management.

PARA.TAB: "This would see too much control of one person's life in the hands of one government agency."

SPEECH.PARA: The article continued:

. . . the Mackay Tenants Group opposed changes to the allocation of public housing because it felt the new system would be open to abuse and manipulation unless strict guidelines and boundaries were put into place. She doubted the commissioners would reassess the issue . . .

As is common in many public inquiries, the impression is given, rightly or wrongly, that in draft reports commissions go out to justify what they have in place and do nothing further with it. The group was concerned about the altered relationship that would exist if the Commonwealth intervened and changed the existing arrangement.

PARA.TAB: I will now deal with the bill which is before the House. The government sees this as a long-term financial commitment to the provision of public housing funding, and the provision of new Commonwealth housing programs and continued support for the crisis accommodation program. The government states that the actual diminution in the funds available over the next three years is a result of the underspending by some states. But it still says that the crisis accommodation program has a very high priority and that this bill actually justifies the underspending of capped funds by the states.

If it is the case that some states have been underspending in this program it is certainly not borne out by the actual situation that exists within the community, particularly in relation to crisis accommodation. I will deal later with two specific areas: ATSIC and the South Sea Islanders' situation. There is an accommodation crisis in the community. This crisis can be affected by the Commonwealth and states getting together to provide extra funds in certain building categories. It distresses me to realise that some of the states have been underspending in this regard. This leads me to ask the question: are the states fair dinkum about this whole agreement and providing funds where they are most needed?

The evidence of the need for accommodation within the community is there for all to see, particularly in time of recession. People were trying to fight against high interest rates which dispossessed many of the type of accommodation they had or were seeking to have and limited the availability of other types of accommodation. Even though I am a federal member, some of the greatest complaints I have, and some of the most prevalent representations I have to make, are in connection with the state housing authority and the provision of crisis and rented accommodation

SPEECH.PARA: to people who have a desperate need but who have been on waiting lists sometimes for as long as two years.

PARA.TAB: I will now talk about the funds being made available to ATSIC through its housing cooperatives, as they are known in many places, and the ineffectiveness of some of those cooperatives. Again I can speak only about my local area. I believe there is a growing concern within the community—and it is not racist in any form whatsoever—about the funds being allocated for specific programs. It would appear to some people that the funds are not appropriately applied to provide for the need that exists in the society. I believe people are not so concerned about the extent of the expenditure but how appropriately it is being used.

Again I refer to the $30 million which has just been allocated under the community cultural and sports program. People in the community are concerned that if they are going to pay this money—and they are taxpayers' funds after all—they want to see it spent in the areas of need, not in the areas of want. I believe this is a very appropriate concern.

I could probably make a judgment in connection with the ATSIC arrangements for housing for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders by what happens within my own electorate. This has been a continuing source of annoyance for about 10 years, particularly within the coloured community in Mackay. It appears that to be a member of the Mackay Coloured Co-operative Housing Society a person has to adhere to certain man-made rules and not adhere to the rules of the association itself.

About four years ago, I raised with Mr Hand, the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the concerns that existed in relation to this matter. I had a need to raise those concerns again with the current Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner). In connection with these complaints, I wrote to both the minister and the ATSIC commissioners. I had not received a response so I was forced to put the questions on the Notice Paper. Again, these questions have not been adequately responded to.

What has happened in the past is that the control of the Mackay Coloured Co-operative Housing Society has rested with or been vested in one family. That family basically determines what the membership is. They determine who comes to the meetings and they also determine how membership expulsions or withdrawals are occasioned.

We had a particular situation last year at the annual meeting where people were put in front of the door to stop certain people who wanted entry, because the secretary had said that they were no longer members. I drew the minister's attention to the fact that there have been membership expulsions and that there were irregularities of conduct. These matters have been reported to the cooperative housing society registrar in Queensland. All of these matters have not yet been satisfactorily resolved.

I raise this issue not only as a matter of a complaint that has not been addressed either by the minister or by ATSIC itself but also to state the fact that the money being allocated for housing is not getting through to those people in need. If we debar those people of South Sea Islander descent because they are not indigenous people, we disfranchise a lot of people. It is a major concern if we disfranchise, say, 50 per cent of those eligible people from either getting rental assistance or being able to acquire their own home. I raise this matter not as a result of any politicking in this area but because of the real concerns within society that money is not finding its way through to the proper area.

I will deal with the other area I mentioned: the people in the South Sea Islander community. Mackay has about 25 per cent of Australia's total population of South Sea Islanders. It is a large community. They are a well respected group, but they are a much disadvantaged group. I will read from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report entitled The call for recognition because it relates to this matter and I believe it is very important that we put it into perspective. Paragraph 5.2.1 deals with housing ownership, and states:

SPEECH.PARA: Home ownership is a good indicator of people's wealth; indeed, most of Australia's wealth is in the form of dwellings.
I believe that the great Australian dream is to be a home owner. The report continues:

South Sea Islanders' home ownership rates are lower than any other racial group in Australia, with the possible exception of Aboriginal people. Less than one-third of South Sea Islander households owned or were buying their house, with only one in seven being full owners. Another one-third of households were public tenants; the rest were mainly private tenants.

I believe that the aspect of the low housing ownership, as far as Aborigines are concerned, can be addressed if we appropriate the funds and use them as they should be used. The report goes on to say:

South Sea Islanders' home ownership (owning or buying) rate is less than half the Australian average—30.8% of South Sea Islander households were owners or buyers in 1992, compared with an average of 68.3% for Australia in 1986. Moreover, South Sea Islanders are not buying their homes at the same rate as other people. Only 16% are buying their home, compared with 31% nationally.
Overall, South Sea Islanders' home ownership rate in 1992 is lower than every sizeable migrant community in 1986.
I want that fact impressed on the minds of honourable members because the South Sea Islanders have been part of our migrant population since the 1860s and 1870s. The report goes on:

Even the newly arrived Vietnamese, Pacific Islander and Chilean communities had higher home ownership levels because more were buying. Ownership is an indicator of community wealth for these ethnic groups—either they have good jobs that enable them to get a home loan, or others in their group are able to lend them funds. After more than a century of Australian residency, South Sea Islanders have not achieved the levels of home ownership these immigrants achieved in a decade.
In fact the South Sea Islanders have been described as being the second less fortunate group in Australia. The report goes on:
South Sea Islander home ownership is between the levels of rural and city Aboriginal people in 1986.

For South Sea Islander home owners, the average cost of housing is $57 per week, but about half of these fully own their home. For those paying the mortgage, the average is $480 a month. The `rule of thumb' for bank housing loans is that the monthly mortgage should not exceed the weekly income; it is noteworthy that only one in seven South Sea Islanders earns $480 a week or more, and one in seven is a purchaser.

I could go on to speak in terms of the difficulties that members of this group have in education, in maintaining their traditional style of life, in health, and also in their job opportunities. In fact, I believe that their job opportunities would rate with those of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, who have a particular program to look after them. But there is no assistance available to the South Sea Islanders. To expect that these people should then have to get in a queue to get the crisis accommodation, or any other state-Commonwealth housing agreement, does not recognise the fact that all those other migrant groups can get in there beforehand and leave these people disadvantaged.

PARA.TAB: This report was made available on 15 December 1992. It has been in the hands of the Attorney-General now for over 12 months. One of the problems that I find in this House is that we get a report on this and a report on that, or a committee looking at this or a committee looking at that, and when the report is finalised nothing ever actually happens.

The South Sea Islanders are a proud race and have waited a hundred years for some type of recognition and some type of equality. I believe it behoves the state and the federal governments to move in connection with the problems that I see and to realise that this bill before us is a result of underspending by states on crisis accommodation programs. That situation is ludicrous, ridiculous and inequitable and I believe that something should be done in that regard.

There is also a growing problem in housing as far as our aged people are concerned. I will not speak about the whole ambit of housing, but only on those areas in connection with the requirements of an ageing population. Two reports have indicated that, by the year 2031, 20 per cent of the population will be in the aged category. A crisis is already developing and this will be extenuated by the fact that not enough hostel and nursing home accommodation is being provided by the Commonwealth, even though it monopolises the area.

I will give one incident. A nursing home body that was formed in my electorate at Airlie Beach went to the department, worked with the department, provided plans, had the land allocated by the local government and was told it was going to get an allocation in the last priorities. This was not forthcoming. The allocation of beds was made not to the charity or the community group that was expecting some Commonwealth capital funding in this regard but to two private enterprise organisations. The funding was going to be provided to and controlled by them. I believe that the amounts of allocations are not good enough nor is the continual pushing of the community and church groups out of the way. I have always found them to provide excellent service and a better service than the private sector. (Time expired).

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak on the issue of housing and, in particular, the Housing Assistance Amendment Bill 1993. I regard this as an issue of great importance throughout Australia, in Tasmania and, more particularly, in the Franklin electorate that I represent. Unlike many other areas in Australia, the Tasmanian community not only requires housing that is secure, appropriate and affordable but also housing that is designed to cater for the wide-ranging seasonal climatic variations experienced in our southern state.

PARA.TAB: The Housing Assistance Amendment Bill is integral to the provision of housing, particularly for low income earners. My primary electorate office is located in a large, broadacre public housing area which encompasses the suburbs of Bridgewater and Gagebrook. Across the eastern side of the electorate of Franklin there are five other major public housing areas—Ridson Vale, Warrane, Mornington, Rokeby and Clarendon Vale—and many other smaller public housing areas are scattered right across the electorate. It, therefore, should be very easy for honourable members to understand my interest in housing and, in addition, my intimate knowledge of the types of housing concerns which pass through my office daily.

In this debate I intend to focus on the issues of public housing, funding for the provision of community housing, the supported accommodation assistance program and continued support for the crisis accommodation program. However, within that context, I will continually draw the attention of this House to the local situation in Tasmania and the types of reforms that are occurring there and in my electorate of Franklin. I make it quite clear that I do not believe, when talking on the topic of housing, that this significant issue can be in any way removed from other issues such as income, education, health and other community services. All of these issues are so closely intertwined that to attempt to discuss any of them in isolation is difficult and perhaps futile.

In discussing this bill, I will attempt to restrict my speech to housing, but I hope that honourable members in this place will understand the significance and implications which underlie the issue of housing. The Commonwealth-state housing agreement, CSHA, has been and continues to be the facility by which housing has been provided to so many Australians over a significant period. The Housing Assistance Amendment Bill seeks to revise the Housing Assistance Act 1989 and, by implication, affects the Commonwealth-state housing agreement which forms schedule 1 of the act.

The bill is extremely significant in terms of funding, representing $1,042.39 million. The 1989 act allows for unpaid Commonwealth funds to be carried forward. So $82.3 million will be carried forward, making available under the CSHA in 1993-94 a total of $1.125 billion. In the same way that the building better cities program looks to the type of Australia that we want in the future, so too does this bill. The bill encompasses the needs of home buyers, public rental housing tenants and renters in the private rental market up to the turn of the century.

It is obvious that long-term planning is the key to the provision of secure, affordable and appropriate accommodation. I am very pleased that this bill guarantees funding under the Commonwealth-state housing agreement until the end of 1995-96. In addition to that guarantee, state and territory governments have agreed to specific reforms which will mean that services should be more responsive to our changing community's needs.

In my state of Tasmania, it has been of great concern to me that the state Liberal government has been underspending on the provision of housing. I am heartened that this bill incorporates a national core set of performance indicators that will mean greater accountability. I am also pleased to see a provision whereby states will not be paid Commonwealth grants more than one month prior to expenditure. It is only in this way that underspending by states can be prevented and, in addition, assist in targeting those groups most in need of financial assistance.

The mortgage rental assistance program is of particular interest to me. Unlike every other state and territory in Australia, Tasmania is unique in having a proportion of mortgage rental assistance program moneys distributed through a community based agency. I have mixed feelings about this situation and would ask members of this House to think very carefully about this type of reform occurring in their own state or territory—in particular, in their electorates. In essence, this type of reform can produce a service with less bureaucracy and with a more welcoming front to the community, but the very real danger is that the community based service is expected to provide the same degree of mortgage rental assistance program provision on a greatly reduced budget to that which would be provided to a state department.

The Housing Assistance Service, situated in Elizabeth Street, North Hobart, is a community based agency that distributes mortgage rental assistance program moneys to those single people without dependants seeking assistance in moving into private rental accommodation. When money is available for distribution to those people eligible for assistance, the line-up of people is often seen trailing on to the main street outside the agency. There is no doubt in my mind that the need for assistance into private rental accommodation is huge and the stress placed on the workers at the Housing Assistance Service is corresponding to that demand. There is also no doubt in my mind that the state government is getting an extremely good deal, certainly in terms of its financial commitment, by using a community based agency like the Housing Assistance Service to distribute these mortgage rental assistance program moneys.

The crisis accommodation program is also one which all members of this House need to be familiar with and the complexities of this program need to be understood. The Human Rights Commissioner, Brian Burdekin, pointed out in his report on homelessness that the problem will not go away by simply providing more crisis accommodation. As someone who has worked in a young people's shelter, I can assure honourable members of this House that this is the case. Providing more crisis accommodation often leads to the growth of a subculture dependent on crisis accommodation and who will continue to be without the means necessary to become independent.

Crisis accommodation is an extremely important component of an overall housing strategy, but I urge all honourable members here to consider very carefully any representations that are made to them by organisations for an increase in available crisis accommodation. Most homeless people are looking for safe, secure and affordable housing, not more temporary accommodation. Some of these people may need support in their accommodation, but it would really concern me if greater emphasis was placed on shelter type housing.

As I mentioned at the beginning of my speech, housing needs are difficult to separate from other issues such as income, health, education and other community services. Every Australian has the right and should have the opportunity to be housed and to live independently. It is sometimes the case though that, for an individual, couple or family to live independently, some degree of assistance and support is required.

It is with that in mind that I am very pleased that the recent review into the supported accommodation assistance program, SAAP, found that access to capital funding is very important to changing the program whose outcomes tended to be of a `bandaid' approach to one now where people are actively assisted to achieve independence and become productive and, hopefully, happier members of our community. As I said, I am relating this to particular organisations in Tasmania.

In Tasmania, the housing young people's outreach—HYPO—program has already made very good headway for that type of outcome in SAAP. HYPO, through the efforts of its workers and that of other similar agencies, has developed a project by which purpose-built housing will be provided to young people. The two- and three-bedroom units are located in a warehouse and will be managed by a cooperative of young people, housing workers and interested people from the community. The accommodation provided by HYPO will be medium term. With the assistance of the cooperative and housing workers, these young people can now look forward to secure accommodation which will ultimately lead to a more independent and rewarding life within our community.

The community housing program is a special form of housing that has the ability to take into account the special needs of specific groups within our community and, at the same time, offer the sense of security and direct control enjoyed by home owners in a more affordable way. As with the new direction taken by SAAP, the community housing program has the capacity to link housing with support services needed by many households in our community. The program also has the capacity to take on recommendations in the recently released report Human rights and mental illness by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission so that there can be better management of various people from institutional to other forms of care.

Australians with mental illness do need more and better housing options. In Tasmania, housing agencies are dealing with increasing numbers of people with mental illness and have limited avenues to direct these people to suitable housing situations. Certainly to date, many of these people with mental illness have been housed in boarding homes and guesthouses that really do not offer the type of accommodation and support that those people so desperately require.

By asking state and territory governments to allocate at least 10 per cent of community housing program funding for the housing needs of these people with mental illness, that portion of the housing sector should grow and support the needs of those in the community who previously did not receive the support they so desperately needed.

The Housing Assistance Amendment Bill 1993 amends section 15 of the Housing Assistance Act 1989 to allow the Commonwealth minister to authorise the full level of untied grants to a particular state, even if the minister cannot ensure that the state can meet its matching obligation from the value of home loans provided through its home purchase assistance programs.

The Commonwealth minister is, and has been for some time, in the invidious position of accepting a financial position put to him on the financial capacity of a state or territory. If he was not satisfied with the financial commitment of the state or territory to the Commonwealth-state housing agreement, his only real avenue to force the hand of the state or territory was to withdraw funding. The only real victim in that scenario would be those Australians in need of housing.

There is now the occasion, and there will probably be the occasion in the future, where state and territory governments, due to fiscal incapacity, will be unable to fully meet their obligations under the Commonwealth-state housing agreement. I accept that, in the best interest of state and federal cooperation and that of those Australians who deserve the right to safe and affordable accommodation, the Commonwealth minister must at times have the legislative ability to waive or reduce a state or territory's obligation to match the balance of untied assistance in relation to these home loans. For the minister to not have the power would only hurt those people who are least able to defend themselves.

It concerns me that the priorities of the state government in Tasmania in relation to housing fall far short of where they should be. That housing in Tasmania comes after a 40 per cent pay increase to state politicians without arbitration, the payment of close to half a million dollars to cover the court costs on the Rouse-Gray bribery case and the total dismantling of the state construction work force reflects just where the state Liberal government's priorities really do lie and they continue to frustrate those in urgent need of housing.

I know it would not be appropriate for the federal government to intervene in every expenditure decision made by a state government. The point I make is that with every dollar spent as a result of a poor decision made by a state or territory government people in our community looking for housing must suffer. Every one of those high-flying decisions that usually bring a financial reward to those people who least need it has a corresponding negative impact upon those people most in need. It is that very simple message that is all too easily forgotten by too many people in positions of power. The state government in Tasmania may be assured that I will continue to monitor and challenge any dubious expenditure decision made, particularly during this period when that government is unable to meet its home lending requirement under the current arrangements of the CSHA.

This bill will allow the federal minister to waive Tasmania's matching obligations in home lending requirements and therefore allow the Commonwealth to release total funding for public housing. I know full well the demand for public housing in Tasmania and to restrict that funding would be a disaster in my home state and the electorate of Franklin in particular. I note that there is an approximately $2 million shortfall expected from Tasmania in home purchase assistance. I find some comfort in the assurance of the federal minister that he will be monitoring this situation very closely.

In speaking to this bill it would be remiss of me to not respond to the comments made yesterday afternoon by the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), who seemed to trot out the usual Liberal drivel. The honourable member for Moncrieff should be aware that the Industry Commission has acknowledged that state authorities have made significant improvements in housing. Some comments are that housing stocks are better managed, that the authorities are more client oriented and that greater attention is paid to the environs and location of public housing in relation to community facilities, but I think this is basically due to the fact that we have had over a decade of federal Labor government rule.

I am really appalled by the gross hypocrisy of the honourable member for Moncrieff in coming into this House and complaining about reforms in public housing. As the honourable member for Corio (Mr O'Connor) stated, the opposition would have more than emasculated—I think gutted would be a far better word to use—the housing program under its Fightback program. It was going to slash $450 million from the housing program.

The Industry Commission, even though it operates in an economic rationalist framework, has supported a mix of rent assistance and public housing combined with head leasing to assist low income households. This is the approach being pursued by this government. The Industry Commission not only strongly supported public housing but also gave implicit support for the provision of more public housing, a policy which is in direct contradiction to Liberal policy which favours sell-offs and a progressive reduction in public housing stock.

The issues I have discussed here this afternoon not only are extremely complex but also affect the lives of many Australians. Bearing that in mind, along with the responsibility I have in representing so many people affected by these issues, I strongly commend this bill to the House.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Order! The honourable member for Franklin used a term, in reference to the honourable member for Moncrieff, which was unparliamentary. I did not want to interrupt his speech, but the term is unparliamentary and I would ask him to withdraw that comment.

TALK.START.PARA: —It probably was remiss of me, and I withdraw that comment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is some time since I have spoken on housing in this place, but I need to get back into the debate when we hear the hypocrisy from those opposite in the way in which they present their effort in housing to the Australian people. I refer them to the document One Nation, published in 1992 at the height of high interest rates. I read to the enthralled members of the gallery what this government said about the purchase of dwellings and the needs of home buyers and renters in Australia. Under the heading `Dwelling Investment' the document states:

SPEECH.PARA: Households are taken to have a desired ratio of consumption of dwelling services (as measured by the stock of dwellings) to total consumption.

That meant that it was an imbalanced situation that enough people had enough money to buy the houses that were available. What does this mean? The rich could buy the houses; nobody else could. One Nation is the document those opposite are living by here in this parliament, for all of these brilliant policies they are bringing forward. Day after day we hear about One Nation. That was a nation divided; that was a nation for the rich. This was not a nation where people who wanted housing could get housing. Now we are debating an aspect of the Commonwealth-state housing agreement, something that relates to the provision of housing rental assistance and purchase assistance for those on lower incomes.

PARA.TAB: At last the matter comes back into the House and the government starts to think about people who have been hurting for the last three years. At the very time the government could have generated employment and opportunities for people by providing additional funds for state governments to boost the housing stock, to help cut back the queues of people waiting for rental assistance, waiting for accommodation, it walked away with a statement in One Nation that the stock of housing was in balance with the people requiring to buy. What it meant was those who had enough money could buy.

The average price of a home in Sydney is $170,000. What young couple under the age of 35 seeking to purchase their first home can put together that package? It can only be after years of slaving and saving to purchase their first home. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services (Dr Theophanous), who is at the table, sits in a salubrious and elevated position here in the parliament, having forgotten where he has come from and the people of his own electorate. It honestly depresses me to see this occurring.

I refer the House to the budget where the exact figures are contained of the Commonwealth's commitment to provide assistance to people requiring housing. I notice that over the next three- or four-year period there is a consistent decline in funding, except for the boost in two or three years time of a program called the social housing subsidy program. It has already been delayed for some time because nobody can work out the guidelines as to how it will work. The budget states:

SPEECH.PARA: The commencement of the social housing subsidy program has been delayed until 1994-95 to allow additional time to develop guidelines and approaches to shared home ownership arrangements in consultation with the states.

It will take those opposite two years to work out how to do it. It is bureaucratic language for saying, `We haven't got the money, we are thinking up an idea, we don't know how to deliver it, but in two years time we'll know how to do it'. That is what has been done in the budget. We just have to look at the budget to see that there is a declining commitment to the welfare housing sector for the people who need housing. It is dropping substantially in real terms, in dollar terms. The parliamentary secretary should not shake his head. If he is prepared to suffer the pain, I will read the figures to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you should.

—All right. In 1993-94 the government's commitment is $975.8 million; in 1994-95 it is $887 million. In my calculation, that is a drop of $90 million—and those opposite say that is a growth! This is their own budget. Have they not read this document? Have they not looked at this paper? Do they not know what the former Treasurer said on budget night? Then there is a further drop in the following year. An amount of $100 million has been put in there for the social housing subsidy program; that is, if the government can work out how to administer it. The figure has dropped over two years already, it has dropped back another year in this budget, and I guess in the next budget it will be dropped back further. We will never see it.

PARA.TAB: Organisations such as the Hills accommodation for youth, a community program, a social program assisting homeless youth, sorely need those funds. Workers with that organisation are not going out encouraging kids to leave home. All they are saying is, `If children are experiencing stress in their family and need support we will stand by them and their parents'. It is not a grandiose program that is funded on the basis of how many kids can be convinced to leave home or come into the establishment, it is a thoughtful, well-administered program. Those opposite say, `Maybe in a couple of years time we will work out how we are going to administer it, then they can have some money'. The fact of the matter is that, if they do not work that out, assistance to people in welfare housing drops.

We have trouble with the legislation before us because of the manner in which it is presented. I have looked at the Auditor-General's report—another blue-covered report. Members of the government ought to read it carefully and pay attention to what is being said. I know that my colleague at the table, the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson), is well aware of the significance of all the Auditor-General's reports.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this one full of fraud?
—This one is not like the sports rorts Auditor-General's report. It is not full of fraud, whiteboards and those sorts of crazy ideas. The foreword states:

PARA.TAB: The commentary contains numerous ideas and suggestions in the nature of consider points which, if sensibly adopted where applicable to specific Commonwealth-State agreements, should stimulate improvements in this important sphere of public administration.

SPEECH.PARA: This report was brought down in September. The Auditor-General is coming up with constructive ideas to improve the administration of Commonwealth-state agreements and arrangements. I would like to read to the House three or four of the salient features that head the list. The first point on aspects of Commonwealth-state agreements states:

Audits conducted by the ANAO in recent years have demonstrated that the administration of Commonwealth-State agreements has potential for considerable improvement, particularly in aspects such as accountability, value for money and effectiveness of program delivery.
The second point states:
Expenditure reductions are possible by identifying and eliminating duplication of effort and adopting best practices through benchmarking.
The third point states:
Audit activity at Commonwealth, State and other levels could be better integrated . . .

There is another series of points which are important but they do not impact much on the program before the House today. Let us look at Commonwealth expenditure in specific purpose payments—that is, tied grants, in simple terms, to the states—and at the growth in those grants over the last five years. In 1989-90 it was $12.7 billion and in 1993-94 it was $16.7 billion. The grants have increased as a proportion of payments to the states from 48 per cent to 53 per cent. So this government is tying more and more of its money. It is setting the conditions that states must comply with.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) made a grand statement about how there should be better relationships between the states and the Commonwealth. One process mentioned by the Prime Minister that the Premiers will deal with is that all of these matters will be looked at. The Prime Minister said, `We recognise the role of the states'. That is a fine opening statement; I do not know how he could avoid recognising the role of the states. Then he said, `We are going to make improvements in micro-economic reform and administration. But, if we make improvements, that is not a valid point for us to gather more funds'. In fact, the states have to do better, cop it sweet on less money and not squeal. If they are doing better, that does not entitle them to more money; it entitles them to less. It is the same old system revamped with different Keatingspeak. If they continue to be inefficient, they continue to claim more money than if they are efficient. In the housing area and tied grants area the government is increasing the number and proportion of tied grants to state governments. That is what the Auditor-General says—and he knows. Today the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) said, `Don't ask me to add up the sums; the Auditor-General does that. I just pay out the money. If a certificate comes back, that is all I look for. It does not matter if it meets policy objectives or anything else. That is not the minister's job; it's the Auditor-General's'. The Auditor-General is saying that the government has increased the percentage and the proportion of tied grants to the states and, therefore, its administration needs to be more careful. The government is telling them more about what it wants. The same thing applies to what the government is doing with the Commonwealth-state housing agreement.

The Auditor-General says that, in order to establish effective programs in housing or any other area, there must be good `consultation, communication and consultative arrangements'; in fact, that is one of the headings in the Auditor-General's report. Under that heading, he states:

Good communication channels are essential to the efficient and effective achievement of the objectives of the agreement. Every agreement should identify the communication and consultative arrangements to operate between the various governments involved.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments the government is moving were notified to the states yesterday and to the coalition at midday yesterday. That is consultation; that is good communication. That is following through the processes outlined by the Auditor-General and the processes which the Prime Minister will speak to the Premiers about when they meet for the Council of Australian Governments.

PARA.TAB: What are you guys doing? You have these audit reports that you ignore. You have statements that you appear not to read in the budget, in One Nation. You have a Prime Minister who makes speeches that are supposed to capture front pages but which have no intellectual content because they mean nothing. Where are you going with administration of Commonwealth-state agreements in the relationship? You need to have some sort of clearly stated goal and an objective that you can clearly adhere to. You do not appear to be adhering to any advice from the officers of the parliament or even adhering to the statements of the Treasurer (Mr Willis). Even the statements of the Prime Minister appear to be unrelated to the real world and the real facts of life. I think you have to answer some of these questions, and you need to answer how are you going to improve communication to start with. The states are not concerned about these amendments. I know that. They think that this is a reasonable adjustment. Why do you not communicate with them? Why do you not tell them about amendments that are coming into the parliament ahead of time? Why do you not tell us in this parliament ahead of time? This is the new, open Australian parliament where everything is up for scrutiny, where we are having two chambers so that members can better apply themselves to understanding the legislation, and where there can be a better explanation to the Australian people of what we do here. We have had changes of standing orders, changes to all sorts of rights in this place today because you want to keep ministers out of this chamber in order to improve communications.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Order! If we are talking about changes and new rules, I would ask the honourable member for Mitchell to direct his references to the chair and through the chair, not to individual members. That is another change that we will institute.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy you want to hear that, Mr Deputy Speaker. Let me explain to you what is going on here; maybe you can prevail upon the parliamentary secretary at the table to get into his minister's ear, the Treasurer's ear and the Prime Minister's ear—those three people in particular—because their communications with state governments are appalling. The Commonwealth is applying greater restrictions and controls to its programs. It is seeking world best practice, whatever that means—it depends which environment we are in as to how that is defined. I will leave that matter to one side.

PARA.TAB: The government does not tell people what it is doing. It is a crazy way to operate. The Prime Minister went on the box and made speeches about how we are going to have this new era of light and gladness. Mr Deputy Speaker, you will benefit from that in your electorate; you will be turning handsprings at the way in which your electorate is going to benefit from the Prime Minister's words spoken yesterday. I draw the attention of the House to the concluding paragraphs of the Auditor-General's report which deal with Commonwealth-state agreements of all sorts:

SPEECH.PARA: In the case of housing, for example, data currently available to the department is insufficient to determine both the true levels of subsidies provided under the various housing assistance schemes and the overall exposure of the Commonwealth under its obligations to meet any shortfalls in the operation of those schemes.

We do need to know those things. I do not think that is intrusion. In that regard and in regard to consultation and communication this is a very sensible and constructive report. The shame of the matter is that the Commonwealth seems to be ignoring it. This report was brought down in September. The government can lob an amendment to the act on the table with 24 hours notice and expect us to debate the implications of it and have the state governments understand it, but the government can ignore a report like this for six months. It seems a strange way to do business. It seems to represent the attitude of a government that does not care or, if it was aware of the Auditor-General's report, which chose to ignore it completely and to go its own way. I do not think that is good enough.

PARA.TAB: The housing industry in Australia is moving at good speed; land prices and values are increasing. That poses a difficulty for welfare housing. In a system with a declining budget, additional costs on the purchase of land will be imposed on state governments. There will perhaps be a shortage of materials; none are appearing at this point in Australia. There also may be some shortage of labour. The government needs to pay attention to that area. It should assess the adequacy of its total budget for future outlays on welfare housing. The government has chosen to ignore it during the harsh period that we have come through. I hope that it will not neglect it in the period ahead.

I commend various state governments for their new approach to housing, particularly the Victorian government which sought to apply a very good administrative approach in the area of assistance to housing. The Victorian government has considered the draft Industry Commission report and has responded in detail, saying that it wants to see transparency and accountability built into the program, and that is laudable. The Victorian government strongly supports the principles of increased targeting of resources to those clients with the greatest need and of improved choice amongst those clients. Those are two fine objectives.

State governments are restricted in their capacity to charge market rents because the Commonwealth government is a bit twitchy about charging market rents. A number of administrators—not in a political sense—have expressed their concern that clients of housing commissions hang in there. Take a hypothetical couple whose children have moved out of home and are off their hands. That couple is paying minimal rent for a three-bedroom house when a townhouse would probably be adequate for their needs. It is okay to ask, `How do you get them to move out?' There is a requirement if there is a shortage of stock and a demand there. There are substantial queues that need attention. There must be a way of moving people on who are holding up accommodation by hanging in there when they should not be.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have to give them incentives.

—Of course, we have to give them incentives to move on. There may be the prospect of transfer fees or assistance in removal. One technique which could be used is to gradually increase rents towards market rents. People then have a real choice.
—What about the poor people?

—It is all means tested. The parliamentary secretary knows that. Does the parliamentary secretary endorse a married couple continuing to live in a three bedroom home? He knows that they would be keeping out a family that has been searching for accommodation, that is in need of accommodation. Some of them are on the waiting list for up to eight or nine years. They put their name on the list when their first child is born and after eight or nine years they could have three or four kids running around and still be waiting to get into a house that the government is supposed to give them assistance to get into. The parliamentary secretary is trying to advance the argument that a couple with no children should hold up three-bedroom accommodation for an interminable period. I do not follow the logic of that argument. By incentive, by encouragement and by the mechanism of market rent, state governments would be better able to administer welfare housing in Australia today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forrest Mr J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to contribute to the debate on the appropriation bills, although I am disappointed that there has not been much of a debate. I do not particularly want to prolong this debate, but it is disappointing—even though I have been here not quite 12 months—to hear in defence of the government's lack of performance reference to the coalition's Fightback package which we took to the last election. That is really amazing.

PARA.TAB: Fightback offered some tremendous incentives in the area of housing. In response to the manipulations of the honourable member for Corio (Mr O'Connor) and the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Quick), the whole intent of the coalition's housing policy was to encourage those people on the long waiting list for public housing to be able to afford their own housing. That was the whole philosophy behind our policy. Just as there is an incredible waiting list in the public health system, there is an incredible waiting list for public housing for those people who this government purports to want to help.

The fundamental difference lies in the philosophies of those who sit on the government benches and those who sit on the opposition benches. The opposition's general political philosophy is that we trust the people to make their own decisions; it is government's function to facilitate the making of those decisions, not to control all aspects of people's lives. It really disappoints me that the government's public housing program is still welfare oriented. I can speak with some experience on the issue of housing. In my real life out there over the last 10 years I have worked as a consultant—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is still the real world out there. I encourage those honourable members who have been here for a while to recognise that the real world comprises the people out there whom we are trying to help by establishing legislation and law. A number of major criticisms have been highlighted by previous speakers. The honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) mentioned criticisms of the Commonwealth-state housing agreement. The criticisms levelled at that program have been reinforced by the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman). The Auditor-General quite plainly criticises the Commonwealth-state housing agreement for its lack of transparency in order for an audit trail to be performed and for the whole accountability process.

PARA.TAB: As a new member of parliament, I am appalled to observe the government's lack of consciousness in this whole process of accountability. It is highlighted by the so-called sports rorts program, which the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson) has brought to the attention of the House over the last few months. The community is demanding more and more accountability from this place as to how its tax dollars are spent. The amount of that tax is ever increasing, via the taxation structure or the petrol bowser, so people are taking a much more accurate interest in how it is spent. I think it is time that the government and those who sit on the government benches recognise this.

Although I realise that this legislation is not all that controversial and that to allocate $3 billion to the seven-year program in respect of housing is somewhat routine, I am really disappointed that in the debate on this legislation no answers have been given either by honourable members who have spoken or by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services (Dr Theophanous) in his second reading speech. He might be able to answer some of the criticisms that have been directed to this program by the Auditor-General. In a draft report issued late last year, the Auditor-General said:

SPEECH.PARA: One aspect that is frequently overlooked by departments and agencies is the need for clear identification, measurement and reporting of Commonwealth obligations or exposure under the agreement.
Audit report No. 6 of 1993-94 said:

PARA.TAB: Implementation of arrangements that provide for an effective and appropriate level of audit coverage for Commonwealth-State agreements is one of the more common deficiencies observed by the ANAO.

SPEECH.PARA: These questions need to be answered. One of the issues which the Auditor-General was trying to track was the administrative cost of running these programs to ensure that maximum value was received by the people in the real world. A number of other criticisms have also been made about the program. I know that the honourable member for Corio made glowing references to the report by the Industry Commission. I do not share his confidence, because the report said:
Governments have a long way to go in assisting Australians who are most in need of housing. Many Australians remain in housing stress and in urgent need of assistance.
The Commission considers it important that governments assess now what role they want public and community housing to take in the future and begin reforms so that people do not suffer needlessly.

These are real criticisms. I have not heard answers to those criticisms in any references in this debate. I will be looking for them when the parliamentary secretary closes this debate. Government members have spoken glowingly about the government's housing policy. Working in the industry over the last 10 years, I have observed that, whilst a problem solved by throwing around quantities of money might make those people who are signing the cheques and sending the money feel warm and cuddly, the effectiveness of those programs at the end of the day is what matters. I have witnessed, on the ground, what I consider to be blatant wastes of community funds. There are other more innovative ways that this government ought to consider. The policies we took to the last election tried to do that by moving those people who unfortunately have become dependent on public housing into a position where they can afford their own housing.

PARA.TAB: Accessibility and affordability of appropriate housing can be created in a number of innovative ways. While working as a consultant, one matter that I developed a particular beef about was the excessive amount of government regulation. By the time a person has submitted a town planning application for a community development of fairly high intensity public housing, suffered the rigorous requirements and costs of advertising, and dealt with public inquiry and often criticism and objection, if eventually lucky enough to receive a town planning permit, that person then has to deal with building inspectors, plumbing inspectors, scaffolding inspectors and a whole host of other excessive regulations.
