All of this costs money. I think the suggestions of the Housing Industry Association, which has made inputs into the considerations of the Industry Commission, ought to be considered. These costs are unnecessary, time delaying and most frustrating.

The Industry Commission report also refers to the cost of taxation. This criticism is described on page 163 of the report, which says that by OECD standards the tax burden on Australian properties is relatively high. These are more innovative ways in which the government could address the situation if it were serious about doing something about the long waiting list for public housing and facilitating a process by which Australians could be encouraged to accept the responsibility and buy their own homes.

A lot of the things that I wanted to say have already been addressed by many of the previous speakers. I am anxious to see whether the government is serious about addressing some of the issues that I and other speakers from this side of the House have raised. We are anxious, as the government is, to see the needs of Australians met. We are not encouraged to hear the criticisms that are made by respectable authorities. We want to see that, when those criticisms are raised, they are met. The amendment before the House makes reference to the fact that there has not been a long consultative process. This legislation could have been an opportunity to address some of those concerns.

Another issue which I think the honourable member for Dawson made reference to, and another concern of mine regarding what I have seen during my involvement in the industry over the years, is that the government's public housing program is still very much welfare oriented. The Industry Commission report said that the question of the role of public housing in the longer term still remains to be answered. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Is it to remain a residual tenure for those on low incomes—that is, welfare housing? The move to welfare housing rather than a tenure available to all appears to have occurred by default through progressively narrowing assistance by . . . targeting.

Something that always used to annoy me in witnessing a new development to provide public housing in my electorate was that in a short space of time the deterioration of that dwelling, contributed to by the lack of a sense of responsibility and any sense of equity sharing in the responsibility of maintenance, resulted in excessive expenses for repair.

PARA.TAB: Programs that are occurring now in Victoria which encourage local cooperatives to have a greater self-regulation control on not just the maintenance but also the rental tenancy agreements and general controls are initiatives that ought to be encouraged. We should place the responsibility for the way that tax dollars are spent in a community cooperative. It does work. As a member of a rural constituency, I can say that when communities are together, when there is a strong sense of community spirit and community accountability, such programs can be made to work. One program working in Victoria already has 200 houses. It is a state-wide cooperative known as the Common Equity Rental Housing Cooperative.

One of the things that these arrangements do is encourage the private sector to seek this sort of housing as a source of financing. I think this is another initiative that the government ought to consider to remove what seems to be an excessive cost burden for the government in maintaining its housing program.

The private sector currently does not have the confidence to invest in public housing because of the lack of accountability and conscience in the caring of properties. I agree with the Industry Commission when it says that the government has a long way to go in assisting Australians who are most in need of housing. I remind the government that it needs to address the sentence which says, `Many Australians remain in housing stress and are in urgent need of assistance'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister, Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I want to thank the honourable members for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), Corio (Mr O'Connor), Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), Franklin (Mr Quick), Mitchell (Mr Cadman) and Mallee (Mr Forrest) for their contribution to what I think has been a very useful and helpful debate in relation to these very important issues. Obviously, the general thread throughout all of the contributions has been the concern of the House with respect to housing issues and homelessness. I was very impressed that everyone is now concerned that housing is a significant social justice issue. It is important that we reinforce that on all sides of the House.

PARA.TAB: Housing is a significant social justice issue. People are entitled to accommodation. This is not just something which is a privilege; accommodation should be a right of every person in an advanced and democratic country. In that sense, obviously, the obligations of all levels of government to help in the provision of housing are present as well as the obligation of the community more broadly.

Having agreed that we have that general social justice goal, it is obvious that there are differences of emphasis as to how one would go about achieving those goals. In some of the speeches I could not work out whether I was being requested to go in one direction or in another. For example, the honourable member for Mitchell started his comments by suggesting that there were some problems with the extent of home building in recent times. That is not true. In fact, in the last year we have had the second highest level of housing activity in the postwar period—the second highest.

If we are looking at the housing issue primarily in terms of the total number of dwellings being built—that is obviously an important dimension—then the comments of the honourable member for Mitchell which tended to suggest that affordability was a problem for the majority of people or even for the average person are quite wrong. In fact, because of the reduction in interest rates and because of the packages that are being offered by many banks and other institutions, housing has become much more affordable than it was two, three or four years ago.

We are looking at what has in fact been a second revision. We have had to revise our forecast of dwelling commencements for 1993-94 to 168,000 from 157,000—up 11,000 from what was previously a very high level. So from that point of view we have to say that the government's macro-economic strategy in terms of its impact on the housing sector is working. Having said that, it does not follow that we will not have any problems in housing. Of course we will. Some other members have addressed these, and I will try to talk about them.

In the first instance, let me comment on the contribution of the honourable member for Dawson with respect to the specific problems of South Sea Islanders. I have just been given by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) responsibility for the access and equity program. One of the areas of implementation of the access and equity program involves housing. I will read the material that the honourable member for Dawson has presented to me on the special disadvantage that people of South Sea Islander background face and I will see what can be done in relation to this particular disadvantage. It is true, as the honourable member says, that a report appeared 15 months ago entitled Call for recognition. That report deserves a response from the government, and I will try to see that a response is given. I thank the honourable member for Dawson for bringing this question to the attention of the House.

It is important when we are talking about the social justice dimension of housing, or indeed other social justice issues, that we remember that there are specific problems for specific groups of people, including people with particular ethnic, cultural or racial backgrounds. In that context, if a particular group has a specific problem we should focus on that problem and see what we can do to assist them. I give the honourable member for Dawson an undertaking that I will look into that matter.

On the general question of public housing, it is important to note that three points of view were put forward in the speeches made by members of the opposition. The first was effectively that there should be less public housing and more done through the market. This is not the view of the government. We believe that public housing has a significant role to play in this nation and as part of the overall provision of housing. We will continue to highlight that. We do not agree with those who argue that public housing should not be provided at the current level and that the private sector should do more. We believe both sectors should work together, but that the public sector has a key and very important role which we will continue to ensure it plays. The honourable member for Moncrieff seemed to be expressing an opposite view—that in fact the government was not doing enough in the public housing area.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that.
—You did because you referred—
—I said there was a shortfall caused by your woeful unemployment record.

—You claimed that state Labor governments had the highest proportion of population on waiting lists for public housing. Obviously you were interested in more being done in the area of public housing, I would assume. Otherwise, what is the point of the comment?
—I am more interested in jobs so everyone can afford their own house.

—There is also the employment question and I will deal with that in a little while—one thing at a time. Let me first refer to the fact that we are committed and we believe we should continue to do a lot in this area of public housing.

PARA.TAB: Speakers on the government side have mentioned that in the Fightback package the opposition proposed to the Australian people—and this is a direct response for the honourable member for Moncrieff, who chose to make political points in this debate—a massive reduction of more than $400 million in this area of expenditure. Imagine the impact of that on the overall housing situation, especially on poor people who would have been most affected and most hurt by that sort of approach.

While it is possible to come in and criticise the government at the edges about various matters concerning the total budget for public housing, the fact is that this government is committed to a massive budget in relation to public housing and federal government support for housing. That is the key issue.

Those who say that there is an adjustment of $5 million or $10 million should look at it in the context of what would have happened had the opposition won the election and implemented the full range of Fightback policies. The whole area would have been massively slashed. Funding close to $1,000 million would have been reduced by more than $400 million. That is what would have happened had the opposition won the election and tried to meet its promise to cut—this depends on the figures one prefers to believe—between $7,000 million and $10,000 million from government expenditures, including housing. So that kind of criticism is also not acceptable.

Another issue involves the role of welfare housing. A number of people criticised the government for using the report of the Auditor-General. But what did the Auditor-General say in his report? He said that it was very important for the Commonwealth to do more to ensure that the state governments meet their implementation responsibilities and that there were problems with implementation when it came to the level of the state governments.

What did the honourable member for Mitchell suggest? He suggested that we should hand over the whole responsibility to the states. Some members of the opposition are referring to the Auditor-General's report as though it criticises the government while other opposition members, such as the honourable member for Mitchell, are saying, `One response is to hand over the whole of welfare housing to the states'. I do not know whether that is the official position of the opposition. Nowadays we have given up trying to work out its official position. I am simply commenting on the various positions of opposition speakers.

Clearly, those who want to take notice of the Auditor-General's report—we obviously do—have to think in terms of making sure that the implementation mechanism with respect to the states is better managed. We do not have the power to direct the states in these matters. We can encourage them, cajole them and give them guidance. That is the sort of thing which the minister and his officials have been doing.

This leads me to the next item—a problem mentioned by the opposition—of insufficient consultation with the states with respect to these amendments. The honourable member for Moncrieff requested a delay of 24 hours. As it turned out, we had a delay of 24 hours. Other opposition members had the full benefit of that delay. I did not notice that they concentrated very much on the amendments. In fact, most of their comments were of a general nature. Very few of them concentrated on these amendments with respect to the states.

These amendments are not controversial. There is nothing controversial here. It is not as though there is some serious problem. Nevertheless, we have had a delay. We have now had a very comprehensive debate, although most opposition members did not have any problem with the amendments. So I am not sure exactly why the honourable member for Moncrieff has moved her quite gratuitous amendment, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)deplores the haste with which the Government has prepared its amendment to the Bill;
(2)regrets the Government's failure to observe the normal parliamentary courtesies—

and so on. The fact is that we have now had the delay which the honourable member wanted. She is seeking an assurance from the government that normal courtesies necessary for the proper consideration of proposed legislation in this chamber be observed in the future.

PARA.TAB: I mention to the honourable member that we will be introducing shortly a second chamber that will look at legislation in very great detail. That is a revolutionary measure in most of the countries that have democratic parliaments such as ours. There will be a very lengthy evaluation of bills. Therefore, the motion that she has moved is not necessary, because there will be a lengthy consultation and consideration of bills in the new arrangements.

I notice that in her speech yesterday—unfortunately, I was not able to be present and hear it because I had to go to a meeting in Sydney with Disabled Peoples International—she talked about being fed up, upset and so forth with procedures in this House. I can only say that the new procedures should be given a chance to operate, especially in the second chamber. When they are given that chance, all honourable members will benefit. I ask her to be a little patient in relation to the new procedures. I am sure we will find that the debates will proceed in an even better way.

I conclude my comments by thanking all the honourable members who contributed to the debate. I thank all honourable members for their commitment to affordable housing for all Australians. Even though we may have some disagreements about how to do things, naturally the government is always open to suggestions and considerations—I know that this is true of the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services (Mr Howe)—with respect to how we can get the system operating better in the future.

This is a federal-state operated system. Because of that, we do not totally control all situations. Nevertheless, with goodwill on the part of governments, irrespective of their political colour, we can achieve the goal of affordable housing for Australians and ensure that no Australian is homeless.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Reid)—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.
—Proceed.

—I claim to have been misrepresented by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services (Dr Theophanous) in what he just said. I want to briefly lay on the record what I said. He said that I had criticised the government for its shortfall of housing funds. He referred in general terms to some matters that I had raised in my speech yesterday. I want to get in the record what I said. The comparison stands. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is noteworthy that the states that had state Labor governments for several years, mainly Victoria and South Australia, were the ones with the highest proportion of population waiting lists for public housing.
I then gave some figures for the states, which I will not repeat at this point because they are fairly lengthy. I then said:

These figures indicated that few inroads were being made in the backlog of demand for public housing and that some states and territories—most notably, Victoria, the ACT and the Northern Territory—were falling further behind in the provision of public housing. The steady increase in unemployment to more than one million after the dates I have mentioned has meant thousands more Australians have been added to those already in need. The recession we had to have, according to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), undoubtedly increased dramatically the already shamefully long waiting lists.
It is clear that what I talked about in my speech yesterday was not the level of funding but the reasons for the level of demand.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mrs Sullivan's amendment) stand part of the question.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! As the House will now proceed to consideration in detail of this bill under standing order 222, I take this opportunity to explain one matter of proposed practice to the House. Honourable members are aware that there can no longer be a Committee of the Whole House and that matters previously dealt with in committee of the whole now have to be considered in the House or in the Main Committee. It is proposed that, where they are relevant and where the standing or sessional orders do not contain any specific provision which would apply, precedents and practices from former committees of the whole should be followed during the consideration in detail stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister, Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the supplementary explanatory memorandum to the House.

PARA.TAB: Clauses 1 to 3—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Proposed new clauses—by leave—taken together.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister, Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: After clause 3, page 2, add the following new clauses:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Grants to be matched by State

PARA.TAB: "4. Section 15 of the Principal Act is amended by inserting after subsection (2) the following subsection:

`(2A) Despite subsection (2), the Minister may, in respect of the sixth grant year, authorise untied grants to a particular State, even if the Minister cannot ensure that the State will match the grants in accordance with the provision of its housing agreement corresponding to paragraph 13(2)(b) of the form of housing agreement in Schedule 1.'.
"5. After section 15 of the Principal Act the following section is inserted:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Grants to be matched by State—exception

PARA.TAB: `15A.(1) The Minister may determine in writing that, in respect of a grant year, a particular State is taken to have fulfilled its obligation to provide matching funds in accordance with the provision of its housing agreement corresponding to paragraph 13(2)(b) of the form of housing agreement in Schedule 1.
`(2) A determination made under subsection (1) must be in relation to the fifth grant year or the sixth grant year.

`(3) The Minister must not make the determination unless satisfied, after consulting with the State Minister of that State, that, in the circumstances, the State was unable to meet its obligation in respect of that grant year under that provision.
`(4) The determination has effect for the purposes of the housing agreement.

`(5) In deciding whether to make the determination, the Minister must have regard to the extent to which assistance provided by the State under the housing agreement reflects the principles set out in Recital (D) of the form of housing agreement in Schedule 1.
`(6) The State Minister of that State must agree in writing to the determination being made.
`(7) The determination made by the Minister must be tabled in each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after it is made.'.".

SPEECH.PARA: These new clauses follow from further consultations with the states. They are intended to help accommodate concerns of the states about the operation of the agreement. It is a very positive amendment from the point of view of the states. I do not understand why the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), in her speech at the second reading stage, wanted to challenge the amendment. It is quite straightforward and will have a very positive impact. We should be allowed to proceed with the amendments and the implementation of the Commonwealth-state housing agreement. We can then deliver the maximum in positive outcomes for housing for people, which is what this amendment will achieve. It is quite clear that the amendment should proceed forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday these new clauses came into this place without any warning, explanation to or consultation with the opposition. We had tabled in the chamber the amendment and the explanatory memorandum. We have had no explanation from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services (Dr Theophanous) as to the effect of the amendment. I would have thought a change that goes substantially to the heart of Commonwealth-state funding agreements and arrangements on housing might be explained. All the parliamentary secretary has said is that it will improve things. That may be so, but this parliament is being asked to amend legislation and change previous funding arrangements without an explanation of how, why or what. We are being told, `Here they are. They're good. Vote for them'.

PARA.TAB: I understand that an examination of the amendment would indicate that it is in line with an expressed desire, wish or agreement between Commonwealth and state ministers. I understand that they are along those lines. But the government has not said that in this chamber yet.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will explain it to you in detail.

—Good. We might have a nice long debate on this. There are questions which need to be answered. We would like to know what the known financial implications for the state governments are. The parliamentary secretary referred to my speech in the second reading debate, but he ignored one part of it. I said that under the heading `Financial impact' in the explanatory memorandum there appeared the statement that there are no additional Commonwealth outlays. I went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition has no information on how this new section is going to affect state outlays.

That was totally ignored by the parliamentary secretary. I understand that this amendment has substantial implications for state governments. We have not heard a word about that. Because of the way the amendment was treated, we have not been able to get that information from the state governments. They were informed only yesterday of the actual amendment. They thought they were going to sight the actual amendment next week at a meeting of Commonwealth and state housing ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ah, come on!

—That is what they believed. They are not spitting the dummy because they have not seen it. They simply could not answer our questions because they had not seen it. So we want to know the known financial implications and the long-term financial implications of these amendments.

PARA.TAB: As I understand it, there is potential for the waiver of some fifty-fifty requirement that applies at the moment. But what happens in this area is a dollar for dollar matching and Commonwealth government approval of loan funds is involved. How will that be affected by this matter? These are all things that should be explained.

As I have said, there is a substantial change and the government should be giving that explanation to this parliament. It should have done it when it brought the amendments in, not at this consideration in detail stage. We also want to know what the variations will be between states. Will states be treated differently? What effect will this proposed legislation have on individual states? We are entitled to all this information. It does not matter that the Commonwealth and the states have had conversations. That is not the end of the subject by any means. Before we vote to change legislation and fundamental agreements, we are entitled to know what that will do.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister, Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —It appears that I will have to delay the House for a longer period in order to answer the questions of the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan). She is quite wrong in saying that the ministers have not been consulted. We have had significant consultations with the ministers. The initiatives for these changes came out of discussions with the ministers about the proposed 1993 act and the fact that some of them were going to have problems with it. In order to accommodate the states and the requests of ministers, we brought in these changes.

PARA.TAB: In addition to that, the states were consulted on the actual amendments. Changes to purchase assistance matching were discussed with the Commonwealth-state standing committee on housing officials on 1 February and in bilateral meetings of the Commonwealth and state housing ministers in the past fortnight. As I have mentioned to the House, last night I attended in Sydney a function held by the Disabled Peoples International. The New South Wales Minister for Housing was present. He did not raise with me any concerns about this amendment. In fact, he is quite delighted that we are proceeding with this amendment in order to get the agreement passed and put into place so that we can do something about housing for people.

I will now present in detail the reasons for the amendment for the benefit of the honourable member for Moncrieff. In amending section 15 of this act, by adding a new subsection 15(2A), the amendment to the Housing Assistance Amendment Bill sets out provision for the Commonwealth minister to authorise the full level of untied grants to a particular state in 1994-95, even if the minister cannot ensure that the state can meet the balance of its matching obligation from the value of home loans provided through its home purchase assistance programs in accordance with paragraph 13(2)(b) of the Commonwealth-state housing agreement.

The proposed new section 15A sets out the provision for the Commonwealth minister effectively to waive or reduce a state or territory's obligation to match the balance of untied assistance provided by the Commonwealth to a state for housing assistance from the value of home loans provided through home purchase assistance programs. This provision will apply for only 1993-94 and 1994-95.

This amendment will not, however, relieve an affected state of its grant matching obligations under the agreement. Commonwealth untied assistance provided under the Commonwealth-state housing agreement to the states and territories is used for a number of purposes, predominantly for building or purchasing public rental housing stock.

The Commonwealth-state housing agreement requires states to match this untied assistance on a dollar for dollar basis, with at least half of the matching provided through state grants and the balance through the value of loans made under home purchase assistance schemes. However, difficulties have recently arisen as a result of lower demand for home purchase assistance products and the relatively attractive terms of commercial products in the current economic climate. The affected states have also indicated that they are not able to provide additional grant funding to meet the 1993-94 matching obligation.

In the case of 1993-94, where it has become evident that some states will not undertake sufficient lending under their home purchase assistance programs to meet their obligations under the agreement the CSHA provides for the Commonwealth to recover financial assistance already provided. In the case of 1994-95, where some states have indicated that they are unlikely to be able to meet their matching requirements the Housing Assistance Act requires that the minister not provide funds which will not be matched. This effectively means that the Commonwealth must reduce untied grants to a level that will be matched. The government considers that either to recover financial assistance already provided or to reduce funding to be provided would be undesirable and that is for the reasons I mentioned in my second reading speech.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. N.B. Reid)—Does the parliamentary secretary wish to seek the indulgence of the House to continue his remarks?

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek the indulgence of the House to continue my remarks.
—Please proceed.

—It will reduce funds for public housing and in the light of the current demand for such housing would disadvantage those most in need of assistance. Also it would be undesirable to pursue such action where states are genuinely unable to meet such requirements because of changed market conditions. To force states to increase lending at this time solely to meet their matching requirements may result in loans being made to more marginal clients. This could impact adversely on the viability of the overall home lending program in the longer term as well as creating problems for clients should their circumstances change.

PARA.TAB: Any decision to waive or reduce the home purchase assistance matching requirement will be taken only after careful consideration of the circumstances leading to the need for such a course of action and will be determined on a case by case basis. Issues taken into account when making this decision will include the economic environment in the relevant grant year, the availability of alternative home lending finance products to low to moderate income earners, a state's lending effort and commitment in previous years, and the nature of the programs being offered by an affected state.

It is not possible at this time to detail specifically the extent of any waiver or reduction of the home purchase assistance matching requirement. The financial information required for 1993-94 will not be available until the end of the financial year, and in the case of 1994-95 states are not required under the agreement to provide details of their matching proposals until 31 March this year, and even this will be based on estimated levels of lending only.

However, in 1993-94 it would appear that New South Wales will have a shortfall of the order of $130 million—its total obligation. Victoria's is difficult to estimate as it will depend on the take-up rate of its new shared home ownership program which is likely to be introduced progressively from April. Tasmania's shortfall is estimated this time to be around $2 million. The Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services (Mr Howe) will be pursuing the 1994-95 issues with the states. Any determination will be made only after consultation with the relevant state minister and after the federal Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services is satisfied that this course of action is the most appropriate. In the case of 1994-95, any action will only be taken after consideration by the government. To ensure ongoing parliamentary oversight these determinations will be tabled. The honourable member for Moncrieff should note that.

This remedy to current difficulties will not be open ended. It is intended only as a short-term response to ensure that those in need of public housing are not disadvantaged. Policy in the home purchase assistance area is to be reconsidered later this year in consultation with the states and territories and in the context of the government's consideration of the Industry Commission report on public housing.

This is a very positive amendment. It is intended to deal with what we hope will be a short-term problem. It is a very sensitive response to the genuine problems of the states as detected by the minister. The minister is to be congratulated for not cutting back on the Commonwealth's contribution, sustaining the Commonwealth's contribution and showing some understanding of the problems of specific states in relation to this matter, thereby fulfilling the Commonwealth's full commitment in relation to public housing and housing generally, as part of the government's continuing social justice commitment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will comment on the remarks made by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services (Dr Theophanous). So far as the views of the states are concerned, I will hear them from the states, thank you. With all due respect to the parliamentary secretary—and I am sure he would not seek ever to mislead the House—he does not speak for the states and I will wait to hear what they say.

PARA.TAB: The information that has just been read into the record took eight whole minutes of this House's time, and that is the information we should have been given to start with. That explanation is what should have been on the record from the beginning. It should have been available either when the parliamentary secretary replied to the second reading debate or when he moved the amendment. That is information we are entitled to. That information goes to the heart of Commonwealth-state financial arrangements and it goes to the heart of the integrity of the government in a range of ways.

This is an example of a relatively non-controversial bill. There have been discussions between the Commonwealth government and the states over the need for an amount of flexibility. The opposition welcomes flexibility. We welcome the fact that an agreement was able to be reached between the Commonwealth and the states. I reiterate, however, that at the time the words of the amendment came before this parliament, from the office of the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe), they had not been shown to the states as the final words. There may well have been agreement beforehand, but the states could not tell us when we contacted them yesterday what the final words were. The states had not seen them and they were not aware that they were public until we made contact with them.

I do not resile from the point I was making yesterday or today. The parliamentary secretary should go back a little further than the debate on this bill yesterday to the preceding debate yesterday, to which I referred in my speech on the second reading, on the subject of consultation and consideration between government and opposition in this place. He should look at the debate relating to the standing orders when reference was made to this bill, and then he would have a better idea of my point.

I am aware that he was absent yesterday. He paid me the courtesy of saying beforehand that he had an important engagement to go to. These things happen. Honourable members cannot always be here for the debate but he paid me the courtesy of explaining why he could not be here. He read that into the record and I certainly did not have a go at him yesterday. However, I said yesterday that he should take a look at my speech. If he is going to come back today and refer to it only selectively, then he ought to have realised that in my speech there was reference to a previous debate and he might have enlightened himself on the relevance of that to this bill as well.

I will say one other thing in that context. Part of the conversation the parliamentary secretary and I had yesterday, which was on the subject of his not being here, revolved around the fact that we were entering into a debate on standing orders. He said that, had it not been for that debate, he would have been here to hear my speech. He is aware that that debate took place; he is aware that it was an intervention and that it all happened yesterday, because it impinged very much on his ability to be present and participate yesterday.

Having said that, members of the opposition in no way resile from the view that we put forward that the information we have just been given in relation to these amendments presently before the House should have been given to us at the start. There was no reason for the office of the Deputy Prime Minister to say yesterday that the debate could not be deferred until today and that the bill had to go through yesterday. The bill could not go through yesterday. As a matter of fact, as I pointed out yesterday, the bill had already been here for more than four months so one day was not going to make that much difference if it were only for the matter of courtesies. We would have liked more than one day. As was referred to in yesterday's debate, there is an unwritten agreement called the seven-day arrangement, whereby the opposition has seven days from when a bill comes in until it is actually debated here to consider the substance of it. The point about these amendments presently before the House is that they are amendments of substance and we probably should have had seven days to contact people and get comment.

I do not say the parliamentary secretary is not telling me the truth when he apparently conveys the content of the conversation he had with the New South Wales Minister for Health yesterday; I am saying that opposition members are entitled to know what took place in that conversation from the New South Wales Minister for Health himself before we consider the amendment we are now being asked to agree to. I hope that is now clear. I point out to the parliamentary secretary that we will take the time and opportunity whenever they are available to raise in this place whatever we think is important.

I am perfectly well aware of what the new arrangements are in relation to the extra chamber and extra debating time. I do not need a lecture from the parliamentary secretary on that. I was part of the committee. I participated in several debates and I know all about that. I know the standing orders well enough to know that one sits down and then gets called again, as well as other things.

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't know that.

—No, I tried to help him but he did not take any notice of me. I believe we have made that point and I hope that the government takes it on board. The reason for the heightened sensitivity on the part of the opposition is that there is a very high level of sensitivity in this place at the moment with regard to the changes in the standing orders, the way they will affect the conduct of business and the way they will affect the democratic process in this country. We believe that the niceties that ought to be observed have not been and were not—and unnecessarily were not—regarded in this case. We think that that is a matter of some importance and we are going to make our position clear from the outset. That is the reason we called for the division on our second reading amendment and why we have insisted on getting all the information onto the record at this stage.

Bill, as amended, agreed to.
