DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1993-94Cognate bills:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1993-94APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1993-94

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems like quite a few hours ago that I had my first opportunity to start my address on Appropriation Bills Nos 3 and 4. Prior to the interruption, I was about to comment on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) which, in part, appropriates $175.7 million for the defence portfolio—including $88.6 million for defence facilities and a further $71.7 million for defence housing, reflecting rental payments to the Defence Housing Authority, which is one of the government's GBEs.

PARA.TAB: The only comment I want to make on that is that defence spending is a big ticket item as far as the government is concerned. We are all well aware of recent reports in the media on the progress of the contract between the Defence Department and the Australian Submarine Corporation in Adelaide. This contract involves something like $5 billion, of which up to about 80 per cent has been paid to the contractors. We have received one submarine; less than 40 per cent of the contract has been completed.

That company has paid some quite handsome dividends to its shareholders. I think government members should be put on notice, and I am sure they have been. As a member of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts I know that the committee is maintaining a watching brief on this matter. The Auditor-General in his report expressed concerns as to the amount of risk the Commonwealth was being exposed to with the way the contract is structured, so it is going to be interesting to see what happens. I thought it would be opportune to mention that along with the money that is being appropriated in this bill today for defence spending. In terms of our total expenditure and the revenue in this country, $5 billion is an awful lot of money. When I previously addressed the House on these bills I followed the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Knott), who made a number of interesting comments.

TALK.START.PARA: —He always makes interesting comments.

—He certainly does and, as I said earlier today, it is always good to follow him because it makes it easier to speak, particularly if he is in the chamber. He came over here and sat with us. I thought he was going to leave the government and join the opposition after his comments about fuel prices.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Gilmore made some interesting comments. One of them was about the levels of unemployment and also the labour market programs for which the government is appropriating a further $49.3 million. I think we should make a couple of interesting observations here—and I know that they have been made time and again to this government. This government, which has been in office for in excess of 10 years, has overseen the highest level of unemployment this country has experienced. We are seeing an enormous amount of spending on labour market programs. A number of these programs are under way in my electorate, and I will concede that a number of the labour market programs are good and are working. I refer in particular to the OLMA program. We have a very reactive OLMA committee on the mid-north coast that has developed a number of very good programs and is helping industry and that labour market adjustment.

We have also seen some interesting exercises undertaken by the local skillshare organisation in Taree, in particular, by a couple of its operatives Eric Trad and Mark Burton who, with a bit of lateral thinking and industriousness, went out to Griffith, into the area that is represented by my colleague the honourable member for Riverina (Mr Hicks), to seek employment for a lot of the unemployed people in the Taree area. They were quite successful. This week 44 people went from the Taree area to work in the orchards and vineyards, and I acknowledge that those involved in this program are doing a very good job. I also acknowledge the help that the honourable member for Riverina and his staff have given these people while they have been establishing this interesting program in the Riverina area.

At the same time, whilst expanding labour market programs in relation to the appropriation of extra funds, the government has not addressed labour market reforms or micro-economic reforms in the way it should have. It has been criticised by a number of different areas of industry in Australia for not doing so. It goes without saying that, until the government does address those areas, it is not seriously going to have any impact on the structurally unemployed, the long-term unemployed, that we have in this country. As the previous Treasurer said when bringing down the budget last year, unemployment is still the main issue that must be addressed.

It has been said this week in debate in this House that unemployment and what the government is and is not doing about it will be the issue in all the upcoming by-elections. The forecast for growth has been revised to 3.5 per cent. Bear in mind that last year—I think it might have been prior to the election—the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said that if we cannot achieve four per cent growth we should all give the game away. We on this side of the House are still waiting.

The revised estimate for inflation is two per cent. The revised estimate for investment is 4.2 per cent. The revised estimate for interest rates is low. We are still running a $16 billion deficit. It will be interesting to see what the forecast deficit in the May budget will be. What was the revised estimate for unemployment? It is the same as it was in the budget last year—10.7 or 10.75 per cent. The government is not willing to acknowledge that it will be able to do something about unemployment. It keeps talking about participation rates, but almost one million people are still unemployed. Those issues have not been addressed.

Labour market programs help alleviate the short-term problem; they do nothing about the long-term problem. The sooner this government realises that the better off we all might be; we might get on the road to some sort of a realistic and believable economic recovery in this country. The almost one million people who are unemployed might start believing some of the stories that the government is trying to tell them.

The challenge is still there for the government. The task force on regional development has brought down its report to the government. The government has identified regional areas as being very critical in addressing the unemployment problems that we have in our economy. The regional development task force, headed by ACTU Secretary, Bill Kelty, brought down its report, but there was not much in it. I want to read into Hansard some comments made by the President of the NFF, whom the Prime Minister claimed every day during the debate on the Native Title Bill before Christmas as his greatest ally and best friend. The NFF news release states:

SPEECH.PARA: NFF President, Mr Graham Blight, said that the Taskforce report proposed a tax-and-spend approach—
that is funny, that is all this government ever does, and here is Mr Kelty recommending more of the same—
to regional development, undercutting its potentially positive contribution to economic recovery.

"Too great a degree of government intervention jeopardises fiscal restraint and threatens to displace private sector investment and activity, which in the long run must underpin regional economic activity," Mr Blight said.
"We welcome the report's focus on infrastructure renewal, especially the goal of improving links between regional Australia and urban and international markets.
"Australia has run down much of its publicly-owned infrastructure. Expenditure in this area is overdue.

"However, by suggesting that fuel tax should be increased to fund much-needed rural road infrastructure improvement, the report fails to recognise that for economic recovery to occur business costs have to fall.

"The massive tax burden imposed on Australia's transport system from fuel excise and sales tax had not been addressed. Neither had the need for improved competition in freight services," Mr Blight said.
The Taskforce also incorrectly recommended that taxes on business should be increased to address labour market adjustment.

How much more can the productive sector of this country withstand from this government? The taxpaying base of this nation is getting narrower, the burden is getting heavier and sooner or later the further we go down this road people will just sag at the knees, give up and say, `Damn it all. Let's go and join the mob on the other side and we will stick our hand out'. How much more is this government going to load on to the productive sector in Australia?

PARA.TAB: In the life of this government there have been enormous increases in fuel excise. In 1982, federal excise was 6.155c a litre. What is it this year? In February 1994, it is 31.75c a litre—absolutely incredible. In 10 years, this government has taken the excise from 6c a litre to 31c a litre, but the important fact to acknowledge is that it is not being spent on roads and transport infrastructure in this country. It is propping up all the other programs of this government that it is not prepared to redress and reduce. It is a high taxing, high spending government. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile) has not stolen some of my time in tonight's debate because I will be saying some different things from that which he has enlightened the House with tonight. I want to talk about my electorate and review what has happened in the last 12 months since the election as regards the needs of that area. The electorate of Corinella is a substantial component of the south-eastern growth corridor of Melbourne. It is an area of young families, new housing and is growing at a phenomenal rate. The infrastructure needs in that area are significant and a major demand upon the local community and government at all levels.

PARA.TAB: In my first speech in this House, I spoke of those issues and of the need for the government to address them. I also talked, to some extent, about some of the developments on those fronts. I would like to take time tonight to detail to the House some of the movements and improvements that have occurred in that area that this government is responsible for.

The local capital works program, which honourable members would know, was part of the One Nation statement and was a major innovation in the way we get money out there to provide important community facilities. The program itself was targeted to areas with high unemployment levels on the basis of local government areas. One of its main targets was to create jobs. It provided a significant fiscal stimulus and also worked to provide important community infrastructure of long-term benefit to local communities. The program was widely acclaimed at the time and has been since by local government. It also had a major component of joint funding with local government. This meant that the actual money provided from the federal level was added to so that the overall benefits to the community were much greater.

The shire of Cranbourne is a major part of my electorate. Cranbourne received $1.92 million under this program. Projects already completed under the scheme include streetscape works in Main Street, Lang Lang, costing $90,000; the bicycle path from Shearwater Drive and Lyrebird Drive, Carrum Downs, costing $50,000; the Blind Bight Community House, costing $200,000, which I was pleased to officiate at the opening of recently; and the Cranbourne Community Centre, costing $480,000, which was a relocation of a neighbourhood house that was decrepit to modern premises to ensure that it could service the needs of that local community.

Still under way are projects like the Hampton Park Community Hall, costing $660,000; the Berwick-Cranbourne Road roundabout at Patterson Road, costing $600,000; and the North Road construction from Langwarrin to Centre Road, costing $360,000. That is around $2 1/2 million in projects on the basis of a $1.92 million stimulus from the government. It shows that, if we consider what can be done in an innovative fashion with other areas of government, particularly local government, we can exceed those moneys to further benefit the community. The Cranbourne shire engineering manager, Bruce Conboy, said that the projects had provided hundreds of jobs throughout the shire and that the scheme showed that the federal and local governments can work together.

I turn next to Springvale, an area of significant unemployment, which I share with the honourable member for Holt (Mr Duffy) and the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Crean). Springvale utilised the money to develop Springers Leisure Centre, which was opened recently. The centre, which took 10 months to build, provides three basketball courts, three netball courts, six volleyball courts, 10 badminton courts, two indoor soccer courts and a roller hockey court, as well as an extensive cafeteria and child-care areas. This is in an area where, basically, none of those sorts of facilities were available. This need was recognised by the council some 10 years ago. It had been working to try and get the money together since that time, but was unable to do so until this program came along.

The size of the building totals 6,290 square metres and is set on Tatterson Park, named after the late CEO of the council, Ian Tatterson. The design of the building was completed in September 1992, with council officers and consultants basing the design on community needs. Councillor Phillip Reed, the mayor of the city of Springvale said that Springvale had benefited from having this state of the art facility and also from the creation of 60,000 employment hours, generated in the building's construction.

Project managers Civil and Civic won a five-star rating from the National Safety Council for its high standard of occupational health and safety, one of only two five-star ratings to be granted to a construction project in Australia. We can see there that the initiatives undertaken and the results were important to those local areas, which were in urgent need of those sorts of facilities.

I now turn to the building better cities program. Under the better cities program, this government is demonstrating methods by which the growth of our cities can be tackled. Improved urban planning, better land use, increased housing choices and affordability, transport costs and availability, and the need for integrated service provision with developments are all part of what will be addressed.

The south-east area strategy covers my electorate. That area strategy will generate about $67 million worth of activity over five years, finishing in June 1996. The Commonwealth contribution is $34.8 million, or about 53 per cent of the total expenditure. That program in the south-east area will look at the electrification of the Cranbourne-Dandenong rail line. Cranbourne is an area, as I said earlier, of major growth and has very poor public transport. It is an area which has a high incidence of two-car ownership but can hardly afford it.

The strategy also involves the redevelopment of Dandenong railway station. Dandenong railway station is a transport hub in the region, but the area is decrepit and there have been concerns regarding drug use and vandalism. Further station improvements will also occur along the Pakenham line through the Narre Warren and Berwick stations. Through this project we will see public transport finally become a realistic choice for many residents in that growth corridor. They will have trains on a regular basis, they will have facilities that are worthy of patronage and those facilities will be safe and secure.

On from that, there is an urban land authority development site at Lyndhurst. That project will involve high density housing development, innovative design concepts and linkages to the public transport improvements that I mentioned earlier. A coordinated development with both housing and transport is involved.

In relation to building better cities, making sure there are communities within those cities that are viable and attractive for people to live in, and ensuring effective land use to try and avoid as much as possible the urban sprawl which characterises many of Australian cities are the sorts of initiatives that need to be trialled, checked out and used as examples of what can be done in the wider sense.

What is really annoying about this, I suppose, from a local member's point of view and also from the federal government's point of view is the fact that the state government in Victoria—and, I understand, in many other states—is endeavouring to claim this program as its own. The program would not have taken place without federal government money. The program is one where the state is often providing in kind assistance, for example, the land where the railway lines will go. Yet, whenever we see developments on these programs in the local area we see the local state minister, Alan Brown, announcing them. We see local state members of parliament claiming the credit for them, at one time crying poor and saying that they have no money and at the next stage coming along and saying, `Isn't this wonderful' and, if we are lucky, giving a short acknowledgment of federal government involvement. I think that is unfair and practically dishonest and not something that the government should tolerate.

I turn to a program which, unfortunately, was abolished in the last budget but which I will be pushing to have reinstated in the coming budget; that is, the black spot prevention program. Two particular black spots in my electorate were funded prior to the election and the constructions have since been completed. One was a set of boom gates at the railway crossing in Dandenong South on Greens Road, which is part of the railway line which will form the better cities electrification of the Cranbourne line. It is an area where, from February 1987 to December 1992, there was a total of 16 reported accidents. One person was killed and 15 were injured, nine of them seriously. It is obviously an intersection which required that sort of correction in terms of traffic control. The other correction was the Camms Road-South Gippsland Highway traffic lights. This crossroad has been the scene of 26 car accidents in the past six years. While there have been no fatalities, 18 people have been injured, three of them seriously.

When we look at the development of growth corridors and the development of new suburbs, we see that these sorts of initiatives are important because as they grow, as the traffic levels increase and as the speed increases, more and more accidents occur. It is incumbent on all levels of government to address those issues in whatever ways they can in terms of their responsibilities. As I said earlier, this is an important program. It is a program I support fully, and I believe this government should be moving to reinstate it in the coming budget process.

When we talk about the role of government in the local area, we also talk about government services. By government services I mean government offices that provide services for the people in those areas. Cranbourne has suffered from being a satellite, if you like, of Dandenong, or Frankston, depending on which way you approach it, and it is an area which has lacked government services. The lack of public transport has also made it more difficult for the residents of Cranbourne to access those services.

Two initiatives were announced prior to the election, on which I am pleased to inform the House of further action. The first one was a new CES office for Cranbourne. Cranbourne residents formerly had to go to Frankston or Dandenong to access CES services and, in a time of high unemployment, that was not appropriate or fair to those residents. At the time of the election, announcements were made regarding a job centre being provided. It would deal strictly with actual job vacancies and have limited scope for additional support services on site. That was important, but at the same time it was not sufficient, in my view. Since the election we have had a further development. This has now been upgraded to include not only a job centre but also an industry services centre, a special services centre and a youth access centre.

The industry services centre will provide direct support to local industry, helping to ensure that their particular needs are met, for example, designing specific assistance programs and organising placements as required. The special services centre will provide support for the long-term unemployed by specific assistance in terms of job referrals, counselling, assessment and programs such as job skills. The youth access centre will provide similar services targeted particularly at the young, which is a growing group in that area and a group that is particularly disadvantaged.

During the election campaign, the then social security minister, the former member for Bonython, announced that a Cranbourne DSS office would be funded in that financial year. That funding has since been confirmed; however, again, at the time only a local office was proposed. Now, instead of a local office, we are moving towards a regional office. Whereas a local office would have meant many DSS clients would still need to attend the Dandenong office for a number of DSS services, the new office will provide the full range of services in Cranbourne. The new office is scheduled to open around early 1995 and will incorporate the department's new open plan office structure.

At present, people in Cranbourne have to travel to Dandenong to attend a DSS office. As Cranbourne is a major growth area, this new office makes good sense. The new office structure represents a revolutionary approach for dealing with clients. It does away with the old stand-up counter approach used by the DSS for years. The open plan office will incorporate sit-down interview facilities and a far more comfortable waiting area.

In the past, criticisms have been made that DSS offices were dreary places where client confidentiality was poor. By allocating more space to the public contact area, the open plan office ensures confidentiality by utilising one-on-one interview facilities. More staff will also be allocated to the public contact area, which will lead to greater efficiency in the processing of clients' needs.

Some of these new types of offices are already operating, and from all reports clients readily approve of the changes. The whole atmosphere is friendlier and more receptive to people's needs. A trip to the DSS should not be a dehumanising experience. People who need to access the services of the Department of Social Security should be extended dignity, respect and, above all, privacy. This new office will help achieve those aims.

I now turn to a more controversial area which may involve some interaction with the opposition members present: the community, sport and recreational facilities grants. Three major grants were made in the area of Corinella. The first was an extension to the Cranbourne Senior Citizens Centre which will be opening, I think, in the next month. Cranbourne, as I have said, is an area of massive growth. Although this has not been principally elderly people, with the growth has come more elderly citizens and that centre is bursting at its seams.

During the election campaign I attended the centre with the former honourable member for Bonython to discuss DSS type concerns with the residents of that centre. The only issue they wanted to talk to us about was the question of when the money would be made available to have their centre extended. Their principal concern was with the council, which is part-funding it with us, in terms of the lead time it would take for it to construct the centre. In my two years as being active both as a candidate and as the member for Corinella, this was probably the most heartfelt meeting I have attended regarding the concerns of the local community. Those people were desperate for the development of that centre, they could illustrate clearly a need for it and they were fully supported by local government in the area. If ever a project was worthy of consideration and funding, this project was.

In addition, there was a major gym hall and community facility at Hampton Park Secondary College on which construction is due to commence soon. Hampton Park is a growing area full of young families, and there is absolutely nothing for kids to do. It is a joint development with the private sector. It will provide better school facilities, with access to the community after hours by a private management system. Once again, there is no doubt that this facility is required, it is demanded by the people of Hampton Park and it is certainly well and truly worthy of support.

The third was the redevelopment of the Wonthaggi Neighbourhood House in a rural part of my electorate. In the rural parts of my electorate there is a pressing need. The employment recovery which is occurring in the metropolitan parts of my electorate is not occurring in the rural areas at this time. Wonthaggi Neighbourhood House plays a crucial support role to many disadvantaged residents of Wonthaggi and surrounding towns, including parts of the electorate of the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), which is a National Party area. Once again, this is a project clearly worthy of support.

I now turn to school funding, on the tertiary, secondary and primary levels in my area. I would like to speak, firstly, about the recently announced Cranbourne TAFE College. An amount of $5 million has been earmarked for the project by the federal government. The funds for the project will provide jobs and go towards the completion of new buildings and facilities. Work on the new businesses and services facilities at Dandenong TAFE Cranbourne campus is scheduled to begin in 1996. The funds to build a new facility were provided through the Australian National Training Authority, an advisory body established last year to provide more training places and strengthen the country's training system. An amount of $200,000 will be provided in the second half of 1995, with a further $3.2 million and $1.6 million in 1996 and 1997 respectively.

Cranbourne as a local government area is in crying need of tertiary education facilities. We have—and it is shown through the statistics—the lowest participation rate in higher education of any local government area in Victoria. This TAFE college is essential to give local residents the opportunity to access tertiary education and put them in a position where they will be better able to contest the job market in the years to come.

Further on from that was the announcement made of a new campus for Monash University at Berwick. A total of $11 million has been allocated over 1994-95 to assist Monash in this development. This $11 million is in addition to $40.1 million allocated to Monash over the 1994-96 triennium for capital purposes. Monash will develop the Berwick campus as a component of an integrated network of campuses in the eastern half of Victoria, with a particular focus on the south-eastern growth area. The campus will be developed to provide facilities for on-campus teaching as well as serving as a hub for a multicampus delivery network involving the electronic linking of all Monash campuses. Monash has agreed to commit at least $9 million of its federal funding to construct teaching staff and support facilities at the site, with a further $2 million to be spent on the facilitation of multicampus delivery networks in the area.

I turn, finally, to the question of funding to non-government and state schools in the primary and secondary area. I will not go through the details, but over $2 million in the last 12 months has been granted to non-government schools in the Cranbourne-Corinella area because it is a growing area and there is a crying need for these facilities. It has provided new classrooms, new libraries and technology facilities, which have been widely applauded by the local community. The one concern that has come up—and this relates more, I guess, to the state government—is why we are putting money into non-government schools but not into state schools.

Here we have a situation where the state government has basically been misleading the Victorian public about what has been happening. The federal government has pumped millions of dollars into government schools in the shire of Cranbourne and more than half a million dollars more than the state government over the last three years. The figures from the director of school education show that in the years 1990 to 1993 inclusive the Commonwealth spent $8,306,100 on major works in government schools in the shire of Cranbourne. This compares with $7.624 million provided by the state government. Commonwealth funds are given to the state governments and administered by them. There are very broad guidelines which the states must adhere to. But generally it is up to the discretion of the states as to what areas and which schools the money is spent on.

We had a situation where local state members were saying that the federal government was not providing this money in the local area. But what happened was that they did not understand the figures. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moylan Mrs J.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak tonight on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4). In 1966 Professor Geoffrey Blainey wrote a book called The Tyranny of Distance in which he talked about how distance shaped the history of Australia. In that book he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Innovations which had come slowly over many years in the northern hemisphere were telescoped into a few years in Australia. The long era in which distance was a tyrant seemed suddenly, but mistakenly, to be fading away.

Those fluctuating fortunes have reaped another tyranny on this country—the tyranny of fuel taxes on the vast ribbons of road that traverse the continent. Just as a preamble, the estimated value of our road system in Australia is said to be approximately $100 billion. This asset has been paid for from the hard-won earnings of the Australian taxpayers. Any good property manager will confirm that it would be a gross dereliction of duty to own such a substantial asset and not make provision for its proper maintenance and care. That is exactly what the federal government is not doing—properly maintaining and caring for our federal road system.

PARA.TAB: In a vast continent where transport is paramount to our economic wellbeing, an increase in fuel tax—a tax that hits all road users, both domestic and commercial—is a great imposition. But, to rub salt into the wound, the federal government hives off a vast percentage of that tax to general revenue. This latest increase of tax on fuel is nothing more than a blatant grab for more cash from a government that has considerable difficulty in managing the budgetary concerns of this nation.

To add insult to injury on the fuel tax grab, the federal government's task force on regional development has proposed a new national petrol tax. The task force, chaired by Bill Kelty, suggests that motorists would accept a higher tax if the extra money raised was spent on roads. Back in the early 1980s a new tax was imposed on petrol to fund the bicentennial and other road projects. Little of that now goes to road funding, so why should anyone in our community believe that this further Kelty tax would be spent on roads?

This outrageous proposal to levy further imposts just underscores the cavalier attitude of this government towards the taxpayers and the management of this country's financial affairs. The situation is that the federal government is set to raise an estimated $8.5 billion in 1993-94 through the indexation of a fuel tax. This is a dramatic rise from a nearly $1.4 billion tax raised in 1982-83. We might say that everything has gone up—and everything has gone up, that is true. But it is the relativity between the increase in tax and the decline in dollars spent on roads in Australia which is so alarming.

In 1982-83 federal road funding amounted to 62 per cent of that revenue. By 1993-94 that ratio has dropped to 12 per cent and will fall to less than nine per cent according to forward estimates for 1996-97. Mr David West, Chief Executive of the Royal Automobile Club in Perth, said of the task force:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Taskforce has ignored the damage done to Australia's transport networks by the Government's continued failure to give road funding a fair share of the considerable revenue already raised from motorists.
He went on to say:
A new fuel tax will simply be another unjustified burden on motorists and increase transport costs in regional areas which already suffer from their remoteness and reliance on transport.

The increase in taxes and the decrease in funding has affected every state in Australia. Not one state is not moving into a downward trend in terms of the amount of money allocated to road funding. My own electorate of Pearce and, in particular, my own state of Western Australia has suffered a savage cutback in road funding. On the basis that Western Australia has 25 per cent of the length of national highways, at least 10.7 per cent of Commonwealth fuel tax collections, 9.5 per cent of the population, and 12 per cent of the national heavy haulage operating out of Western Australia, these figures do not convert very well in terms of fairness and equity.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the figures in dollar terms. Fuel excise revenue contributed by Western Australia amounts to more than $700 million and Western Australia will receive back only $77.1 million in road funding this financial year. That equates to a miserly seven per cent of the total national highway funding. To arrive at its so-called equitable position the government applies its `model' for determining funding. It conveniently overlooks the fact that many of our national highways are in remote areas—Western Australia being a particularly good example.

Isolated though they may be, these highways carry our vast mineral wealth to markets creating enormous revenue for the Commonwealth that all Australians share in. The wealth generated in Western Australia by mining, oil, gas and gold all contribute to the national economy. What my state wants is a better deal from the Commonwealth, starting with a fair ratio of fuel tax collections against revenue for allocation to road funding. As I mentioned before, no diligent asset manager would put a $100 billion asset at risk by failing to maintain it or provide the funds to maintain it; the ongoing maintenance of the existing national highways must be a funding priority.

In addition to upgrading of the existing national highway system, the expansion of the present national highway system is a necessity in any sensible approach to a federal road funding program. Geoffrey Blainey wrote how distance shaped Australia's history. Distance may well shape Australia's economic wellbeing and with it the future of most Australians. The fact is that road transport carries 80 per cent of freight in Australia and directly employs more than 100,000 people and another 300,000 people indirectly. It operates in a vast variety of conditions throughout Australia, from local distribution tasks to the enormous road trains of the outback. My colleague the shadow minister for transport, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp) highlighted this in a media release late last year when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is unfortunate that the Government's commitment to raising the standard in the most immediate sense—by the provision of a good and safe road infrastructure—has waned. The Federal Government's commitment to road funding has fallen this financial year (1993/94) to below the level of 1982/83 in actual terms. In real terms the decline is far more severe.

It is scandalous that this government is doing nothing to address the nation's short- or long-term road funding crisis. The issues at stake are many. There is the safety of everyday motorists, the commercial carriers' efficiency and the ongoing viability of our business sector to make a financial contribution to the nation. There is also the growing tourist numbers. We spend vast sums on attracting tourists but we do not have the infrastructure in place to accommodate their motoring and transport requirements and under this government we will not get that infrastructure. There is also the matter of ripping off motorists by way of a petrol tax without allocating back a fair and reasonable amount for road improvements.

PARA.TAB: The new Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) has a great opportunity to show the Australian people that he can come to grips with this important national issue. I was pleased to hear my colleague across the room, the honourable member for Corinella (Mr Griffin), talk about the black spots program. The Minister for Transport could start by seeking an appropriation of funds to reinstate the black spots program which was dropped in the 1993-94 budget. Unquestionably, this program made a major contribution to road safety with some benefits in the employment sector. When this program was first budgeted for, the then Minister assisting the Treasurer, in his second reading speech on the Appropriation Bill (No. 3), said:

SPEECH.PARA: This program (the Black Spot Programme) is a cost effective initiative to significantly improve safety standards at sites with a history of traffic accidents. In addition to improving the safety standards on Australia's road system, this increase in expenditure will create new employment opportunities.

The government boasted that the program would save 220 lives per annum and now the black spots program has been unceremoniously dumped. According to the Royal Automobile Club of Western Australia, the elimination of black spots is a cost effective way of improving road safety. Initial federal studies showed a reduction of more than 50 per cent in crashes. In Western Australia an evaluation by the Main Roads Department of more than half of the black spot sites showed that a treatment cost of $6.5 million resulted in reduced accident savings of about $60 million. That was the first year after the road improvements.

PARA.TAB: Motorists will be compromised and lives will be lost as motorists continue to pay higher and higher taxes on fuel, vehicles and spare parts. This must stop and I call on the government to start the process of turning around its appalling record since coming to office in 1983 and to reinstate the black spots program and return to our roads the money necessary to maintain and improve them and to ensure the proper management of a valuable national asset and the safety of all Australians and tourists to our country.

If we are to come to grips with this national issue it will be through a cooperative effort between the states and the Commonwealth. I have complete sympathy with the Prime Minister's stated objective in last night's speech at the Australian National University when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Over the coming decade, I'd like to see a new relationship with the states involved based on four principles. The first of these is that we recognise that the States have a vital role as units of government in Australia.
A little further in his speech he said:

And the fourth principle is that while the Commonwealth believes the states should be adequately resourced, it should be taken as understood that the Commonwealth will not be party to any substantial transfer of Commonwealth taxing powers to the States. Now within those four principles we have the opportunity to cooperatively develop, I think a new commitment, if you like a new consensus, a new understanding between the Commonwealth and the States about how to make these important areas of microeconomic change.

The Prime Minister must go beyond the rhetoric and match his stated ideals with some practical solutions. It is not good enough that the state premiers are forced to grovel in the dust like a bunch of poverty stricken peasants for a few crumbs off his heavily laden table. State bashing has to stop.

PARA.TAB: Meaningful dialogue between the states and the Commonwealth would be a good starting point and the minister for roads might pick up a point or two from his Western Australian counterpart, Mr Eric Charlton. Since coming to office only 12 months ago, he has ensured that Western Australia has become the only state to direct all federal untied money into road programs and he has increased the allocation of funds from state resources by a huge 34 per cent. This allocation has been made by virtue of efficient management of the public sector transport system and without any diminution of services. It is not a matter of saying, as the Prime Minister stated, that the states' idea of cooperation is just a question of handing over more money. It is a question of giving to the states what is rightfully their share of revenue to use for what is constitutionally their responsibility.

The Federal government has busied itself trying to interfere with education, social policy, health, the environment, and economic policy. It has even taken to usurping the role of parents via the youth homeless allowance, without any ongoing responsibility or coordination with the states. It is time the Prime Minister and his ministers recognised their limitations and set about concentrating on the issues of national importance that they can fix, doing their job well and not meddling in all of the other areas that they seem hell-bent on taking on. Their passion for self-exaltation and grandiose schemes smacks of the very megalomania that the Prime Minister seeks to distance himself from, as quoted in the Australian on 14 February 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.30 p.m., the debate is interrupted. I propose the question:

PARA.TAB: That the House do now adjourn.
Mr Kerr—I require that the question be put forthwith without debate.
Question resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1993-94Cognate bills:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1993-94APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1993-94

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the government is serious about its stated intention of getting on with the job of cooperating with the states, it should set about having dialogue with the states and it should endeavour to work on a cooperative basis, not to force the states to raise state tax in order to meet road standards that should clearly be funded by the Commonwealth taxing of fuel.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Mr Johns) adjourned.
Motion (by Mr Johns) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight because the minister for sports rorts—
—You might refer to the minister by her correct title. You know better than that.

—The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) is under a great deal of pressure. There is some speculation—and I think members of the government feel some sense of potential relief about it—that the former Premier of Western Australia is going to come to Canberra and somehow cleanse the government of its sins by being present on the government front bench.

PARA.TAB: During the adjournment debate on 13 November 1990, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) and I spoke very strongly about the need for a royal commission in Western Australia. This happened to be on the occasion of the tabling of a sensational report in the Legislative Council of the Western Australian parliament by the Parliamentary Commissioner for Administrative Investigations—in other words, the parliamentary ombudsman. He delivered a blockbuster report to the Legislative Council and called for a royal commission with extended powers—as was the case with the Fitzgerald inquiry—to investigate matters raised in the revelations contained in documents that were seized from Robert Smith, private investigator, who at that time was gaoled for bugging offences under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act. It took longer than a week for the then Premier of Western Australia to be dragged, screaming, to a royal commission. An article in the Australian of 21 November 1990, under a title of `Right Decision for Grubby Reason', editorialised:

SPEECH.PARA: Had Dr Lawrence been brave enough, when appointed Premier of Western Australia in February, to order a royal commission into political and business corruption, she would have won considerable credit. She could have expected the sort of kudos earned by Mr Mike Ahern when, as Queensland Premier, he set up the Fitzgerald commission to deal with allegations against a government of his own party. But Dr Lawrence showed no similar determination. When speed would have helped restore confidence in Western Australia's political and business processes, she chose the course of the delay trick. Her initial response to calls for a royal commission, made on the first day she took office, was to cite the Costigan inquiry into the failed financier, Rothwells Ltd, claiming one would pre-empt findings of the other . . . commented that only last week she answered demands for a royal commission by citing the advice of the Commission of Police, Brian Bull, who claimed such an inquiry would probably impede police investigations.

PARA.TAB: Now Dr Lawrence has changed her mind with a swiftness that is surprising and a stated rationale that is perplexing. The switch raises serious questions about whether her decision is an attempt to investigate corruption allegations or just another grubby exercise aimed at dispersing the spotlight of scandal so that it includes the ALP's political opponents as well.

In trying to justify her about-face, Dr Lawrence maintains that in the past fortnight, for the first time, claims of political corruption have been made and they attack the core of our democratic process. Her view seems to be that, despite the outstanding allegations made since the WA Inc. scandal was first disclosed, there has been little that is specific.

SPEECH.PARA: History has shown what futile words they were. It is my submission that the lateness of the calling of the Western Australian royal commission into WA Inc. impeded the opportunity for the vast millions of dollars to be either identified or recovered. Even her own minister for justice, now the opposition spokesman for justice, Mr Smith, called only recently for the NCA to investigate the money that is still missing from the Western Australian royal commission. In comments that have been made as a consequence of those remarks, it has been pointed out that there is little evidence around to track it down.

PARA.TAB: It is quite clear that, in contrast to this image of the Premier of Western Australia, Dr Lawrence, being somebody who rushed to form a royal commission in Western Australia to look into these scandals to try to find out where all this money had gone as a result of all these bungles made by the Western Australian government, she did no such thing. She had to be dragged screaming to a royal commission. It was only thanks to the outrage that was expressed by a combination of the ombudsman, the Western Australian Liberal Party and the media that she made that decision at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of this government's outstanding achievements has been the better targeting and scope of Australia's income support system. This nation's egalitarian values should always be reflected in the maintenance of a compassionate and effective safety net for those who require public assistance. The limited scope of government resources makes essential the targeting of welfare measures to those most in need. There are, however, several areas of public policy where equity issues have not been fully addressed.

PARA.TAB: The national government, in my assessment, has a role to play in rationalising the means by which state pricing policies transfer large hidden subsidies to high income earners. The wealthiest customers of state authorities are also the largest customers of electricity, gas and water, thereby enjoying the greatest benefit from partial cost pricing. Just as much, Australia's housing system and the appearance of a housing shortage show how hidden subsidies are too often transferred to those least in need.

In cities such as Sydney, Melbourne and Adelaide there are nearly as many bedrooms as there are people. The talk of a housing crisis is actually a question of distribution and the way government subsidies have overlooked the needs of private rental households. The national housing strategy has documented how private rental housing receives the smallest amount of government support per household even though it has the greatest number of households in poverty. It has brought these matters to the attention of the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) and they are now under government review. I look forward to a more equitable outcome of the distribution of those subsidies.

The housing strategy found that, on the annual value of housing subsidies and tax concessions in Australia, home owners received $1,200 per household, home purchasers $1,330, public tenants $1,800 and private tenants just $300. The Commonwealth-state housing agreement should develop a funding and administrative system by which, on the basis of means testing, private housing tenants receive as much government support as public tenants. The agreement, in my assessment, should also face up to the failure of state housing authorities to take an interest in urban renewal and community development. At Holsworthy, which adjoins my electorate and is part of the electorate of the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner), the Defence Housing Authority has shown how a shift to private ownership and basic housing, street and landscaping improvements can transform the quality of life in these estates.

If there is one thing that this government can do and the Deputy Prime Minister's housing strategy can achieve, it is to target public housing estates for a transformation in the quality of life. We cannot go on neglecting the poor planning outcomes of the 1960s and 1970s, the run-down in housing stock and the way in which we need to turn around some of the aspects of lifestyle that have been neglected by state authorities for so long.

Indeed, the recently completed Liverpool housing study in my electorate has recommended how similar cooperation and results can be achieved between the New South Wales department of housing and local government authorities. This has the potential to produce substantial benefits for the Glenquarie, Minto, Airds and Claymore housing estates in my electorate. The federal government will find no better way of building better cities than providing financial support for these projects.

This demonstrates an important point about the support role of government. The most successful public programs are those which empower the disadvantaged to take greater control of their own lives. My experience in local government has reinforced how the work of government is made doubly difficult without a sense of ownership, control and community pride. Any amount of self-sufficiency among disadvantaged groups will always achieve much more than welfare dependency.

These issues have great relevance in the electorate of Werriwa because they featured in the recent by-election campaign. The Liberal candidate for Werriwa tried to label and stereotype some of the public housing estates in the Campbelltown local government area, most regrettably by putting the label of ghetto on them. Admittedly, these areas have their problems, but I think there is a great responsibility for all people in public life to understand that we should be talking about solutions instead of trying to add to the stereotypes and labels that have been too much a feature of media comment in Sydney's south-west.

This makes a very important difference between the ALP and the Liberal Party. We do not look down our noses at people in public housing estates. We do not talk down to them. We do not try to put them down in that fashion. We are about some of the positive solutions that can make a difference. I trust that the matters I have outlined tonight in this adjournment debate will be picked up by the Deputy Prime Minister to show that solutions are at hand. It is possible to work with state and local government authorities to do a lot better than the labels and very unfair stereotypes suggested by those in the Liberal Party. I would ask them to apologise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the past few weeks Mutual Community, the largest private health insurer in South Australia, has been advising its members of fee increases, and once again there has been a clear cry from the community for greater support for those who provide for their own health cover. I can just remember the stickers when Medibank was first introduced that read `Your health and politics don't mix'. It is a slogan all political parties should remember today.

PARA.TAB: On this side of the House we learnt the lessons from the bulk-billing debate in the last federal election. However, when it comes to private health insurance the government still suffers some form of ideological myopia. True, it has advanced slightly from the typically sophisticated decisions made by the former Minister for Health, now Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services (Mr Howe) to marginalise the role of the private sector. However, the government has not yet done anything to increase the level of private health insurance. Instead, it merely wants to place a floor under the system to prevent further collapse.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has already rolled the current Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) over his proposal to increase the tax levy on high income earners who, like himself, do not have private health insurance. The minister has had to deal with campaigns against the private health sector from supposed allies, such as the Australian Nurses Federation and the ACTU. Senator Richardson must show the Australian people that their health comes first and the Labor Party second. While it might be hard for a Labor mate from New South Wales to oppose his own tribe, he must reaffirm his commitment to restructuring the health system and resist the pressure from his own party.

The reason the minister should do this is simple, and it is not driven by any reason other than plain economic fact: the private health system saves the government $2 1/2 billion a year; it pays the hospital bills for four out of every 10 Australians. The government clearly benefits from private health insurance. An expansion in the numbers of people with private health insurance and a greater utilisation of the bed capacity of private hospitals will only save the government money and create more room in an overcrowded public sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would increase the cost of health.

—Here is the honourable member for Gilmore, who has nothing better to do. He has no speech to give on the adjournment tonight so he wanders in to heckle members of the opposition. He really has so little to do—and in a marginal seat like Gilmore, where, if I am right, he has a margin of less than one per cent. What is the margin? Less than 1 per cent? Less than 0.5? He really has better things to do. With Jervis Bay on his mind, I imagine, he should be back in his office working instead of wasting our time.

PARA.TAB: Consumers of private health cover enjoy obvious advantages, and when their number expands even those without health insurance benefit from the reduced amount on the services in the public sector. The Liberal Party has continued to endorse the use of tax incentives to encourage Australians, particularly lower income earners, to take up private health insurance for all these reasons.

In the decade to June last year, the number of people with private health insurance dropped from 70 per cent to about 40 per cent. At this rate of decline it has been estimated that the figure will fall another 10 per cent by 1998. However, at the same time, the figures released by the Australian Health Insurance Association suggest that 66 per cent of Australians who do not have private health insurance would join a health fund if incentives were introduced. Groups like the Consumer Health Forum have argued that tax rebates for private insurance unsettle the tax base. They have claimed that rebates redistribute wealth from the less well off and the ones who suffer the most from poor health to the wealthy. However, it could be argued just as strongly that the behaviour of high income earners like the Prime Minister, who fail to take out private health insurance and who draw on scarce community resources, is equally regressive.

The argument for private health insurance should not be seen in purely ideological terms. If the decline in the number of people without health insurance is not reversed, we will see horrendously long waiting lists for elective surgery, overcrowding of public wards and a gradual diminishing of service overall. The public health zealots will have triumphed in creating a system with no equity at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —I bring to the attention of the House this evening a clear issue of the double standards in the application of the income tax law. A 10-year tax bungle that involves thousands of dollars of tax having been overpaid by retiring police officers in New South Wales has in fact extended to a range of New South Wales government employees, including the Maritime Services Board employees as well. But tonight I am specifically talking about tax.

PARA.TAB: We all know that if we owe the Commissioner of Taxation $100, he will pursue us up hill and down dale forever to get that money. But here we have a case where police officers retired. The analysis of their lump sum on retirement and the balance of their payment was calculated in error and they were heavily overtaxed. They knew nothing of this until quite some years later. For many of them the three-year deadline was 1986 and they did not object to their assessment by 1986 so they are debarred by taxation law from gaining a refund of the tax that they had overpaid in innocence. So the contrast is: if we owe the tax commissioner, he will get us; but if the tax commissioner owes us, we cannot get him. For these retired persons—men getting up in their higher years—as each year passes by, the money goes down in value, the commissioner has a free loan of it, inflation takes its toll on it, and the men's opportunity to use it becomes less and less.

I brought this matter to the attention of the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear). I brought it to the attention first of the Australian Taxation Office. It correctly said that the Income Tax Assessment Act preclude it from making a refund because the date for objection has passed. I then took it to the Assistant Treasurer and he told me what I expected he would tell me—the same thing. But the Taxation Office did take it to the Department of Finance and asked it to make an act of grace payment. The response of the Department of Finance was that the Audit Act 1901 allows act of grace payments only where there is evidence of Commonwealth maladministration. In this case, it was maladministration by the New South Wales police force in providing the wrong information on group certificates. As the Commonwealth government was not involved in maladministration, the department chose not to recommend any act of grace payments.

Further advice from the Taxation Office has informed me that other provisions within the Audit Act 1901 would enable act of grace payments to be recommended. The upshot is that these former police officers and other state government employees have been heavily overtaxed. In one case, the gentleman had $1,700 taken from him. There is another case of $1,000. They are not small amounts of money; they are substantial amounts of money. Honourable members can visualise what the taxation commissioner would be doing if these people still owed, for example, $1,700 in tax.

But the commissioner has the money. He says he cannot pay it out because the tax act does not let him. The Department of Finance will not recommend it because it has chosen a particular interpretation of the Audit Act 1901, which I believe to be a faulty interpretation.

Tonight I bring this matter to the attention of the House on behalf of my constituents and all state government employees in New South Wales who have suffered under incorrect information. I ask the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) to look at this issue very seriously and ensure that there is provision within the Audit Act 1901 to enable prompt refunds to be made to these taxpayers. If he still thinks it cannot be done, the taxation act should be amended very promptly so that these people can get back the money that has been owed to them since, in these cases, 1983 and 1984. I hope that both ministers involved—the Assistant Treasurer and the Minister for Finance—will give this request their very prompt and favourable consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening in the adjournment debate I want to bring to the attention of the House and, in particular, the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) a question I have on the Notice Paper: has the government reviewed its intentions with respect to the introduction of SBS services to the mid north coast region of New South Wales; if so, what are the details? I have not yet received a response to that question, but I presume it will be in the pipeline shortly.

PARA.TAB: I received this week further correspondence from some people in Port Macquarie. They represent a number of my constituents who are concerned about the equity in the provision of these services between the metropolitan areas and the regional areas in particular of New South Wales. At this point, I note that I did hear—I do not know whether it is rumour or fact—that SBS television will soon become available in the rural areas of north-west Tasmania. If that is the case, I ask the minister whether he is also planning to do something about the mid north coast and the north coast of New South Wales. The letter I have received from Guy and Molly Bogan of 198 Granite Street, Port Macquarie states:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr Vaile
Subject: Enabling residents of Port Macquarie to receive the TV broadcasts of SBS.
This, the second letter that they have written to me, continues:
Reference my letter of 29/5/93 and your reply of 8/6/93.

PARA.TAB: As 7 1/2 months have elapsed since your letter, would you please ask the Minister for Communications in Parliament, and inform me, of the current situation . . .

SPEECH.PARA: That situation is the provision of SBS television services to the mid north coast. These are two people out of a number of constituents who have lobbied me and asked me to make representations on their behalf to the Minister for Communications and the Arts on this issue.

PARA.TAB: In Taree, there is a group called the SBS Group for the Mid North Coast. Over a number of years, it has been talking with the Department of Communications about trying to provide this service to our area. It is an area which, from the mast on Middle Brother Mountain, would probably service 100,000 people or more. This group in Taree has taken it upon itself to raise funds privately to buy its own transmitter and to establish it on a high point in the Taree area. That will only service about 40,000 people. The point is that it is raising private funds to buy this transmitter.

In the early stages of its negotiations with the government department—it was with whichever the preceding authority was prior to the establishment of the National Transmission Authority—it asked whether it could establish its own transmitter on the mast on Middle Brother Mountain. The answer was yes. The rental that was suggested was about $1,500 a year. Its members then said, `We'll cost out what it will cost the community to buy this equipment to establish its own SBS service'.

They came back and found that they were now dealing with one of the government's new GBEs, the National Transmission Authority. I have not got to the stage of finding out its community service obligations and to what extent the government funds them, but when they went back and said, `We want to put our own transmitter which we will buy on the mast that is under your control on Middle Brother Mountain west of Laurieton', they were told by the National Transmission Authority that the cost of renting the space on the tower was not going to be $1,500 a year but $25,000 a year.

This group, which is raising funds within the local community, could not afford that amount and had to seek another site where it could put its transmitter. It did that through one of the local utilities. It is on a high point in the area which will service the majority of the Manning Valley community. Before this group purchased its equipment it wanted to test whether it could redirect the signal into the local area and what its success rate would be. We contacted the National Transmission Authority to see whether it would do a test of this new location before this group, with private funds, bought its new transmitter. The authority said, `No. Go jump. You do it yourself. You buy your transmitter. You go and do your own testing'.

Here we have this government, through its government business enterprise, the National Transmission Authority, saying that it will not assist in testing a site for this private group which wants to provide a service to the Manning Valley community on the mid-north coast that should be provided by this government. It is starting to recognise the importance of regional development, and the provision of communication services is a most important aspect of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knott Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call for an enquiry into the bank rip-offs that are taking place in this country. An independent government enquiry must be urgently initiated into banks ripping off their investors. The federal government must take appropriate action to prevent banks from taking advantage of defenceless investors due to the big four banks' total monopoly on interest rates. Recent figures produced by the OECD to September 1993 confirm that Australia is now charging the second highest margin in the world. In fact, the margin charged by banks has, in the last twelve months, ripped off Australians by more than $790 million. As banks have grown their profit margin has grown from 3.8 per cent to 4.4 per cent.

PARA.TAB: It is truly amazing that in the midst of a recession the profits of the big four banks, that is, the NAB, ANZ, Westpac and the Commonwealth, have turned around from a loss of just under $400 million last year to a profit of over $4 billion, even after writing off some $5 billion in bad loans and carrying some $17 billion in non-performing debts. It has also been seen over the last twelve months that the NAB profit increased by 67 per cent to $1.3 billion, apart from the massive turnaround of a $1.6 billion profit recorded by Westpac to 30 September 1993.

The question must be asked: how can a massive loss be turned into a resounding profit in such a short period without being at the expense of defenceless Australian investors who cannot compel banks to reduce their excessive margins? A disgusting position exists with pensioners now forced to dig into their limited remaining capital merely to survive. By the time pensioners pay bank and government duties, they are likely to be earning no more than 3 per cent on their money.Small businesses are paying a ridiculous premium to the banks. This is leading to more and more unemployment. Moreover, small businesses and farmers are being charged an even higher premium than the base lending rate. Essentially, bank margins are frustrating the emergence of the housing and business market from recession.

The government has a responsibility, as does the chairman of the banking industry, to create controls on bank lending margins as investors are defenceless to take on the monopoly that exists among the big four banks. Naturally, they invest with the major banks as they know they are guaranteed by the government of the day. Also, a serious perception of banks exists wherein individuals are obsessed about paying off their bank loans as quickly as possible. Often they do not properly manage for their retirement by setting aside their own contribution moneys into superannuation, apart from what their employers must compulsorily provide, as they are petrified of banks foreclosing on their properties. In addition, from a small business perspective, they are concerned to retire debt as banks keep criticising small businesses saying that they are not making enough profits and have insufficient retained earnings. Therefore, small businesses believe they are compelled to clear up existing debts due to their lack of confidence in the future.

If talented and skilled individuals do not commence their own businesses, a tremendous drain and loss of intellectual skill and talent will occur in Australia. Already many talented individuals are leaving the country to move to the United States and Japan so that their

SPEECH.PARA: special skills can bear fruition. Also, many individuals will go and work for large companies and never truly develop personal skills that are only brought to fruition by their running their own stand-alone businesses. Banks offer no support to small businesses. Government intervention is necessary. Sadly, the banks' record profit is very much at the price of individuals and small business survival.
